title: jquery 3 ready function does not work correctly
body:
Good afternoon!

I moved from jquery 1.11.1 to jquery 3.3.1. I have the following code on the page:
...
    <script type="text/javascript">
        function onJqueryLoad() {
            $(function () {
                console.log(document.readyState);
                 window.app = new App({
                    logsUrl: '3434'
                });
            });
        }
    </script>
    <script type="text/javascript" src="~/Scripts/jquery-3.3.1.js" defer onload="onJqueryLoad()"></script>
	...
	/// more scripts
	...
    <script type="text/javascript" src="~/Scripts/Common/App.js" defer></script>
...
In the console I see the following error:

interactive


jquery-3.3.1.js:3818 jQuery.Deferred exception: App is not defined ReferenceError: App is not defined
    
at HTMLDocument.<anonymous> (http://localhost:53228/:12:35)
    
at mightThrow (http://localhost:53228/Scripts/jquery-3.3.1.js:3534:29)
    
at process (http://localhost:53228/Scripts/jquery-3.3.1.js:3602:12) undefined


Uncaught ReferenceError: App is not defined
    
at HTMLDocument.<anonymous> ((index):12)
    
at mightThrow (jquery-3.3.1.js:3534)
    
at process (jquery-3.3.1.js:3602)

It turns out that the contents of $ (function () { were called before the App.js script was loaded, and the status of document.readyState was “interactive”.
But if you do not use “defer” when importing jquery:
<script type="text/javascript" src="~/Scripts/jquery-3.3.1.js" onload="onJqueryLoad()"></script>
then the console will have the status: “complete” and no problems will arise.
Description of the status document.readyState interactive (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/readyState):
"The document has finished loading and the document has been parsed, but sub-resources such as images, stylesheets and frames are still loading."
I failed to find more detailed information on whether the status “interactive” indicates that all scripts are loaded.
I checked it in the latest versions of chrome and firefox, but in Microsoft Edge no problem.
In the earlier version of jquery 1.11.1, there were no such errors.
Any thoughts?

title: How to change JQuery language?
body:
Hi there,

I developed a site using `ASP.NET Core` and I implemented the localization logic using [this](https://docs.microsoft.com/it-it/aspnet/core/fundamentals/localization?view=aspnetcore-2.1) documentation. I'm using `Bootstrap + JQuery` so I encountered a little problem on the localization, in particular, if I change the default language (italian) to english, I still get the validation message provided by `JQuery` in italian, and of course this is bad because the user has changed the language to english.
Is possible to tell to `JQuery` to use the english localization when the language change in someway? How can I do this?

I didn't found anything related on internet, I also opened a question [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/52126578/how-to-change-bootstrap-localization/52129137?noredirect=1#comment91208943_52129137) but still no good answers.

/*! jQuery v2.0.3 | (c) 2005, 2013 jQuery Foundation, Inc. | jquery.org/license

/*! jQuery v3.3.1 | (c) JS Foundation and other contributors | jquery.org/license */
...

title: HTML hidden attribute on elements made visible with show() or toggle()
body:
### Description ###
When a hidden element `<div id="foo" hidden>` is made visible with `$('#foo').show()` or `$('#foo').toggle()` it still has the `hidden` attribute.
Apart from semantics, this is wrong because with a rule `[hidden] { display: none !important }` in the stylesheet, `show()` and `toggle()` will not work. (Uncomment this rule in the CodePen.)
Thus, `show()` and `toggle()` should remove `hidden` attributes from the elements.

### Link to test case ###
https://codepen.io/gunnarbittersmann/pen/jvNNpx?editors=1111

title: $.each breaks on string
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest version of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What actually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

### Description ###

When calling $.each with jQuery 3.3.1 like so:
```javascript
$.each("woohoo");
```

**What actually happens**

It breaks with an error:
```
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot use 'in' operator to search for 'length' in woohoo
```

**What I expect to happen instead**

I think it should do either one of two things:
1) Loop through the string character by character.
2) Output a more sensible error, something like "incorrect parameter type string for jQuery.each"

**Browsers affected**

* Firefox and Chrome throw the error above
* Edge throws a different error `Invalid operand to 'in': Object expected` which means the same.
* Safari throws another different error `TypeError: obj is not an Object. (evaluating '"length" in obj')` which means the same again.

I suspect this problem affects every browser.

### Link to test case ###

https://jsfiddle.net/botp2fuL/1/

### Use-case ###

I was each-ing through an object that is expected to sit in a data attribute on an element. Somehow, because of undue circumstances let's say, that data attibute is no longer rendered by the server as valid json, and is therefor passed to my code as a string, throwing the error I describe here.

Novice developers might ignore this error for too long, because it doesn't look like an error in their code. This is no excuse, but I do believe clear error messages, or expectable behaviour when doing this on purpose, helps everyone.

Thanks!

title: use visualViewport's value for $(window).height()
body:
### Description ###
In recent Chrome,`window.visualViewport` is available to get window size.
[Window.visualViewport - Web APIs | MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/visualViewport)

This is the only value that can follow the address bar shrinking on mobile browsers.
`window.innerHeight`, `document.documentElement.clientHeight` don't work well.

So consider to use `window.visualViewport.height` for `$(window).height() `  if possible.

----

(Ditto for `width`.)

title: Why running `npm run build` results in an equivalent but different jquery.min.js file?
body:
### Description ###

  *  What do you expect to happen?

I was hopping to run `npm run build` in a repo without making any change, and get the exact same *dist/jquery.min.js*

  *  What actually happens?

I am getting an equivalent *dist/jquery.min.js*, but with different variable names, different line separators in some cases, and some extra parenthesis. For example:

Checked-in *min* file:

```
globalEval:function(a){var b,c=eval;a=n.trim(a),a&&(1===a.indexOf("use strict")?(b=d.createElement("script"),b.text=a,d.head.appendChild(b).parentNode.removeChild(b)):c(a))}
```

Produced *min* file:

```
globalEval:function(a){var b,c=eval;(a=n.trim(a))&&(1===a.indexOf("use strict")?(b=d.createElement("script"),b.text=a,d.head.appendChild(b).parentNode.removeChild(b)):c(a))}
```

Notice how the new produced file has more parenthesis, and one less comma.


  *  Which browsers are affected?

None


Is there any other command that will give me the exact same minified version? I would like to make some changes, and use the official tools to minify the file, but I expected to get mostly the same output, which would make (private) code reviews easier to approve.

title: jQuery.ajax method removal not documented in final release note
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:

  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

### Description ###
In jQuery 3.0 Release, `success, error, complete` are removed from `jQuery.ajax`. This is not documented in the [final release note](https://blog.jquery.com/2016/06/09/jquery-3-0-final-released/). The only place I can find it mentioned is the [beta release note](https://blog.jquery.com/2016/01/14/jquery-3-0-beta-released/).
> ### Removed special-case Deferred methods in jQuery.ajax ###

Please add this change to the final release note. @timmywil

title: Unable to query a form when it has input element with name="id"
iOS 7 fails dimension SVG tests
body:
It seems as if this iOS/safari version ignores `box-sizing:border-box` when the `width` attribute is used (`<svg width="100" style="box-sizing:border-box">`), unlike the width `style` (`<svg style="width:100px; box-sizing:border-box">`).

The failing tests could easily be updated to put the sizing in the `style` attribute. But maybe this is also a real bug worth fixing? Seems to only occur with Safari in iOS7 (iPhone 5).

See http://swarm.jquery.org/result/2886392

title: .is(':hover') doesn't work with multiple elements
body:
In this example, the second Javascript line fails. ```html
``` ```javascript console.log( $('div').is(':hover') ) ; //this line works fine console.log( $('div, span').is(':hover') ) ; //this line throws an exception ``` Jsfiddle here: http://jsfiddle.net/kbohu58w/9/ The documentation for `.is()` says that it returns true if at least one of the elements matches the selector. Which means `.is(':hover')` should work for multiple elements. But as the example shows, it doesn't.

title: css() function called with ";" added in the values did nothing
body:
### Description ###

This is the right way to call css().

```
object.css("border", "solid red 1px");
```

object.css("border", "solid red 1px;");

### Description ###
I have an application where the customers can load arbitrary HTML code which is then loaded into the DOM via jQuery.
A customer had a copy and paste error which linked to an non existing js file. This lead to an 404 but nevertheless jQuery pushes the return value (error HTML page) into a HTMLScriptElement text property. This leads to an exception:

    Uncaught SyntaxError: Unexpected token <
    at DOMEval (jquery-3.3.1.js:111)
    at Function.globalEval (jquery-3.3.1.js:345)
    at text script (jquery-3.3.1.js:9640)
    at ajaxConvert (jquery-3.3.1.js:8784)
    at done (jquery-3.3.1.js:9255)
    at XMLHttpRequest.<anonymous> (jquery-3.3.1.js:9548)
    at Object.send (jquery-3.3.1.js:9600)
    at Function.ajax (jquery-3.3.1.js:9206)
    at Function.jQuery._evalUrl (jquery-3.3.1.js:9367)
    at domManip (jquery-3.3.1.js:5759)

### Minimal test case ###
Put this HTML onto an webserver:
````html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <script type="text/javascript" src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-3.3.1.js"></script>
    <title>Title</title>
	<script>
	function clickme() {
			var jBody = $(document.body);
			jBody.append('<script type="text/javascript" src="notexisting.js"><'+'/script>');

	</script>

  <body>
        <button onclick="clickme()">Click</button>
  </body>
</html>
````

title: jquery.js:4745 Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'createDocumentFragment' of undefined
Invalid encoding of %20 char sequence in $.ajax post, put body
body:
### Description ###
Seems that jQuery 3 replaces `%20` char sequence to `+` in a request body during PUT and POST. A request like 
```javascript
$.ajax({
  method: 'put', 
  url: '/test/doc', 
  dataType: 'json',
  headers: {'content-type':'application/json'},
  data: JSON.stringify({val:'%20'})
})
```
actually sends `{"val":"+"}` in 3.2.1 and 3.3.1, both with Migration tools. 

jQuery however 2.x behaves correctly.

Update. Seems the reason is this block https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/src/ajax.js#L617-L621. It assumes `s.contentType` is the only source of `Content-Type` header, but there can be `s.headers['content-type']`, which later (https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/src/ajax.js#L648-L650) overrides `s.contentType` value.

title: Explore removing boolean attribute string value changes
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest version of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What actually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

### Description ###

Our boolean attribute handling tries to keep boolean attribute values valid according to the spec, by always setting the lowercased attribute name regardless of what value was set. However, we do this for all elements whether the boolean attribute is valid on that element or not. This is especially troublesome for custom elements.

Rather than checking the nodeName of the element to ensure the boolean attribute applies to that element, it may be doable to just allow any string through. It may not be technically valid, but I think it works in all browsers to set any string. We'd still want to keep the special handling for the value `false` (i.e. remove the attribute rather than set `"false"`, which is actually `true`). Note that the string `"false"` would still be passed through.

### Link to test case ###

See https://github.com/angular/angular.js/issues/16602#issuecomment-397794145 for background.

Use jQuery@3.1.1

title: Issue with serialize on form when a HTML form control element has a name of "elements"
body:
### Description ### When a form control element has a `name` of `elements`, calling `.serialize()` on a jQuery object containing the form causes an issue. When calling `.serialize()` on the jQuery form object `jQuery.prop( this, "elements" );` (from [this line](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/1ea092a54b00aa4d902f4e22ada3854d195d4a18/src/serialize.js#L102)) will return a different result if there is a control element with a `name` of `elements`. Here is the returned value with no element named `elements`:
Screenshot

Here is the returned value with several control elements with name `elements`:
Screenshot

**Note:** In this case `jQuery.prop( this, "elements" );` returns only the 3 elements with `name` `elements`. **Form contents (no elements named `elements`):** ```
``` **Form contents (notice 3 control elements have the `name` `elements`):** ```
``` ### Link to test case ### Clicking on `Add to cart` on these pages will cause the issue to occur. Adding a breakpoint in the `jQuery` plugin on the site for [this line](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/1ea092a54b00aa4d902f4e22ada3854d195d4a18/src/serialize.js#L102) will allow you to see the result: - With issue: https://jquery-potential-bug.myshopify.com/products/name-is-elements - Without issue: https://jquery-potential-bug.myshopify.com/products/name-is-not-elements

title: `outerWidth()` doesn't work on IE when content width matches style=width specification when `box-sizing` set to `border-box`.
body:
### Description ###
`.outerWidth()` calculation on IE 11 (Version: 11.98.16299.0IS, Windows 10 64-bits) is different from Chrome and is wrong, I think.

In the attached test case I have a table with 3 header rows. First cell in each row has a different width (200px, 190px, 180px), top row overrides width of cells in the 
When width specified in style attribute matches content width of the element - the value returned by `.outerWidth()` is different.

Running the test case on IE (in console) produces 200, 190, 200 while on Chrome the result is 200, 200, 200.

This is messes with my `dataTables` and `fixedColumn.dataTables` components that rely on `.css('width')` and hence `.outerWidth()`.

The problem seems to be in `getWidthOrHeight` function (jQuery v3.3.1). Specifically this line (6368):

```
	// Check for style in case a browser which returns unreliable values
	// for getComputedStyle silently falls back to the reliable elem.style
	valueIsBorderBox = valueIsBorderBox &&
		( support.boxSizingReliable() || val === elem.style[ dimension ] );
```

`val` is coming from `window.getComputedStyle().width` but `elem.style['width']` is coming from `style` attribute (as I understand it). And when these two values are equal it leads jQuery to believe that `val` is a `border` box size already and doesn't add padding.

Changing the width of the second row cell to `191px` or `189px` results in `outerWidth()` of the problematic cell (`th`) to `200`.

### Link to test case ###
https://codepen.io/rgavrilov/pen/KeqxJp

I expect all 3 values printed to codepen's console to be the same, but they differ on IE, even though all 3 TH cells (of the first column) are of the same width.

title: GetClientRects error for disconnected node in IE
Seirous bug with jquery acessing window
body:
Hi,

For long time I use the "disable-web-security" flag when launching my Chrome so I can open windows (using javascript) in different domains and still being able to access the window's content.

This is for testing/debugging purposes and LOTS of devs use this "disable-web-security" flag from Chrome to do all sorts of tests. It's a very important feature.

HOWEVER, even if the browser ALLOWS external domains access to iframes/windows in different domains for some weird reason JQUERY 3.x shows an error when trying to access these iframes/windows. JQUERY 1.12.4 didnt have have this problem.

You can check this bug very easily: 

1) first close all chromes windows/instances on your computer and then relaunch it using the disable-web-security flag, something like the code below:

start "Chrome" "chrome.exe" --disable-web-security 

2) after that acess this jsfiddle -> http://jsfiddle.net/36sewf1p/1/   -> this fiddle will simply open a window (with an external domain) and after 5 seconds will try to access its content.

3) check your browser console (in the jsfiddle tab) and you will see this error:

Blocked a frame with origin "http://fiddle.jshell.net" from accessing a cross-origin frame.
    at http://fiddle.jshell.net/_display/:34:24

title: position: relative being added to elements when calling .offset() with arguments
body:
### Description ###
When calling `.offset` with arguments, `setOffset` is called which will set the position to 'relative' if the element either has no position or has `position: static`.

Is there a reason that the position is not reverted to the previous state before exiting the function?

Seems like it should collect the current style here
```
	// Set position first, in-case top/left are set even on static elem
	if (position === "static") {
		elem.style.position = "relative";
	}
```
and set it back after calculations.

### Test case ###
Exposed when using affix plugin for Bootstrap 3.3.7

### Workaround ###
Set style in css with `position: (absolute|fixed) !important`

Feature Requests:

Frequently Reported Issues:

-->

### Description ###
`v.3.3.1`

I see that the object returned by `$.ajax()` contains a `promise()` function. However, looking at the documentation of `jqXHR` I cannot find this function being mentioned anywhere:
- https://api.jquery.com/jQuery.ajax/#jqXHR
- https://api.jquery.com/Types/#jqXHR

Also the function does not exist in `XMLHttpRequest` (for which jqXHR is a superset)
-  https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/XMLHttpRequest

`Deferred` has a `promise()` function, but I can see that `jqXHR` is not a `Deferred`, since it does not have a `resolve()/reject()`

Should't the function be referenced in the `jqXHR` documentation?

title: Type of async function should be function

body:
Tested on Chrome on an android phone connected to my computer with [remote debugging](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/chrome-devtools/remote-debugging/).

**Expected behavior:**
When I am scrolling through the page, `$(window).innerHeight()` (and `outerHeight()`) should be equal to the height of the browser page.

**Actual behavior:**
On a mobile device, the returned value for `$(window).innerHeight()` seems to be the same as the innerHeight on page load, which has the top address bar visible to make the screen smaller.

E.g.:
On page load, innerHeight() returns `560` for me. The page height is correct.
On scroll event, innerHeight() still returns `560`. The browser has collapsed the address bar and the innerHeight is now `616` for me.

Open http://jsbin.com/vevicuvoxu/1/ on a phone and scroll down.

![screen shot 2018-05-17 at 3 33 59 pm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12423598/40207144-d8ac2944-59e7-11e8-80dd-14e1289a1e0e.png)

**Work around:** `window.innerHeight` is still showing the correct value, so I had to use that for now.

title: i want to do something for Korean students
prev().hide issue on jQuery slim
body:
Here is a simple code where I notice issue on jQuery slim (https://jsfiddle.net/Chiarucia/st825n9r/ )
(actually this is example from http://api.jquery.com/hide/).
**1. What I expect to happen:**
a) By clicking "Hide" button last span child starts to hide, the previuose and so on. 
b) By pressing "Show" - all spans appears slowly.
**2. What actually happens:**
a) By clicking "Hide" button last span child hides.
b) By pressing "Show" - last span child shows (fast).

Here is the same code that runs perfect on jQuery (edge) (https://jsfiddle.net/Chiarucia/6ypjt24f/).

Simplified code https://jsfiddle.net/Chiarucia/nhwer8st/ ,where I expect hiding or showing slowly - on **jQuery slim** outputs **fast**. On **jQuery 3.3.1** or else is working perfect.
Browser - google Crome (Version 66.0.3359.13)

Is it a bug on jQuery slim? 
(i am brand new to codding world, so can't figure out more)

_**Links to test code:**_
jQuery slim not working perfect https://jsfiddle.net/Chiarucia/st825n9r/
jQuery (edge) working perfect https://jsfiddle.net/Chiarucia/6ypjt24f/

title:
$("
") not work
Bug: `$('> SELECTOR', parent)` selector false positives if some children have same id as parent.
body:
## Summary The `$('> SELECTOR', parent)` selector produces too many matches, if children of parent have the same id. ## Test case https://jsfiddle.net/hecpovge/1/ (run with open browser console) (Chromium Version 65.0.3325.181 (Official Build) Built on Ubuntu , running on LinuxMint 18.1 (64-bit)) ```html
LEVEL 1
LEVEL 2
LEVEL 1
LEVEL 2
LEVEL 1
LEVEL 2
``` ```js var $ = jQuery; var div0 = $('div')[0]; console.log('div', $('> span', div0).length, $('span', div0).length); var abc0 = $('#abc')[0]; console.log('abc', $('> span', abc0).length, $('span', abc0).length); var xyz0 = $('#xyz')[0]; console.log('xyz', $('> span', xyz0).length, $('span', xyz0).length); ``` ## Expected `$('> span', parent)` should always find the "LEVEL 1" element, but not the "LEVEL 2" element. ## Actual `$('> span', xyz0)` finds "LEVEL 1" and "LEVEL 2". ## Notes I am aware it is not "allowed" to have multiple elements with identical ids. But I think it is wrong to rely on that.

title: Security Vulnerability
body:
Hello,

Currently we using the jQuery-1.11.1 library on our website and the Google Chrome browser Audits tool detects them as vulnerable. Please find this link for more details:

https://snyk.io/vuln/npm:jquery?lh@1.11.1

Can you please confirm if this is a legit issue? If so, then would you please advise hot to fix it?

Thank you,
Rustam.

title: Add render function to elements
body:
### Description ###
Requesting for a "render" function on elements.
From time to time I run into a situation where I need to apply several changes to a DOM element but I need the browser to render the first change before applying the next.
For this I add a render function to jQuery like this:

`jQuery.fn.extend({
  render: function() {
    this[0].offsetHeight
    return this;
  }
});`

Then I can use it like this:
_$("#progressIndicator")
    .css({ transition: "width 0s", width: "0%" })
    .render()
    .css({ transition: "" });_

In this example, it disables the CSS transition animation while resetting the progressBar and when done, it re-enabled the transition for the next change.

Calling an element's offsetHeight forces the browser to render the changes and execute the rest of the code after rendering. Adding the render function allows for easy chaining.

I'm thinking it would be beneficial for others to add this render function by default. I notices that there are many questions asked and articles written to get around the issue of rendering changes which could all be solved easily this way.
Thanks

title: Can you explain what is this line that is causing some lag on my code.
body:
So after a long debugging on my app, related to rendering events on a calendar that apparently uses this deferred line, ( https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/821bf34353a6baf97f7944379a6459afb16badae/src/deferred.js#L230
 ) i ask what is the function of window.setTimeout(process) why is this in a timer with no seconds?

Is that some sort of hack to solve another issue? because on android chrome, i noticed that this would delay the execution on some of my code functions, in 1.5 seconds ( which for our application is high), this only happens in android chrome.

removing the timer, and calling the process() does solve the lag...

title: Use lockbot to avoid comments on stale issues and PRs
body:
### Description ###

See https://www.henryzoo.com/blog/2018/05/06/an-issue-with-issues.html and https://github.com/apps/lock . This prevents people tacking on comments because they're using an old jQuery without the fix, they happen to have a similar-looking error message,  they are looking for tech support, they randomly decide to add line comments on a PR, etc.

title: Memory leak issue in .html() with injected inline script elements.
body:
jQuery Version : 1.11.4(currently we are used) and 3.3.1

Forum Link:
https://forum.jquery.com/topic/memory-size-is-keep-on-increased-in-every-navigation-of-jquery-ajax-call.

The injected inline scripts by .html(), should be GCed.
The injected inline scripts by .html() are not GCed because the script elements has root as global.
Browsers tested: Edge, Chrome.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the URL in Edge browser [Fiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/5w8zc7tb/6/).
2. Run the demo fiddle. 
3. Open F12 Developer tools and select Memory Tab.
4. Start the Profiling session.
5. Take initial heap snapshot.
6.  Press Action One button and Take another heap snapshot.
7.  Press Action two button and take another heap snapshot.
8.  Repeat step 6 and 7.
9.  Compare the last snapshots.

As shown below screen shots.
1.
![memory leak 1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38877074/39465018-8f1017f6-4d3e-11e8-855b-b425306dc9ed.png)

2. 
![memory leak 2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38877074/39464947-1e118d8c-4d3e-11e8-951e-abafa5e42af1.png)

Demo Files:
[demo.zip](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/files/1963200/demo.zip)

- [ ] `jQuery.cssNumber`.

### Description ###
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3774176/38924448-8f309896-432f-11e8-875b-13d6ce26de33.png)

It may caused by 
`	map: function( callback ) {
		return this.pushStack( jQuery.map(this, function( elem, i ) {
			return callback.call( elem, i, elem );
		}));
	},`
the callback.call( elem, i, elem ) may be callback.call( elem, elem, i ) to make the map function act the same when called from different method.

title: jquery breaks when running $(window).text() while an iframe with different doamin exist on the page.
body:
When running $.text() on window, while there are cors iframes on the page throws an exception.

STR:
1. Open a page with that have at least one iframe from a different domain.
2. run $(window).text() . 

 *  What do you expect to happen?
> Return empty string/undefined
*  What actually happens?
> Throws exception (cors/security 18)
 *  Which browsers are affected? 
> (WebKit/gecko based at least)

minimal testcase -> https://jsfiddle.net/xpvt214o/127474/

* why is it happening? 
> 
a. it seems that Sizzel.getText function assumes that if the parameter sent have no .nodeType property, it must be an array, so it's start iterating the element indexes,
b. when adding iframes to the document there is a reference also on the window object
window[0...n] (n - the number of frames on the page)

so when sending the window object, it iterates also the inaccessible windows and try to access their .nodeType prop which throws an exception.

title: Store dist output from Travis CI
body:
I am sometimes less than certain that a fix actually resolves a reported issue, due to environmental issues like OS dependence or browser zoom (cf. #4029). We should be able to direct issue reporters to the files built by recent PR CI jobs for confirmation, as we have with [jquery-git.js](http://code.jquery.com/jquery-git.js) and [Jenkins](http://builds.jenkins.jquery.com/jquery/73d7e6259c63ac45f42c6593da8c2796c6ce9281/test/jquery.js) for commits in the master branch.

However, since the files contain arbitrary user code, we should make sure that they aren't available from a commonly-trusted domain like jquery.com. Options that come to mind:
* Register a new domain.
* Push to GitHub.
* Push to S3/file sharing service/etc.
* Persuade Travis CI to store them.

Reproduction:
---
Example here: https://jsfiddle.net/qcx2zxs1/

### tl;dr
1. create a form with `<input name='elements'/>`
2. try to serialize form by `.serialize()` (which uses `.serializeArray()`)

This happens because of this line:
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/src/serialize.js#L102

Configuration
---
Jquery edge. Actually, repro works on any jquery that i tested. Looks, that line is present in history since the very first commits.

title: Transfer jquery-datepicker npm package namespace
body:
### Description ###

Hello, I created [this npm package](https://www.npmjs.com/package/jquery-datepicker) back before there was a decoupled version of jquery-datepicker that could be consumed w/ bundlers and esmodules. 

I was happy to see that [jquery-ui-datepicker-with-i18n](https://www.npmjs.com/package/jquery-ui-datepicker-with-i18n) is now available + it has the i18n files which are easy to resolve. I was actually about to update mine with the i18n files but came across this first and it works wonderfully!

I'd like to transfer ownership of the `jquery-datepicker` package namespace on npm to y'all in favor of the the `jquery-ui-datepicker-with-i18n` package contents. Can we coordinate this? Also, I think a readme for the new package would be a valuable addition.

title: Make jQuery.fx.interval use private
body:
Migrate has to make some shaky assumptions about the implementation of core's animations in order to warn about `jQuery.fx.interval`. It would be simpler if we used a private value for the interval value (basically just hard-code the default `13`) so that *any* use of `jQuery.fx.interval` could be indentified as deprecated. There is a slight risk that someone might be changing that value but it seems unlikely since we are already ignoring it except for two rare-ish cases: 1) IE9 always, 2) browsers when the document is hidden.

In addition, per some discussion on https://github.com/jquery/jquery-migrate/pull/298 we may want to change from `document.hidden` to `document.visibilityState` since the standard has changed. From looking at caniuse.com it seems like IE10/IE11 support `rAF`  and `document.hidden` but not  `document.visibilityState` so I am not sure that is possible until we drop their support.

title: Deprecate auto-appending `px` in 3.4.0?
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest version of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What actually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

### Description ###
In 4.0 I plan to take a stab at #2795. I think, though, we should try to deprecate auto-adding `px` earlier than that. This may not require changes in jQuery itself but on the API pages & in Migrate but I'd like to discuss the approach before doing the work.

One question - do we want to deprecate auto-adding `px` altogether or just for the properties we will stop auto-adding for? (i.e. not some most common ones like `width`) Deprecating all of that would go towards the ideal goal but might trigger warnings on the vast majority of projects so perhaps it'd be less invasive to not do it on the ones we will auto-fix.

N/A

title: width/height css set hook causes forced reflows
body:
### Description ###
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/3fcddd6e72e7e318c0b062e391d60867732318ae#diff-414c8f59bff0d1b63680b64763d8c529R370 started invoking the `isBorderBox` test 100% of the time instead of only when necessary. In my case this causes a series of `.css({width})` calls to cause a "forced reflow" (that's the chrome terminology in the performance tool).

Updating the width/height `set` to avoid computing `isBorderBox` unless necessary fixes it for me locally, but makes the code a bit uglier:
```
6582c6582
< 				isBorderBox = jQuery.css( elem, "boxSizing", false, styles ) === "border-box",
---
> 				isBorderBox,
6587c6587
< 					isBorderBox,
---
> 					isBorderBox = jQuery.css( elem, "boxSizing", false, styles ) === "border-box",
6593c6593
< 			if ( isBorderBox && support.scrollboxSize() === styles.position ) {
---
> 			if ( support.scrollboxSize() === styles.position && (undefined === isBorderBox ? (isBorderBox = jQuery.css( elem, "boxSizing", false, styles ) === "border-box") : isBorderBox) ) {
```

However so far I have been unable to reproduce this in jsbin, so there must be another condition that I'm not understanding such as a specific position type on the element or parent element?

Here's an example where a series of `ng-style="{width: X}"` in AngularJS causes this (and jQuery 3.1 does not cause it):
![jq33-reflow](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/89246/36817988-0ee5a638-1cdb-11e8-8713-bb69f3290230.png)


### Link to test case ###
TODO

title: Don't fill jQuery.cssProps if mapping isn't needed
body: While working on https://github.com/jquery/jquery-migrate/pull/291 the tests failed indicating that we are using `jQuery.cssProps` still in a [somewhat insidious way](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/4a2bcc27f9c3ee24b3effac0fbe1285d1ee23cc5/src/css.js#L66). Each time someone accesses a CSS property we're populating it with properties like `{ width: "width" }`. That makes it hard for Migrate to warn since just about anything can end up there through no fault of external code. For now I won't land this warning and leave https://github.com/jquery/jquery-migrate/issues/283 open until we can change the logic to only populate `jQuery.cssProps` when it needs to actually change the property name.

title: Feature: Support colon character in event namespaces
body:
### Description ###

I have an issue for unbind an event created for a component having a colon character in its id. 
The colon character is used as separator by the JSF API.

The event is bind like this:
```
var elementId = document.getElementById('test:colon').id.replace(':', '\\:'),
selector = '#' + elementId + ' .clickMe';
$(document).on('click.xxx-' + elementId, selector, function (){alert('clicked');});
```
But the off function does not unbing the event:
`$(document).off('click.xxx-' + elementId, selector);`

The issue appear in the off function on the line:
`( !tmp || tmp.test( handleObj.namespace ) )`
The regex pattern failed to test the expression because of the escape character...
If you change the line:
`tmp = tmp[ 2 ] && new RegExp( "(^|\\.)" + namespaces.join( "\\.(?:.*\\.|)" ) + "(\\.|$)" );`
by escaping the \ character:
`tmp = tmp[ 2 ] && new RegExp( "(^|\\.)" + namespaces.join( "\\.(?:.*\\.|)" ).replace('\\', '\\\\') + "(\\.|$)" );`
seem to works in the chrome debugger:
![debug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7791600/36473324-84931100-16f4-11e8-92cf-de18a4564cb9.png)

  *  What do you expect to happen?
Event must be unbind
  *  What actually happens?
Event is not unbind
  *  Which browsers are affected?
All browsers

### Link to test case ###
https://jsbin.com/yamitatece/edit?html,js,output

Having something like a lifecycle to DOM elements would be great Mutation Observer could come in handy here maybe? ### Example ### In Javascript/TS I create a couple of elements like `$a = $("
Some Text
")` At some point they are are added to the DOM, now it would come in really handy if we could react to this so we can give our element some more properties that were impossible to assign before it was loaded into the DOM. title: jQuery on Node.js can't be used as a dependency
body:
What's the status of jquery in node.js environment?

One of the modules, my node.js project imports, is a jquery plugin and requires jquery as a dependency. When I try to initialize it, I get an error that `$.fn` is `undefined`, thus plugin can't attach to it.

Turns out, jquery can't properly initialize without a `window` object.

`console.log(require("jquery").toString());` returns: 

`function ( w ) { if ( !w.document ) { throw new Error( "jQuery requires a window with a document" ); } return factory( w ); }`

I can't just initialize `jquery` manually, passing `jsdom` as a `window` object substitute:

```js
const jsdom = require("jsdom");
const { window } = new jsdom.JSDOM(`...`);
var $ = require("jquery")(window);
```

because `require('jquery')` is executed in a plugin code, that I can't modify.

[StackOverflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1801160/can-i-use-jquery-with-node-js/40656811#40656811) has an overwhelmingly large number of recent answers, so, I suppose many people have recently encountered a similar problem.

What do I do?

Thank you, 
Boris.

JQuery 3.1.1 vs 2.2.4 change in behavior appending rows to a table
body:
The following code:

$('<TABLE />').append('<TR><TD>1</TD></TR>').appendTo('BODY');
results in slightly different DOM structures.

Under 2.2.4 you get <TABLE><TBODY><TR>...

Under 3.1.1 you get <TABLE><TR>...

This causes problems if you later have selectors like #id TBODY TR (to get all the body rows, and no header rows).

I've reviewed the jQuery Core 3.0 Upgrade Guide and can't see anything that might be related.

So my question is... is this expected behaviour or a bug in JQuery?

(from stackoverflow question: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48658605/jquery-3-1-1-vs-2-2-4-change-in-behavior-appending-rows-to-a-table and forum question https://forum.jquery.com/topic/jquery-3-1-1-vs-2-2-4-change-in-behavior-appending-rows-to-a-table#14737000007604149)

title: pattern.exec run against non sanitized string returned by the server
body:
This venerability exists within the jQuery library within the ajax component. The third parameter of the callback will be a jqXHR object with a method getResponseHeader. This method may be called with a key (such as 'Connection') to access response headers.  In parsing the headers, this method calls exec on responseHeadersString without sanitizing the string.  

https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/src/ajax.js#L461

If a client were to reach out to a third party service or a man in the middle attack were to be performed, malicious code contained in headers could be executed on the client machine.  

In practice this vulnerability is blocked by modern browsers (eg. Chrome, Firefox, and Safari). 
 A message is put on the console reading "The page at https://localhost/7000/home/quote was not allowed to display insecure content from XXXX."

title: Support only last 3 iOS versions and drop Android Browser in jQuery 4.0+
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest version of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What actually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

### Description ###
We currently support most browsers in their `current` & `current-1` versions. The exceptions are IE, iOS & Android. Wrt to IE it's obvious we can't switch to the "`current` & `current-1`" scheme as this browser is dead and we support it for legacy reasons. Android Browser 4.0-4.3 still has around 6.1% of Android Browser market share (91.8% of which are Android 4.1-4.3) so we can't drop Android Browser just yet.

iOS is different. It doesn't progress as quickly as desktop rolling-release browsers as Safari cannot be updated separately from the OS but people update the OS pretty quickly. Stats show hardly anyone uses an iOS version older than `current-2` at any given moment. [Apple stats](https://developer.apple.com/support/app-store/) provide some insight but they don't separate `current-2` from older versions.

Currently we explicitly support iOS 7+. This means as long as we don't release a new major jQuery version we have to test on more & more iOS versions (currently 4 of them). Could we limit ourselves to a specific number of iOS versions supported in line with most of the desktop browsers? I feel `current` & `current-1` might be too little but perhaps we can limit ourselves to last 3 stable versions?

This would have to happen in jQuery 4.0 & newer as we try to not limit https://jquery.com/browser-support/ in patch/minor releases.

### Link to test case ###
N/A

title: $.ajax will change URL
body:
Consider the following $.ajax request:

```
$.ajax({url: "/rate",
            method: "POST", success: function(results){console.log(results)}})
```

This will call the correct URL like: `http://<hostname>/rate`.

Now, consider this request:

```
$.ajax({url: "/rat/1",
            method: "POST",success: function(results){console.log(results)}})
```

Again, as expected, the URL `http://<hostname>/rat/1` is called.

Now, the strange behaviour:

```
$.ajax({url: "/rate/1",
            method: "POST",success: function(results){console.log(results)}})
```

will call `http://<hostname>/rate` instead of the expected `http://<hostname>/rate/1`

Not sure, whats happening there.

I tried these `url`-settings:

Working:

- `/myendpoint`
- `/myendpoint/1`
- `/rate`
- `/rate/`
- `/rate/e`
- `/rat.e/1`
 `/rate/e`

Not working (leading to a call to just `/rate`:

- `/rate/1`
- `/rate/2`

title: off() does not support object as selector
jQuery.fn.load Uncaught TypeError: url.indexOf is not a function
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest version of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What actually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

### Description ###

I am getting an error in v3.2.1 that I was not getting in v1.12.3 and I have traced it to the jQuery.fn.load function.

In v1.12.3, the jQuery.fn.load function begins as such.
`jQuery.fn.load = function( url, params, callback ) {
	if ( typeof url !== "string" && _load ) {
		return _load.apply( this, arguments );
	}
	var selector, type, response,
		self = this,
		off = url.indexOf( " " );
`

In v3.2.1, the jQuery.fn.load function begins as such.
`jQuery.fn.load = function( url, params, callback ) {
	var selector, type, response,
		self = this,
		off = url.indexOf( " " );
`

The lines 
`
if ( typeof url !== "string" && _load ) {
		return _load.apply( this, arguments );
	}
`
have been removed out of the new version.

The error occurs when I try to run this snippet of code.
`  var ifr = $('<iframe/>', {
    src: url,
    load: function() {
      alert('here');
    },
    frameborder: '0'
  });`

The definition of load within the iframe creation is what is causing the TypeError.



### Link to test case ###

title: jQuery doesn't optimize identifier with backslash
body:
jQuery doesn't optimize selector "#\\:x" to document.getElementById(":x").

The problem is with this regex which doesn't recognize backslashes escape character:

```js
// Easily-parseable/retrievable ID or TAG or CLASS selectors
rquickExpr = /^(?:#([\w-]+)|(\w+)|\.([\w-]+))$/,
```

title: jQuery 3+ breaks droppable/draggable with subpixel width/height
body:
### Description ###
Issue:
When using jQuery 3+ with draggable elements which have a width or height that has subpixels (e.g. by using em or rem units) the draggables fly back to their source position even when configured to snap and stay on the target.

Expected behaviour: snap and remain on target.

Browsers affected: All recent (Chrome 62, Firefox 52, IE Edge/11)

### Link to test case ###
Minimal test case: https://jsfiddle.net/bv3ddrjx/7/

To reproduce:
1) Drag the white boxes onto the drop targets => they'll bounce back (the bug)
2) In the CSS, remove the subpixels in line 35 and 36 => it works as expected
3) Leave the subpixels, but swap the jQuery library (first HTML lines) to 2.2.4 => it works with subpixels

Use different values of subpixels to get different failures (no draggable works, just one works etc.)

title: Deferred#fail throwing Uncaught (in promise) on Chrome
body:
I'm having a very odd behaviour with jQuery#ajax interactions between Deferred#fail and Deffered#catch, on Chrome (but not Firefox).

When I am writing a callback like so:

```js
$.ajax({ ... }).done(doneFunction).fail(failureFunction)
```

If the AJAX call fails with a 400, the `failureFunction` is called (expected), but another error is thrown in the Browser: `Uncaught (in promise)`, shown here in the inspector tools:

![chrome jquery bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3889656/34595515-7e8e4f3a-f23d-11e7-9f57-fa5fdbc6b8d9.png)

But if I change the behaviour to:

```js
$.ajax({ ... }).done(doneFunction).catch(failureFunction)
```

Then the `failureFunction` operates as expected, and there are no uncaught promise errors. I can also do this, and `failureFunction` executes twice:

```js
$.ajax({ ... }).done(doneFunction).fail(failureFunction).catch(failureFunction)
```

From what I understand (and from the docs), it appears that Deferred#fail and Deferred#catch should both be doing the same thing (they are both documented as "Add handlers to be called when the Deferred object is rejected."). Is there a subtlety between the two methods that I'm missing?

Even the docs themselves suggest using #fail is the correct behaviour with #done: http://api.jquery.com/deferred.fail/

In the meantime, replacing #fail with #catch seems to be solving this issue.

title: jQuery.parseJSON error on empty string
What's the future of jQuery in 2018?
body:
Hi - so I just wanted to take an opportunity to enquire about the future of this library and what the plans are going forward in terms of updates and support. 

Over the last few years it's fair to say the landscape has changed, frameworks including Angular, React and VueJS have introduced a new paradigm for writing JavaScript and in some ways made jQuery redundant - to the effect that it's encouraged not to load/use the library at all. 

This is also inline with an observable decrease in the number of releases being pushed, with just 3.2 and 3.2.1 this March. Before that, 3.1 shipped in July 2016. And whereas there were 8 blog posts in 2015 and 16, there has just been the one this year, and ever since, silence.

During this time, we've seen a number of major changes in the JavaScript ecosystem, including (and not an exhaustive list): promises, arrow functions, spread operator, async/await, generators, fetch api (replaces ajax), template literals, let/const and classes.

All of these changes can add up to one of the biggest rewrites of the library we've seen to date. I question whether Ajax is still required now that Fetch is supported on all major browsers. 

---

With all that said, my main question is what is the plan going into 2018 and beyond in regards to jQuery; it's no lie with each passing year an already aging codebase, some of which hasn't been touched in years, continues to be common across the web. It'd be delightful to see a v4 project attempted to try and remove any parts which are no longer required and focusing on keeping only the absolute essentials, focusing on extreme performance and a modern codebase now that all these new language features have been added to the browser.

Thank you and I look forward to any comments this issue may generate.

Happy coding :)

title: selector is jquery object, why not fn.init return itself
delegated Mouse Event targeted on SVG `<use>` element are not caught
body:
### Description ### When using the delegated version of `$parent.on(events, selector, handler)` with `events` being a MouseEvent, the event is not recognized in IE11 and Edge (and possibly in other IE flavors either), if the `.target` of the event is an SVG `` element pointing to an externally defined symbol.

$(document).on('click', 'p', handler); // This will not work The event is recognized if the reference SVG symbol (pointed by the ``'s `xlink:href` attribute) is itself declared inside the delegation target pointed by `selector`, e.g in above example if the first `

`, it would work. It will also work if the event is not delegated, e.g with the first HTML structure, `$('p').on('click', handler)` will work. I believe this is because IE does set the target of such event to a weird `SVGElementInstance`, probably representing the shadow-element `` element uses. I don't know IE that much and it's the first time I encounter this weird object, which I don't think is part of any standards, but I thought you might want to handle this case. ### [Link to test case](https://jsfiddle.net/8yb36w27/) ###

title: Events bound inline / at runtime being automatically deleted on document load
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest version of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What actually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

### Description ###
Here is a full description of my debugging process: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47506724/jquery-events-bound-inline-at-runtime-being-automatically-deleted-on-document

TLDR:
* Binding to an input's `keyup` and `change` events at runtime / inline HTML
* Events are bound successfully at runtime according to `$._data`
* Event parent is being removed and re-added elsewhere in the DOM
* Using `element.addEventListener` works as a replacement to jQuery
* Alternatively, setting `jQuery.cleanData = function(){};` prevents the bound events from being deleted

### Link to test case ###

        console.log("outside")
    });
JQuery 3.2.1 output
      1.inside
      2.outside.

JQuery 3.1.1 output
      1.outside
      2.inside. 

Sample Link(jquery 3.2.1): https://www.w3schools.com/code/tryit.asp?filename=FLMCAWA173W6

Sample Link(jquery 3.1.1): https://www.w3schools.com/code/tryit.asp?filename=FLMETVQCUR42

Expected result: 
1.outside.
2.Inside

Please let me know if you have any concern,

Thanks for your help in advance.

Regards,
Keerthana.

title: ready callback might be called after load event fired
[Suggestion] rename isArraylike function or add a comment in it
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest version of jQuery.

  *  What actually happens?

  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

### Description ###
Hi, when I read [core.js](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/src/core.js) yesterday, I was confused because `map` used `isArrayLike`, but it was not a real `isArrayLike` function, this was only used for checking `if it is object or dense array`, but not `if it is an array like`. I also find duplicate issues reported bugs like 
```
Uncaught TypeError: Cannot use 'in' operator to search for '' in ‘’
```
And yeah I find out the owner replied, saying it was clear in the document that the type passed in should be array or object. So that was users fault that did not read the document, but it is still unreasonable for you to use the name of `isArrayLike`. 

Would you add a comment to the function or rename this function?

title: Importing jquery to electron applications
body:
I tried to import jquery in my electron application like usual
<script src="foreign_modules/jquery.js"></script>

But nothing happened, therefore I searched online and found a solution in stackoverflow

Add the below script at the beginning, before importing jquery. 

<script>if (typeof module === 'object') {window.module = module; module = undefined;}</script><script src="foreign_modules/jquery.js"></script>

title: [jQuery 3.2.1, Internet Explorer, Edge] $.isPlainObject fails when passed object has been created in child browser window
body:
I have a simple HTML page (lets say PAGE1) that opens new browser window using window.open() function and loads another HTML page (lets say PAGE2):
`newWindow = window.open(page2url, "Page2", "top=50, left=50, width=400, height=200, resizable=1");`

PAGE2 creates a simple object in its own window: `object2 = { property2: 'value2'};`
**Note** this object is created in child browser window.

Then when I try execute `$.isPlainObject(newWindow.object2);` in main browser window then the following error is thrown:
**_TypeError: Function.prototype.toString: 'this' is not a Function object_**

![isplainobjecterror](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10869858/32592735-2ecd948a-c536-11e7-8816-763ed10516e3.PNG)

This was working fine with jQuery 2.1.4 but stopped working in jQuery 3.2.1.

I was using the following versions of IE and Edge:
 - IE: 11.0.9600.18816 (update versions 11.0.47 (KB4040685))
 - Edge: 40.15063.674.0 (Microsoft EdgeHTML 15.15063)
 
Tested on Windows 7 and Windows 10.
FireFox and Google Chrome do not have this issue.

I have created a ZIP with simple demo that reproduces the issue. Attached ZIP contains Readme.txt with detailed instructions of how to reproduce the error.
[jQueryTest.zip](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/files/1456737/jQueryTest.zip)

**Slightly updated the sample demo:**
[jQueryTest_updated.zip](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/files/1456861/jQueryTest_updated.zip)

title: AJAX Post network errors not returned
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest version of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What actually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

### Description ###
Using ajax to post does not propagate network errors to callback.
This can be replicated by using the following code:
```
$.ajax('<some bad url that won't resolve>', {
    method: 'POST',
    error: (jqXHR, status, err) => alert('Error: ' + err.toString())
});
```
This results in a blank error (empty string).  I see the same behavior when there is no internet connection, post fails but I get no error back (empty string).  These errors appear in the console but I can't do anything with the error myself.

I'm using chrome.

### Description ###
When getting the 'order' (css style) of an element (using jquery's .css() method), the returned number is exponentialized (sp?) for larger numbers, leading to errors when that order needs to be used for computation (e.g. to move items around programmatically). 

This seems to occur only for larger numbers, possibly negative numbers. All is well for smaller numbers (e.g. less than 100,000 - but I'm not sure what the actual range is that triggers the problem).

title: Microsoft Edge returns error code 0 for request and doesn't offer a responseJSON
body:
When calling my web service in the following manner, Chrome, FF and IE correctly reply with an error object which includes a proper responseJSON attribute. Microsoft Edge, however, reports a status "0" with the statusText "error". The object doesn't contain any additional information.

The web server always responds with an error 400 to this request:

`$.post(Händlerportal.apiAddress + 'getToken', {
    username: 'abc',
    password: '123',
    grant_type: 'password'
}).fail(e => console.log(e))`

The raw response to this request is according to Google Chrome:

`{"error":"invalid_grant","error_description":"Benutzername und Kennwort stimmen nicht überein."}`

The expected result for parameter e should be:

`"{"readyState":4,"responseText":"{\"error\":\"invalid_grant\",\"error_description\":\"Benutzername und Kennwort stimmen nicht überein.\"}","responseJSON":{"error":"invalid_grant","error_description":"Benutzername und Kennwort stimmen nicht überein."},"status":400,"statusText":"Bad Request"}"`

Microsoft Edge, exclusively under all tested browsers, generates:

`{"readyState":0,"status":0,"statusText":"error"}`

title: Use the new fetch API
body:
### Feature Request / Improvement ###
Hi,
What do you think about using the new `fetch()` API, which is already implemented in all major browsers. It should be used by default when the `window.fetch()` function is available and can be explicitly deactivated by using a parameter. All major browsers have been supporting this feature for some time. 
I'm not so familiar with the jQuery codebase (only used it) so maybe this cannot be implemented due some missing features e.g.

For the full Browser Compatibility and usage check out the documentation here:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Fetch_API

title: offset() can be inaccurate when pinch-zoomed
body:
Bug Reports:
  *  What do you expect to happen?
    offset() should return offset from document origin
  *  What actually happens?
    On some browsers, it can be off when pinch-zoomed
  *  Which browsers are affected?
    Edge, possibly Safari in the future.

### Description ###

Open the console and click/tap on the input box. Now pinch-zoom into the page, scroll to the very top, then scroll back down to the input box and tap it. The output should always be the same.

See https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=170981 for some background and https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2017/09/visual-viewport-api for the details.

The issue is that offset() is adding getBoundingClientRect (which is relative to the layout viewport) to window.pageX|YOffset which is relative to the visual viewport.

Note: Chrome recently made pageYOffset relative to the layout viewport so this isn't an issue there.

### Link to test case ###

 http://jsbin.com/vucayumeta

title: FeatReq: Add new API for ::before and ::after tags
body:
In the past I already asked in forums on how to peek into a ::before CSS rules e.g. for example in ```
::before ....
``` with a CSS declaration like `span::before { content: "foobar"; }` I learned that this is not possible resp. only with difficulties. Since there are more and more CSS stylesheets out there with ::before and ::after tags it becomes more and more important to access them by jQuery. So jQuery should provide a new API for them in the next release. As a first step it would be sufficient not to modify but only to check for the presence of them E.g. (see sample above) find simply all elements which have such a ::before clause. Afterwards I want to remove these elements. The coming jQuery API should make the following possible/valid: $("div span::before").remove();

body:
### Description ###

In the test case provided below, you can see that upon arriving on the page, the items in the green column are regularly sliding up. To be precise, the topmost item is being slideUp, making all items underneath slide up as well. The topmost item is then moved down the green column where it re-appears. In this case, everything looks good.

But as soon as you start scrolling down the "page", to see more items of the yellow column or to read the text in the red column, you see that now every time a green item slides up, the whole page slides up as well. So in effect, you see that the yellow and red column look like they are going back up until they reach the top of page, at which point the green column resumes the intended motion.

title: $.ajax interprets webserver error-document as valid javascript
body:
When $.ajax is called with dataType 'script', then the received document is always interpreted as javascript, even when it actually is a 404-error document.
Expected behavior: evaluate the received document only when the webserver returns 200-OK.

Small example:
```
<html>
<head>
<script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.2.1/jquery.min.js"></script>
<script>
    $.ajax({
        url: 'doesnotexist.js',
        dataType: 'script'
    });
</script>
</head>
<body></body>
</html>
```
In Firefox this shows a message in the console 

> SyntaxError: expected expression, got '<'

as it tries to execute the HTML document received from the webserver.
Expected behavior is that the $.ajax call above is functionally equivalent to
> <script src="doesnotexist.js"></script>
meaning that non-existing resources on the webserver should give an error message in the console log, but not syntax errors.

title: IE/Edge - Submitting a form using jQuery's .submit() causes the submit handler on other forms to detach when using beforeunload
body:
### Description ###
In the below examples I have two forms. The first form, Foo, is submitted through js by a button outside the form. The second form, Bar, is submitted by a submit button within the form. Bar also has an event handler on the submit event, this handler will disable the beforeunload confirmation dialog so that Bar can be submitted without asking the user to confirm. When you submit Foo, the confirmation dialog displays and you can choose to stay on the page. The page should remain unaffected as if the button was never pressed. This works fine in pure js, but when using jQuery in IE or Edge choosing to stay on the current page causes the onsubmit handler of Bar to become detached somehow, so it doesn't run when Bar gets submitted. In this case that just means that the user gets another annoying dialog, but it can cause more severe problems if there is some processing that needs to happen in that handler before the form is submitted.

I've worked around this in my own code by just calling submit on the raw form element. It can also be solved by attaching the event handler using pure js, or using pure js entirely.

### Tested on: ###
IE 11.540.15063.0 (fail)
Edge 40.15063.0.0 (fail)
Firefox 55.0.3 (pass)
Chrome 61.0.3163.100 (pass)

All tests were run on Win10

### Link to test cases ###
[jQuery](https://jsfiddle.net/Antimony51/du8bzr6x/)
[Native](https://jsfiddle.net/Antimony51/nwvp8cog/)

To reproduce the issue:
1. Submit Foo
2. Click "Stay on current page"
3. Submit Bar

Pass when:
The form just submits

Fail when:
The confirmation dialog shows

title: css() reports wrong width/height in Chrome on certain zoom levels
body:
jQuery 3.2.1 reports wrong sizes for elements with `box-sizing: border-box` in Chrome (v61) on certain browser zoom levels. It seems to add the element's insets (padding + border) to its width and height, although the CSS width already includes the insets.

### Demonstration ###
http://output.jsbin.com/yipudeloya/

In the provided test case, we have two \<div>s with 10px padding on all sides, 1px border on all sides and a CSS width/height set to 32px. Because box-sizing is set to `border-box`, the visual size of the elements is 32x32px with a remaining "inner" space of 10px. At 100% browser zoom level, this is correctly reported both by `css('width')` and `.outerWidth()`.

If we now zoom to 110%, the numbers get slightly changed, probably due to some rounding errors (31.9886px instead of 32px). Because we should always get "CSS pixels" that are not affected by browser zoom, I would have expected those numbers to stay the same - but I can live with that. The real problem occurs when you reload the page while having the browser zoom at 110%! Now the width is completely incorrect (53.977236000000005px instead of 32px).

If the page uses those values for programmatic layout, the results will be wrong. You can see the effect in the demo. The CSS width and height of the first \<div> are copied to the second, so they should always be the same size. However, if you start at 100%, the second \<div> is much larger.

### Analysis ###
Analysis has shown that this seems to be caused by the internal function `computeStyleTests()` in *css/support.js* that wrongly sets the internal property `boxSizingReliableVal` to `false`. Apparently, this happens because of a rounding error. In my case, the test div's measured width is 3.997px, which is not equal to the expected value of 4px. What's worse, this internal property is only calculated once! So when you start at 110% zoom, and then reset it to 100%, the problem still persists until you completely reload the page.

I could observe the problem at the following zoom levels: 110%, 90%, 80%, 67% and 33%.

Firefox (v56) and IE (v11) don't seem to be affected by this problem. Also, with jQuery 2.1.4, everything works fine on all browsers. All tests were performed on Windows 7 with default DPI and font size settings.

title: Remove package-lock.json?
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest version of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What actually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

### Description ###
npm 5, even the version included in the latest Node.js 8.5.0 re-generates `package-lock.json` on each install. And when it does on a system that doesn't support all the optional dependencies that are supported on the OS where the lockfile was generated, it removes those optional deps from the lockfile.

The effect is that everyone firing `npm install` on our repo on any OS other than macOS will immediately get a dirty state of the repo as the `fsevents` dependency subtree gets removed from `package-lock.json`. That's a really bad experience.

title: XSS possible in test/data/jsonp.php
body:
### Description ###
The file `test/data/jsonp.php` outputs the `callback` parameter unescaped, this coupled with a lack of `Content-Type` header allows Cross Site Scripting.

Although the script is only *meant* for testing purposes, a Google search reveals that the file has been deployed to several sites across the web; presumably where the entire jquery repository has been cloned.

I believe that adding a `Content-Type: application/javascript` header, while not a perfect solution, will help prevent more sites from inadvertently acquiring this vulnerability.

title: Standardize keyboard event "key" property
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest version of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What actually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

### Description ###
According to MDN, [`KeyboardEvent.which` and `KeyboardEvent.keyCode` are both deprecated](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/KeyboardEvent). The recommendation is to use `KeyboardEvent.key` instead. However, `KeyboardEvent.key` has some inconsistencies across browsers. One such example is for the arrow keys: for example the up arrow key shows up as `"ArrowUp"` in modern browsers, but as `Up` in IE9+.

Here is the spec for `KeyboardEvent.key`: https://www.w3.org/TR/uievents-key/

### Link to test case ###
https://jsfiddle.net/c26juan5/1/

Focus in the text box and press any arrow key on your keyboard to observe the value. Result in modern Chrome / Firefox differs from IE9+.

title: Tests: pathname parsing breaks tests when hosted on URLs that include the string "test"
body:
As per https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/test/jquery.js#L5 which is used in _test/index.html_, it tries to load _/test/unit/ready.js_ and _/dist/jquery.min.js_ dynamically, but since it is just splitting on the string _"test"_ in the pathname and grabbing the first instance, hosting on any url where _"test"_ is located earlier (e.g. _mydomain.com/testcontent/jquery/test/index.html_) incorrectly calculates the path to _mydomain.com/test/unit/ready.js_ instead of _mydomain.com/testcontent/jquery/test/unit/ready.js_ for those resource files and breaks the test. 

Would you be open to me submitting a PR for a fix? Just wanting to change the line in question:
`var path = window.location.pathname.split( "test" )[ 0 ],` 
to 
`var path = window.location.pathname.substring(0, window.location.pathname.lastIndexOf("test")),`

title: Reserve window.jquery together with window.jQuery & window.$
jQuery.ready() calls method named "catch" without quotation
body:
I think `.catch` call should be replaced with `['catch']`.
Now it fails script file parsing in old browsers like IE8 or Safari 5. Even if jquery doesn't support such browsers, it could break application's fallback functionality, delivered in the same file.

title: Add unit test for $.getScript signature that accepts the options object
body:
### Description ###
Unit test needed for the $.getScript options signature.
See PR https://github.com/jquery/api.jquery.com/pull/1054/

jQuery 1.12.0 added a signature for passing an options object to $.getScript.
This signature cannot be documented before a unit 
This signature is a blessing, allows an easy way to cancel the anti-cache like this:
```
 $.getScript({
        url: "foo.js",
        cache: true
    })
```

https://jsfiddle.net/oriadam/h0b26L1a/

title: Accessing Input element Value field via 'val()' is unintuitive!
body:
### Description ###
The long established convention of accessing the Input fields 'value' is done using the named attribute called 'value'. Jquery should NOT be trying to re-invent the wheel. Having a function call of 'val()' is unintuitive and requires the first time user of this function to look up in the Manual to see what happened to the 'value' attribute in jQuery..... not great. Additionally, Stackoverflow seems to be trying to solve problems that should not exist in the first place.

So please, make 'value' attribute accessible again.

Thank you.

### Link to test case ###

not applicable

title: PhantomJS 1.x failure
body:
I've been investigating why there are multiple failures in the jQuery Migrate unit tests, only on PhantomJS. Even a simple test like `jQuery( document.body ).append( document.createElement("p") );` throws an error. 

I  bisected it down to a16339b8933f115da3661f3d3f64854c3fa60bdc and [this line](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/a16339b8933f115da3661f3d3f64854c3fa60bdc/src/core.js#L220) in core.js:

`return typeof obj === "function" && typeof obj.nodeType !== "number";`

Unfortunately, `getAll` returns a NodeList that looks like a function but doesn't have a `nodeType` property so that fails the `isArrayLike` test when it shouldn't.

Do we want/have to support PhantomJS 1.x in jQuery 3.x? If so I think we'd need to fix this.

title: Feature request:  delay on .blur()

In my h5 project, i use a module 'lib' to process the dom, ajax...， zepto and jquery is always same, so i want change the 'lib' module dynamic , if i use jquery features, 'lib' will be jquery, else keep small and use zepto. 

Here is my code.
```javascript
// require config
require.config(
{
        paths: {
            'lib': 'zepto' // or jquery
        },
    };
)

// use
require(['lib'], function($) {
    console.log($); // undefined
})
```

I search the jquery src and found code in [src/exports/amd.js](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/2d4f53416e5f74fa98e0c1d66b6f3c285a12f0ce/src/exports/amd.js)

```javascript
define( "jquery", [], function() {
     return jQuery;
 });
```
**I moved module name 'jquery', and it works, so what about remove the module name for flexible use?**

title: CSS: Switch to .setProperty and detect !important in strings
body:
### What do you expect to happen?
When calling `.css('key', 'val !important')`, the correct css is added to the element.

  ### What actually happens?
jQuery silently ignores the css value. This can be tested by performing the following:

    $('body').css('background', 'hotpink !important');

#### Using jQuery 3.2.1, but I can see this issue has [been around for a while](https://bugs.jquery.com/ticket/11173).

Whether or not this should be added to jQuery is another matter for debate, but I think regardless, the parser should return an error, or at least information, if it has failed to parse CSS that has been passed to it. I've just wasted half an hour on a project trying to figure out why my CSS wasn't being added to a dynamically created element, and didn't stop to think that jQuery might just be ignoring the `!important` part.

title: IE9 and the incredible shrinking scrollboxes
body:
80f1c8239e9d5f793f3e54e0cb8d7bd0747e4856 worked everywhere except IE9: http://swarm.jquery.org/result/2255930

Investigation traced the root cause to a mishandling by that browser of `box-sizing: content-box`, particularly in combination with `overflow: scroll`... specifically, `getComputedStyle` seems to always report content box dimensions, even for border-box elements, and the lack of accounting for scrollbars means that round-trip set operations shrink such elements: https://jsbin.com/zotomuqoho/edit?html,css,js,output
