title: $([]).toggle() fails when an array of elements is passed
body:
I am seeing this with Chrome on Linux for every version of jQuery at least through 3.1.0.

I've received three different errors from this same pattern, all of which trace to the same cause:

Uncaught TypeError: Failed to execute 'getComputedStyle' on 'Window': parameter 1 is not of type 'Element'.

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'display' of undefined

Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'defaultView' of undefined

Directly using show() and hide() works fine.  But when you try to do $([]).toggle(), you run into these errors.  

https://jsfiddle.net/odrmhh4y/1/

title: ajax: REST responses problem with json and empty responses (like 201)
body:
So, the problem is, when `contentType` set to `json` and there is `201 empty` response (without content-type) I getting response in the errorHandler due to fail JSON parsing. But I know and understand, that this is, actually, success response. And it is correct. 
So I need something like `contentType: 'json any'` (tried to achieve so with `accepts: {any: '*/*'}` key with no luck) so if json parse fails it will return empty success response. 
Any thoughts? Maybe it is possible to workaround (without checking `xhr.status` to be correct (200<=x<400) in error handler (wtf?)) and, still, get correct-typed response (in my case, if `contentType` is not specified I getting xml by default, but 201 is success then. Not the solution).

title: Selecting elements with a list of IDs is orders of magnitude slower than selecting them individually
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest (1.x, 2.x, 3.x) versions of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What acually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->
### Description

There isn't a significant benefit to using `$(document.getElementById('firstID'))` over `$('#firstID')`, but using `$('#firstID,#secondID')` is several thousand times slower than `$([document.getElementById('firstID'), document.getElementById('firstID')]);`
This affects all the browsers I've tested: Chrome, Firefox, IE11, Edge
### Link to test case

https://www.measurethat.net/Benchmarks/Show/129/3/element-by-id-fetching-javascript-vs-selectors
See the final test case '2 divs with single jquery selector'.

title: Can't set Breakpoint for $.fn.load() script directly in Web Debugger
body:
`debugger;` statement may be kind of solution, but it fails in `require.js` and old IE, let alone how boring to write it anywhere I want to stop... ([Related Issue](//git.oschina.net/Tech_Query/EasyWebApp/issues/11))

So, we need a `<script src="" />` for **AJAX HTML Loading**, no matter that source of the script is same or cross domain, `$.fn.load()` will have the same behavior.

---

In the end, I agree with the opinion of @rwaldron :
- https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/1051/files#r3664819
- https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/1051/files#r3665451

If there are problems related with "Synchronous Script" in **jQuery UI**, I think we need _Event Callback_ or _Promise Object_ to resolve them.

title: Why dataFilter() of $.ajax() can't be applied to non-XHR request ?
body:
In many cases, especially **SPA development**, We need to preprocess **Data Structure of Response JSON**, such as:

``` JavaScript
{
    code:       0,     //  > 0 while error occurs
    message:    'Success',
    data:       { }    //  Useful Data for Business Code
 }
```

Moreover, many **Open HTTP API** have only **JSONP** to support Cross Domain...

---

There's [a solution](http://stackoverflow.com/a/9478670) on the Internet, but I don't agree with it.

Because, I want to **Filter the Data**, not _Convert the Data from one Data-Type to another_, it'll be the same type forever~

---

So, I'm so **Confused** about [this four-year old ticket](https://bugs.jquery.com/ticket/11967#comment:7)...

title: JQuery autocomplete performance problem
body:
I used the code from site http://jqueryui.com/autocomplete/#combobox and noticed a significant performance issue on my page.  My list has ~3000 options in the combobox.  I noticed that most of the time it was stuck in the in the jquery js file within this set of code:

`indexOf = function( list, elem ) {
        var i = 0,
            len = list.length;
        for ( ; i < len; i++ ) {
            if ( list[i] === elem ) {
                return i;
            }
        }
        return -1;
    },`

Even though my list object was only expected to be ~3000 rows, it was actually significantly higher.  Here is my stacktrace:

`indexOf (jquery-1.12.4.js:644)
hasDuplicate (jquery-1.12.4.js:1375)
Sizzle.uniqueSort (jquery-1.12.4.js:1518)
processClassString (jquery-ui.js:510)
_classes (jquery-ui.js:523)
_toggleClass (jquery-ui.js:549)
_addClass (jquery-ui.js:537)
refresh (jquery-ui.js:5249)
(anonymous function) (jquery-ui.js:144)
_suggest (jquery-ui.js:6100)
(anonymous function) (jquery-ui.js:144)
__response (jquery-ui.js:6043)
(anonymous function) (jquery-ui.js:144)
_superApply (jquery-ui.js:133)
__response (jquery-ui.js:6229)
(anonymous function) (jquery-ui.js:144)
(anonymous function) (jquery-ui.js:6027)
proxy (jquery-1.12.4.js:529)
_source (combobox.html:108)
(anonymous function) (jquery-ui.js:144)
proxy (jquery-1.12.4.js:529)
_search (jquery-ui.js:6019)
(anonymous function) (jquery-ui.js:144)
search (jquery-ui.js:6011)
(anonymous function) (jquery-ui.js:144)
(anonymous function) (jquery-ui.js:5992)
handlerProxy (jquery-ui.js:621)
`

In processClassString it does line:

`current = $( $.unique( current.get().concat( options.element.get() ) ) );`

The current list is my 3000 or so rows initially, and then it adds the elements back into that list making it roughly 6000 rows.  Depending on how the user is interacting with the page (clicking the dropdown icon multiple times, typing into the textbox for the filter and then deleting the text, etc), it will keep adding to itself.  At one point I had almost 200,000 rows in my 'list' variable.

I was able to reproduce this by stepping through the code using Chrome developer tools on http://jqueryui.com/autocomplete/#combobox .

title: For null/undefined item in $.each() callback this=window
body:
...when using version of callback function without arguments. It looks to me like a bug.

Documentation says: "The value can also be accessed through the this keyword, but Javascript will always wrap the this value as an Object even if it is a simple string or number value."

https://jsfiddle.net/8zy75pxr/

Tested with Firefox and Chromium.

title: Cannot read property 'toUpperCase' of undefined
body:
jQuery v. 2.2.2
-  What do you expect to happen? Nothing
-  What acually happens? Error thrown: angular.js:13424 TypeError: Cannot read property 'toUpperCase' of undefined at vendorPropName (jquery.js:5890)
-  Which browsers are affected? All
### Description

When launching my AngularJS (v.1.5.x) app, the error is thrown.

To solve the issue is appears to be enough to add a simple condition at line 5890, like so:

```
// Check for vendor prefixed names
if(name[ 0 ]) var capName = name[ 0 ].toUpperCase() + name.slice( 1 ), i = cssPrefixes.length;
```

title: $.ajax() cache parameter substitution works incorrectly
body:
jQuery 3.1.0:

```
$.ajax("http://testurl?_=<randomnumber1>&p=2", { cache: false })
```

actually requests:

```
http://testurl&p=2?_=<randomnumber2>
```

but should request:

```
http://testurl?p=2&_=<randomnumber2>
```

I'll add a test case later if needed.

title: Possible to use css function to validate css rules?
body:
Is it possible to use .css to validate some basic inline rules to see if they are valid? ``` var tree = $("
"); tree.find('span') .css("background-color","#eee"); console.log(tree); // span changed tree.find('span') .css("background-color","blaahhhhcolor"); console.log(tree); //no change to span tree.find('span') .css("background-colaar","black"); console.log(tree); //no change to span ``` Compare both before and after and see if there has been an inline style attached, if there is it is valid? If not would it be possible to add some type of callback to CSS to suggest the given rules are valid? I know jQuery isn't a linter but in my case and possibly others this may suffice.

title: JQuery not rendering a page returned by the server after an AJAX post
[v1] Safari bug - $option.attr('selected', 'selected')
body:
Code is far from ideal, I've found it in our legacy code and this bug was really hard to track as we get reported this issue from our customer and couldn't reproduce it for a while.

Test case:
https://jsfiddle.net/6y091fqq/3/

It's working in Chrome, but aint in Safari (Version 9.0.2 (11601.3.9) on OS X). I've fixed it by just using `$('select').val(value)`. But thought it might be addressed at the core.

title: V3.1.0 ajax call with cache=false and prior '_' qparam in url is generating malformed url
body:
### Description

Due to some code changes apparently introduced in ajax.js between 3.0.0-alpha1 and 3.0.0-beta1, calls to ajax with a url containing an anti-cache query param can get broken apart and reassembled into a malformed url.

`$.ajax({ url: '/myapp/?_=1472073761152&nextPage=2', cache: false})`

changes the url around before sending.  Older versions replaced the anti-cache param in place.  The newer versions remove the prior param and then tacks on a new param at the end.  The actual url requested in this case comes out as

`'/myapp/&nextPage=2?_=1472073761268'`
### Link to test case

[See jsfiddle example](https://jsfiddle.net/L14kr5sy/2/)

title: $.when.done in 3.x breaks backward compatibility with 2.x
body:
### Description

How to maintain full compatibility for existing code with 3.x release. In attached example is shown case where $.when behaves absolutely different with 2.x release.

We have to support both versions of jQuery 2.x and 3.x, but now we see only one way - write own version of $.when that behaves same in both versions.
### Link to test case

2.x - https://jsfiddle.net/mpcteamkvet/qh6Lfhzn/
3.x - https://jsfiddle.net/mpcteamkvet/jmykr166/

title: Use native mouseenter/mouseleave Events
body:
Right now jQuery simulates the nice event [mouseleave](https://api.jquery.com/mouseenter/) by itself. 

This event is native since [2013 in chrome](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=236215), [2012 in Firefox](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=432698), bugfree in Safari since Version 8, since forever (Version    5.5) in IE.

I think its time to reduce the code overhead by relying on the browsers.

$(document).not(collection) constant empty results

title: Cannot read property 'toLowerCase' of undefined
body:

Frequently Reported Issues:

### Description

When trying to get value by a number, it throws an error:

``` javascript
$(1).val() // Throws error: Cannot read property 'toLowerCase' of undefined
```

Normally this should either return the number or nothing.
The error is thrown is because it assumes that the entry in the jQuery obejct array is a DOM element and tries to read `nodeName` of what is in this case a Number.

**File:** jquery/src/attributes/val.js
**Line:** 20

title: Deprecate jQuery.holdReady
body: Suggested in https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/1778#issuecomment-72764833 and decided in https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/2850#issuecomment-173315469 . Gap noticed in #3287.

title: calling jQuery.holdReady(false) without jQuery.holdReady() will trigger jQuery.ready() without DOMContentLoaded
body:
### Description

I have an app that assuming `jQuery.holdReady()` is called. So I can call `jQuery.holdReady(false)` whenever I'm ready. The problem is `DOMContentLoaded` is probably not triggered yet. Do you guys consider this as a bug? Also `readyWait: 1,` as a initially value is probably not intuitive. If we treat this as a bug I think the code would look better without this magic number :)

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest (1.x, 2.x, 3.x) versions of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
-  What do you expect to happen?

Calling `jQuery.holdReady(false)` without calling `jQuery.holdReady()` should not trigger `jQuery.ready()` if dom is actually not ready.
-  What acually happens?

Calling `jQuery.holdReady(false)` without calling `jQuery.holdReady()` triggering `jQuery.ready()` and jQuery actually think dom is ready.
-  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a _minimal_ test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

I was going backward and forward whether I should open an issue. But I can totally provide a test case for this.

title: Security Error in Chrome when use contents()
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest (1.x, 2.x, 3.x) versions of jQuery.

  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->
### Description

Using of method "contents()" on page with iframes from remote domain causes fatal error in Google Chrome:
Uncaught SecurityError: Failed to read the 'contentDocument' property from 'HTMLIFrameElement': Blocked a frame with origin "http://example.com" from accessing a frame with origin "https://www.youtube.com".  The frame requesting access has a protocol of "http", the frame being accessed has a protocol of "https". Protocols must match.

To prevent errors when using "contents()"  maybe should:
replace 
`return elem.contentDocument || jQuery.merge( [], elem.childNodes );`
by

```
try {
    return elem.contentDocument || jQuery.merge( [], elem.childNodes );
} catch (e) { 
    return false;
} 

```

or add checking that elem is not iframe from remote domain before expression 
`elem.contentDocument`
### Link to test case

title: event namespacing broken
IE11 - Script 5007: Unable to get property 'style' of undefined or null reference
body:
jQuery 3.1.0 stops execution on Internet Explorer 11 and 10 (VirtualBox, Windows 7) on first load, when website has not been cached yet with the following error message:

**Script 5007: Unable to get property 'style' of undefined or null reference**

This refers to **function computeStyleTests()**, in particular to `div.style.marginRight="50%";`

This basically stops any script from being executed on the page. The error disappears if the page is reloaded. In IE10 and lower it silently fails without any error message.

This problem does not appear on any other modern browser or platform.

title: Unify filtering by selector in `winnow`
body: Per https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/3261/files/c1339665c27440a23a5576ca1dfdad9c38567288#r74370245 , the complexity of separate branches for simple vs. non-simple selectors doesn't seem worthwhile. Both of them should defer directly to `jQuery.filter`.

title: <script defer> fires after $(function) in Chrome and FX
body:
In Chrome, FX and IE >=10 ` ... ...
waiting...
waiting...
``` Both tests pass when files load fast enough, but sufficient delays (>50ms each) in the `*.js` files cause the jQuery test to fail in latest Chrome and FX. It doesn't fail consistently, but the jQuery ready always fires before the document one. [Here is a jsBin that reproduces it on first load](https://jsbin.com/taremu/edit?html,output), although this might depend on your network and subsequent loads won't show the bug. Try throttling your connection and CTRL+F5 if it doesn't happen on first load. This bug is extant in the latest 2.x and 3.x but doesn't seem to occur in 1.x This appears to be due to this check: ``` javascript // Catch cases where $(document).ready() is called // after the browser event has already occurred. // Support: IE <=9 - 10 only // Older IE sometimes signals "interactive" too soon if ( document.readyState === "complete" || ( document.readyState !== "loading" && !document.documentElement.doScroll ) ) { // Handle it asynchronously to allow scripts the opportunity to delay ready window.setTimeout( jQuery.ready ); } ``` When debugging it appears that `document.readyState === 'interactive'` and `!document.documentElement.doScroll` is true, so `jQuery.ready` fires with the minimum delay (4ms). Breaking on `window.setTimeout` halts execution while some of the numbered js files are still `pending` in the Network tab. I don't know whether this is a recent change in behavior, but Chrome and Firefox appear to report `document.readyState === 'interactive'` as soon as the body is present, but before deferred scripts are evaluated. This isn't a problem in IE < 10 as it doesn't support `defer` (it sort of does, but fires scripts out of order and so would fail this test anyway).

title: $.ajax Sends `data` property in DELETE body instead of query string
body:
### Description

The $.ajax functionality in regards to the `data` property is not compliant to the RFC spec for HTTP DELETE standards and causes issues. Currently we are running an api behind a Google Compute L7 Load Balancer and are getting 400 error codes when sending DELETE requests using data.
### Current docs for $.ajax:

**data**
_Type: PlainObject or String or Array_
Data to be sent to the server. It is converted to a query string, if not already a string. It's appended to the url for GET-requests. See processData option to prevent this automatic processing. Object must be Key/Value pairs. If value is an Array, jQuery serializes multiple values with same key based on the value of the traditional setting (described below).
### Why not send data in body??

The HTTP Spec states the following...

> "A payload within a DELETE request message has no defined semantics; sending a payload body on a DELETE request might cause some existing implementations to reject the request."

site: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.5
### Who cares what the spec says??

Apparently Google does. Here's a response from a cloud support specialist regarding the matter...

> DELETE requests with a payload are rejected at the Google frontend service. As stated at [1] "A payload within a DELETE request message has no defined semantics; sending a payload body on a DELETE request might cause some existing implementations to reject the request." Given that the load balancer does not allow a DELETE request with a body, the workarounds you have are to either use the same URL without a body or use a handler where you can POST the same body and delete the specific topic ID.

I would very much appreciate if you could fix the $.ajax functionality to work correctly per the standards defined [here](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-4.3.5), or a more recent version of the specification. I believe the GET method works in this way and if the DELETE method could be changed to work the same as GET, that would be perfect.

I'm a long time user and fan of jQuery and I look forward to continued use. Thank you for taking a few minutes to review my request.

title: Source file location in jQuery CDN .map file is incorrect
body:
At some point in the recent past, Chrome added the ability to manually associate a map file with minified source. For people using the jQuery CDN, this would optimistically mean they could right click on the file in dev tools and for example associate https://code.jquery.com/jquery-3.1.0.min.map with the jQuery 3.1.0 minified file. However, that map file refers back to plain old `jquery.js` as the original source, which is our frozen-in-time 1.11 version. It should refer to `jquery-3.1.0.min.js`.

The release process should ensure the file name matches the one on the CDN so that it could be manually associated for debugging.

Map files are so lame.

title: jQuery 1.12.x line breaks compatiblity with Firefox 5 or older, Netscape and Konqueror
body:
When I tried to update from 1.11.3 to 1.12.4 I noticed that the latest releases broke a lot of old browser versions. Not only did jquery stop working, it totally broke javascript in some of these browsers

I looked into some of the error messages and found solutions:
1. getComputedStyle() always needs to have a pseudo element in older browsers: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/getComputedStyle
2. addEventListener() always needs to have set useCapture explicitly to false in older browsers: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener
3. removeEventListener() always needs to have set useCapture explicitly to false in older browsers: 
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/removeEventListener

Setting a few null / false was not much, but had a huge impact. After adding these, in no browser jquery broke javascript completely and some of the browsers now worked totally fine. But sadly in some old browsers there is still one problem which doesn't break javascript but some of the jquery behaviour. This gives of the error message:
"div.getClientRects is not a function"

Since this worked before, I think there should be a way to fix this. How did jquery handle this before 1.12?

And my second question: Why did jquery 1.12 suddenly have these "bugs" on some places of the code? Was it decided to drop support for these old browsers, or was that a regression introduced by code rewriting?

Thanks :)

**What actually happens?**

title: Event types colliding with Object prototype properties don't work
body:
We use `event.type` [as a key](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/305f193aa57014dc7d8fa0739a3fefd47166cd44/src/event.js#L294) to get the array of event handlers, which throws an exception when we instead receive an `Object.prototype` property and treat it like an array: https://jsfiddle.net/9t4kqaqr/

Our standard fix is appending a space (cf. [delegated selector match tracking](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/305f193aa57014dc7d8fa0739a3fefd47166cd44/src/event.js#L370-L371) and [Sizzle `createCache`](https://github.com/jquery/sizzle/blob/582b63c607b344ce5838d89eaf57e693461948b2/src/sizzle.js#L349-L367)), but we should also consider `Map` for such purposes (ponyfilling as needed), especially if [Data.js](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/305f193aa57014dc7d8fa0739a3fefd47166cd44/src/data/Data.js) can be updated accordingly—one of @rwaldron's original goals when creating it.

title: Insufficient documentation with parseHTML 3.x behaviour
body:
Hi, 

I ran into an issue with jQuery.parseHTML while switching my project to jQuery 3.x.

The part of the documentation which is the issue is : 

> As of 3.0 the default behavior is changed. If the context is not specified or given as null or undefined, a new document is used.

The problem is, in the case the context parameter is boolean, a new document is also created, with : 
`jQuery.parseHTML(html, [true|false])`

We could then change the doc : 

> As of 3.0 the default behavior is changed. If the context is not specified or given as null or undefined **or boolean**, a new document is used.

As a second through, the new document should only be used when keepScripts is true, so maybe change the [line 32](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/src/core/parseHTML.js#L32) : 
`if ( support.createHTMLDocument ) {`
to
`if ( support.createHTMLDocument && keepScripts ) {`

The new document is a strange behaviour (jQuery ui widget cannot work with this type of element because it uses [this.element.ownerDocument to set this.document](https://github.com/jquery/jquery-ui/blob/master/ui/widget.js#L310), which is not the current document anymore), and should be restricted only to keepScripts = true.

What do you think about this ? Regards, Olivier

title: Subtle bug with offset() and scroll position
body: A common use for `offset()` is to scroll the viewport to an anchor element. eg: ``` $("html, body").animate({ scrollTop: $(`#an-anchor`).offset().top }); ``` In my case, the element I am scrolling to looks like this: ``` ``` See the v3 source code of `offset` here: https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/src/offset.js#L106-L115 Because my anchor doesn't have a height or width, the `offset()` top and left are not correctly taking into account `pageYOffset`. `offset()` is returning the _top_ of `getBoundingClientRect()`, which is relative to the _viewport_, not the _document_. I fixed this by changing the markup to ` `, but `offset()` should be able to correctly handle the original markup.

title: Remove `event.which` property fill
body:
IE8 seems to be the last browser that didn't provide this natively. It's a bit tricky to test because it needs a real event and not a simulated one. 

https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/3233#discussion_r70875393

See also gh-2337, if we're not filling the property and just passing it on I don't know that we need to formally deprecate it in jQuery or generate a Migrate warning. If browsers ever tried to deprecate it via a console warning, the pass-through we do when copying the property would be the responsibility of the caller. If anything I'd say we add a note in our docs to use `event.button` or `event.buttons` where possible.

title: .param() function ignores Set object
body:
Hi. It looks like .param() function used fro all AJAX requests ignores the Set object. Tested with 3.0.0 version.

Here's the code 

```
let s = new Set([1,2]);

let params = {
  set: s,
  arr: [...s]
}

console.log($.param(params))
```

Output is `"arr%5B%5D=1&arr%5B%5D=2"`. I'm expecting `"arr%5B%5D=1&arr%5B%5D=2&set%5B%5D=1&set%5B%5D=2"`

It's still the question should we serialize Set as Array. But I think it's the closest Set representation in case of GET request.

Here's the live demo http://codepen.io/fetis/pen/JKrdvX?editors=1111

title: jQuery.ajax() with cache: false mangles URL with _ parameter
Deferred should group async operations
body:
Today each promise operation has it's own `setTimeout` creating many async events.

The aplus spec allows promise operations to be grouped (see [note 3.1](https://promisesaplus.com/#point-67)) and the operations also don't have to be strictly async, as long as they are called by "platform code" (see [2.2.4](https://promisesaplus.com/#point-34)).

Grouping the operations and reducing `setTimeout`s will:
- Improve performance by having less timeouts/async events
- Reduce the probability of aplus tests failing with `Error: timeout of 200ms exceeded` errors. I see this locally fairly often.
- Allow other "platform code" to flush the pending promise operations. For example load-before-ready (#3194, #3197) could be fixed by flushing the pending promise operations on the [DOMContentLoaded event](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/ad6a94c3f1747829082b85fd53ee2efbae879707/src/core/ready.js#L70-L74).

title: .not(arrayLike) shouldn't restrict results to elements
body:
As [reported](http://irc.jquery.org/%23jquery-dev/latest.log.html#t11:52:27) by @scottgonzalez, `.not( arrayLike )` started filtering out non-element items in jQuery 3: http://jsbin.com/yobuhucife/1/edit?html,js,output . This is inconsistent with `.not( singleNode )` and `.not( fn )`, and counter to the stated "not(Selector) excludes non-element nodes" goals of the commit that introduced it: 0e2f8f9effd2c95647be534bf9055e099aad7cfd.

We should restrict the additional filtering to selector input (i.e., `.not( string )`).

title: Deprecate event shorthand methods
body: As [discussed](http://irc.jquery.org/%23jquery-meeting/latest.log.html#t12:54:24) in the core meeting, we should deprecate `on`/`trigger` [event shorthand methods](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/305f193aa57014dc7d8fa0739a3fefd47166cd44/src/event/alias.js) in a pre-4.0 minor release.

title: $.on("ready", handler) shouldn't be deprecated and should behave the same as $(handler)
body:
From http://api.jquery.com/ready/

> There is also $(document).on( "ready", handler ), deprecated as of jQuery 1.8. This behaves similarly to the ready method but if the ready event has already fired and you try to .on( "ready" ) the bound handler will not be executed. Ready handlers bound this way are executed after any bound by the other three methods above.

Wait, what??

So, I have to remember that I can't use `$(window).load(handler)`, I have to use `$(window).on("load", handler)` instead; but on the other hand, for the `ready` event it's the other way round: I can't use `$(document).on("ready", handler)`, I should use `$(document).ready(handler)` or `$(handler)` instead. And also, `$(handler)` _is_ the same as `$(document).ready(handler)` but it is _not_ the same as `$(document).on("ready", handler)`. Unlike **every** other event, where `$(something).on("event", handler)` _is_ the same as `$(something).event(handler)`.

That's a lot of gratuitous inconsistencies and a lot of unnecessary things to know that one can easily miss.

`$(document).on("ready", handler)` should not be deprecated, and it should behave the same as `$(handler)`, both in whether it is fired or not and in the order of execution.

I know, you'll tell me that it is not gratuitous and unnecessary, that it is because of how stuff is implementated. However, implementation difficulties should dealt with by implementors, not exposed to the API users.

title: .load() as a shorthand for .on("load",...) shouldn't be deprecated
body:
I know it has been for a long time, but I have just found out because I have tried jQuery 3 where it has actually stopped working.

The deprecation of `.load()` as a short-hand of `.on("load",...)` is inconsistent. You haven't deprecated `.click()`, `.ready()`, etc., and you are not going to, are you? Until then, `.load()` shouldn't be deprecated either. It just create unnecessary inconsistency.

I do see the rationale behind it: it is ambiguous with the ajax `.load()` method. Discouraging its use is a good idea, but deprecating it and breaking it is going too far. **Unless** you do the same with all the event-binding shorthand methods such as `.click()`, `.keydown()`, `.ready()` etc. 
(Which wouldn't be such a crazy idea btw if it wasn't for backward compatibility: that has always been a bas API design from the beginning, sacrificing clearness for the sake of saving a few keystrokes in writing code.)

**Consistency** is a must in such a large API as jQuery's.

(by the way, it's ironic that with `.ready()` you did the opposite thing: keeping the `.ready()` method and deprecating `.on("ready")`; just one more inconsistency with even less reason to exist)

title: $("selector", data) from data loaded via ajax only works starting from one level of nesting
body:
Suppose you have this file called `loaded.html`: ``` This is the loaded page's title
First level div, direct child of body. Can't be retrieved.
Second level div, i.e. nested within a div. Can be retrieved.
``` Now from another file you do: ``` $.ajax({ url: 'loaded.html', success: function(data) { console.log($("#test1", data).length); console.log($("#test2", data).length); } }); ``` **EXPECTED**: both lines should output **1**. **OBSERVED**: the first outputs 0, the second outputs 1 as expected. It seems that only nodes of a depth of at least 3 in the DOM tree of the loaded data (where 0 is the `` node itself, 1 is the body, and 2 would be a direct child of the body) can be retrieved. Not even direct children of body can, let alone the body itself, or the `` etc., which by the way you should be able to retrieve too. This is utter nonsense and is not even documented. Simple test case: http://matteosistisette.com/test/stupidjquery/1/

title: Under IE10 can't submit form with submit() method
$.offset() is returning improper top, left for scaled viewports on devices such as Chromebook Touch/Surface/iOS/Android for relatively positioned parents.
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest (1.x, 2.x, 3.x) versions of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What acually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->
### Description

I expect when returning the offset, even if the viewport is scaled, it should properly give me the top & left registration point of the relatively positioned parent element. Instead, the amount of offset in the window's pageYOffset/pageXOffset properties need to be subtracted out to give a proper top & left registration point for the relatively positioned parent. You also need to subtract out the document element's top & left values in its client rect in case it has been scrolled when panning around the scaled viewport.

This is how we're handling it in our code once we get the offset back from jQuery: 

``` javascript
var offset = $(el).offset();

//get document element width without scrollbar
var prevStyle = document.body.style.overflow || "";
document.body.style.overflow = "hidden";
var docWidth = document.documentElement.clientWidth;
document.body.style.overflow = prevStyle;

if(docWidth / window.innerWidth !== 1) { //kind of a hack to determine if the viewport has been scaled
    var docRect = document.documentElement.getBoundingClientRect();
    offset = {
        top: offset.top - window.pageYOffset - docRect.top,
        left: offset.left - window.pageXOffset - docRect.left
    };
}
```

Note: We've only tested this in WebKit based browsers such as Mobile Safari & Chrome.

[JSBin](http://jsbin.com/jacuhakafa/)
**Testcase Steps**
- Open link on a touch device (Chromebook Touch/iOS/Android/Surface) in a WebKit browser (Safari/Chrome for example).
- Spread two fingers gesture to zoom page in.
- Tap the green box to place a red square within it.
- Notice that the red square is not placed within its parent correctly.

title: .html() does not entity-encode greater-than character in attributes
body:
### Description Per the WHATWG HTML5 spec, attributes cannot contain the greater-than ( > ) character: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/syntax.html#attributes-2 jQuery's .html() method does not respect this: ``` var $x = $('x'); $x.find('a').prop('title', 'a

b

c'); $x.html() // x ``` `<` and `>` should be changed to `<` and `>`, respectively. (For `<` that's actually not required by the standard but is more user-friendly.) Tested on Chrome 50.0.2661.86 (64-bit), on Ubuntu 14.04. ### Link to test case https://jsfiddle.net/ph3mvrsb/

title: Setting the selected option using prop() vs attr() in IE11
body:
Hi all,

I'm having a problem selecting options and reading when using both prop() and attr() methods. I reduced the problem to what could be seen in the following fiddler:
https://jsfiddle.net/kz3nskf6/1/

Basically after setting the property of all options to false I can't set a selected property using $.attr() method and then read the select value with $.val(). The problem only occurs in IE11 (I haven't tried other versions).

While this may seem an odd thing to do I got here since I'm using different jQuery plugins to enhance my selects (multiselect and picklist). I can't programatically clean all selected options by using the prop() method because later on the multiselect will not work anymore but I can't also just use the attr() method since the multiselect uses the prop().

I'm not sure if this is a bug or simply a browser limitation (or even the intended behavior). Chrome and Firefox seem to handle that just fine.

I tried several different jQuery versions but without luck.

Thanks in advance for your help.

title: jQuery 3.0 still breaks sourceMaps
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest (1.x, 2.x, 3.x) versions of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What acually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->
### Description

Traceback reformatting breaks source-maps, it is unreadable compared to browser built in tracebacks, and it cannot be folded closed like browser built in tracebacks. Tracebacks are an essential development tool. Breaking traceback is not an acceptable way to write libraries.

Closing tickets pointing out that jQuery breaks tracebacks, does not fix tracebacks.

title: Exceptions silently swallowed in $(fn)
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest (1.x, 2.x, 3.x) versions of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What acually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->
### Description

If an exception is thrown in an event handler (such as $.ready), it is silently swalloed.

There are many cases in which exceptions are used to indicate errors for situations that are not code errors, for instance:

``` javascript
var foo = function(arg){
  var result = parseFloat(arg);
  if(isNaN(result)){ 
    throw new Error('not a number');
  }
};
```

Exceptions like that may be cought by the user, such as when the number is user-input. But they may also indicate errors in the usage of the code (such as foo('123') ), in which case catching them is counter productive since they can't be debugged anymore.
### Link to test case

http://jsbin.com/bazaxixihe/edit?html,js,output

### Description

In your document, i find:

> Note: jQuery does not support getting the offset coordinates of hidden elements or accounting for borders, margins, or padding set on the body element.

And in your code, it's:

``` js
// Make sure element is not hidden (display: none)
if ( rect.width || rect.height ) {
    ...
}
```

So how about element shown but with 0 width and height? Seems it's belong to hidden element in your code and get wrong offset value.
Is that a feature or issue? Since there may be some chance i need to know a element's offset which is shown but has no size.
### Link to test case

http://codepen.io/poppinlp/pen/gMMaEY

In this test case you will see element with no size get wrong offset.

title: wrap() does not refocus wrapped element
Document Safari Mobile support
body:
Now that jQuery 3 is out, I looked at the [browser support page](http://jquery.com/browser-support/) and saw that only the _Current_ and _Current - 1_ versions of Safari are supported (currently those should be 9.1.1 and 9.1 respectively).
Anyway, the Mobile section also mentions support for iOS: 7+. If I'm not mistaken, the first iOS 7 release came with Safari Mobile 6.1 preinstalled in late 2013.
Does this mean that Safari Mobile 6.1+ is actively supported by jQuery? Or does it mean that iOS 7 is only supported when Safari Mobile is updated to the almost latest version?
I'm sorry if this sounds like a silly feature request. I really wished those facts were better addressed by the documentation when reporting browsers versions and OS versions in the same list.

title: Locking issues to comments is a bad practice
body:
For example at https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/3160#issuecomment-225445829

The last comment is:

> I don't think this discussion is going to resolve anything so I'll lock the thread. I've given the reasons why we don't provide detailed API violations and you disagree which is your right, but it won't change our [approach](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/API-design-guidelines).

 Locking the issue to comments was totally unnecessary or at the very least premature. The administrator here could have just made the same comment without locking the issue, so I could have asked him what part exactly of the API guidelines he linked to is supposed to back his point.

In general, locking an issue to comments is a very stupid thing to do. It should be a last resort in extreme cases.

title: Uncaught TypeError: n.easing[this.easing] is not a function
body:
To reproduce: call animate() with an invalid value for the easing parameter, e.g. "kjbdkjbdbd".

Expected: a meaningful exception with a sensible error message such as "Unknown easing type 'xxxxx'" and whose first or second item in the stacktrace is the line of code calling animate().

Observed: an uncaught exception very deep inside jQuery's code, difficult to debug.

Uncaught exceptions are by definition bugs. For god's f***ing sake, check the sanity of input values.

title: data() function possible bug or stupid intend?
body:
### Description When using the data() function, then jQuery will get the attribute value if it doesn't exist, and get the data and NOT attribute value if it doesn't exist. Heres an example:
If you fire $("div").data("foo");, then it will return "house". That makes you believe that the data("foo") function is linked to the data-foo attribute in the DOM. So if you set it now like this: $("div").data("foo", "bike"); Now you think that the data-foo attribute value is "bike", haha, thats not the case, its still "house". So now, to get the attribute data-foo, you need to write $("div").attr("data-foo"); And to get the foo data in the code that i set, then i need to go for $("div").data("foo"). That is EXTREMELY error prone, because there could be name classes between the $("div").data("foo") and the $("div").attr("data-foo"); An example could be if you wanted to check if a key/value pair is undefined in the data(). But it is defined if the DOM object has the attribute and it is undefined if it doesn't have that attribute. I figured it out when i was coding, and i expected something to be undefined, but it was defined because i had the same data-XXX attribute name as i had in the data("XXX") jQuery function. And then all the bug hell broke lose. Is this a bug or a stupid intend? I think its very error-prone. ### Link to test case https://jsfiddle.net/ahmdgm1r/

title: jQuery UI (1.11.4) position without specifying within gets error
body:
The jQuery UI position utility function dies with the new jQuery 3 when a wthin option is not specified.
The default for within is Window.
The position routine tries to use the offset routine of jQuery.
According to the new documentation use of  Window to query offset will throw an error:
Excerpt from blog:https://blog.jquery.com/2016/06/09/jquery-3-0-final-released/

> **_Error cases don’t silently fail
> 
> Perhaps in a profound moment you’ve wondered, “What is the offset of a window?” Then you probably realized that is a crazy question – how can a window even have an offset?
> 
> In the past, jQuery has sometimes tried to make cases like this return something rather than having them throw errors. In this particular case of asking for the offset of a window, the answer up to now has been { top: 0, left: 0 } With jQuery 3.0, such cases will throw errors so that crazy requests aren’t silently ignored. Please try out this release and see if there is any code out there depending on jQuery to mask problems with invalid inputs._**

My fix in jQuery-ui:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4060795/15963969/e7986c8c-2ee3-11e6-89f8-11db3fc45660.png)

title: Minified version of jQuery include unexpect block scoped function
Inconsistent call sequence of $.when with single promise
body:
I fear the ⚡  thunder of the JavaScript gods ⚡ , but I'll still venture to ask: what output should the following produce?

```
deferred = $.Deferred()
deferred.done(function() { console.log('A') })
$.when(deferred).done(function() { console.log('B') })
$.when(deferred, deferred).done(function() { console.log('C') })
deferred.resolve()
console.log('D')
```

I get the 'ABCD' I was hoping for in jQuery 2.x, 3.0.0-beta1, but in 3.0.0-rc1 I now get 'ACDB'.

Although I don't particularly care about it, I'll mention that if using `then` instead of `done`, in 3.0.0-rc1 I get 'DACB', when I was expecting 'DABC', for the same reasons I imagine.

I remember the polymorphic nature of `$.when`, but I feel this has more to do with argument passing than with calling order. Indeed, the native equivalent give me 'dabc':

```
var resolve;
p = new Promise(function(r) { resolve = r })
p.then(function() { console.log('a') })
Promise.resolve(p).then(function() { console.log('b') })
Promise.all([p, p]).then(function() { console.log('c') })
resolve()
console.log('d')
```

cc @gibson042 
_/ducks for cover_

title: Sets of generic objects support in 3.x
body:
It appears that the following is no longer supported in jQuery 3.0.0rc1:

```
foo = {hello: 'world'}
$([foo]).not([])  // => Returns $() and not $([foo])
```

I have no problem with this (assuming it is on purpose), but I'd recommend including a note in the release notes, as many people are relying on this (or did I miss it)?

In particular, see these 3 StackOverflow answers [here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/7726509/8279), [here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/26398304/8279) and [here](http://stackoverflow.com/a/15385871/8279)...

title: $(sel).click() fires multiple events
body:
### Description For a test case, we had implemented a function utilizing `$( selector ).click()`. This broke some assumptions another programmer had made (good, we corrected those). Meanwhile, while researching why currentTarget was not set for this test case, we discovered that click() was firing not one, but two events. Here is actual output from our reduced test case (attached below): #### Native Click ``` Click Handler: MouseEvent {isTrusted: true, screenX: 94, screenY: 165, clientX: 94, clientY: 55…} index.html:10 Event type: click index.html:11 Event target:
​…​
​ index.html:12 Event currentTarget:
​…​
​ ``` #### Generated with jQuery 2.2.4 ``` index.html:16 Native button click event: MouseEvent {isTrusted: true, screenX: 95, screenY: 200, clientX: 95, clientY: 90…} index.html:17 Delaying jQuery generated click ... index.html:19 ... Generating jQuery click index.html:9 Click Handler: n.Event {type: "click", timeStamp: 1465332138698, jQuery22406390061249255916: true, isTrigger: 3, namespace: ""…} index.html:10 Event type: click index.html:11 Event target:
​Child - Click in here for native event​
​ index.html:12 Event currentTarget: undefined index.html:9 Click Handler: MouseEvent {isTrusted: false, screenX: 0, screenY: 0, clientX: 0, clientY: 0…} index.html:10 Event type: click index.html:11 Event target:
​Child - Click in here for native event​
​ index.html:12 Event currentTarget:
​…​
​ ``` ### Link to test case Complete, self-contained test case (34 lines of HTML/JS, 2 functions): - [index.txt](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/files/303510/index.txt) Apologies for text file, GitHub doesn't appear to accept HTML.

title: Add support for JSPM sfx bundles.
body:
Feature Request:
**\- Does it require access to jQuery internals?**
- Yes it does. The problem seems to be in the way jQuery is exported.

**\- Can jQuery itself benefit from the feature?**
- Yes it does. jQuery can be used in more development and production environments.

**\- Is the feature related to DOM operations?**
- No.

**\- Is the need already served by a plugin?**
- No.

**\- Does it change an existing API?**
- No.

**\- Does it support best practice?**
- Yes.
### Description

In my project to create our widget bundles we are using:
- [jspm](http://jspm.io/docs/getting-started.html) - [jspm-cli](https://github.com/jspm/jspm-cli)

As they are widgets we want our code as isolated as possible, so we use jspm sfx bundles that you can create using:

``` js
jspm bundle-sfx scripts/main dist/main.js
```

The problem is that if this packages doesn't add a `define` or  `require` to the global and when jQuery wants to export itself it decides that needs to be on the global.

Overwriting the jQuery we have in the page we have a lot of issues.
### Link to test case

https://jsfiddle.net/aptm7qxy/1/

If we use Webpack Dev Server it doesn't happens:

https://jsfiddle.net/2xua7b98/

title: Use RAF's timestamp for smoother animations
body:
jQuery 3.0.0-rc1 uses `requestAnimationFrame`, resulting in significantly smoother animations compared to before. However, its tweening logic uses `Date.now()` instead of the [RAF `timestamp` argument](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/window/requestAnimationFrame). As a result, the animation is still _slightly_ choppy.

Before you switch to using `timestamp`, I should point out that the Velocity.js library opts not to use `timestamp` ([velocity.js:3366](https://github.com/julianshapiro/velocity/blob/9c9c052a5fb6d5854c9aad931d9410c6790816ee/velocity.js#L3366-L3368)):

```
/* We ignore RAF's high resolution timestamp since it can be significantly offset
   when the browser is
   under high stress; we opt for choppiness over allowing the browser to drop huge
   chunks of frames. */
var timeCurrent = (new Date).getTime();
```

I don't know if this is actually still an issue in modern browsers. @julianshapiro originally wrote this code in 2014 -- perhaps he can chime in with some details.

I created a test case to demonstrate choppiness resulting from not using `timestamp`: https://codepen.io/joliss/pen/wWKGeV/ (The test case uses Velocity.js, but I believe it's the same for jQuery.)

My hope is that you can use this test case as a debugging aid, and as a motivating example to convince browser vendors to get any remaining `timestamp` issues resolved.

Running the CodePen, we see that there is some slight choppiness with the jQuery's `getTime` implementation:

![a pen by jo liss jtbyc](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/524783/15835268/1281d79a-2c27-11e6-9d3e-14e0c735f47b.png)

Using the RAF `timestamp` argument instead, the animation feels smoother, and the graph is perfectly smooth as well:

![a pen by jo liss her4j](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/524783/15835273/1b4f9f2e-2c27-11e6-8e70-801d7c627b73.png)

I thought that perhaps using the microsecond-resolution `performance.now()` function would improve smoothness, but it doesn't seem to help much:

![a pen by jo liss hft9a](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/524783/15835281/243ff674-2c27-11e6-8ed5-64e5be7da169.png)

title: `jQuery.Event( src )` cannot require `src.target`
body: If you construct a `jQuery.Event( src )` using something that has `src.type`, the 3.0 code will die if there is not an `src.target` property. jQuery Mobile uses a pattern where they construct an object and then set properties like `target` afterwards, which was allowed by 1.x/2.x, so we need to fix this as a regression.

title: Studying the evolution of JQuery's project
body:
Hi there, 

I'm a researcher studying software evolution. As part of my current research, I'm studying the implications of open-sourcing a proprietary software, for instance, if the project succeed in attracting newcomers. JQuery was in my list. 

To further analyze the impacts of JQuery’s migration, we analyzed the git log commit history of your project in terms of _number of contributions_, _number of newcomers_, and _number of contributors per month_. The following figure presents a temporal perspective regarding these three measures. 

![jquery](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/235062/15755667/a70604e0-28b2-11e6-85bc-356b86e67510.png)

Given the numbers presented in the graphic, we would like to ask JQuery developers the following questions:
1. What motivated the project to open its source code at Github? How do you evaluate the benefits of this migration?
2. Does this snapshot make sense? Did you find any inconsistency on the data?
3. Do you have any internal policy to promote/attract/retain newcomers? If so, do them succeed?
4. Why there was a slope on the number of newcomers that joined the project? 

Thanks in advance for your collaboration,

Gustavo Pinto, PhD
http://www.gustavopinto.org

title: Bootstrap 3 unit test fail with SVG element
body:
[This test](https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/blob/f01f3e5f34c1acdd802cc61ea9aae9f9b14169c3/js/tests/unit/tooltip.js#L1042-1079) from Bootstrap 3 (the current version) fails on Chrome and Safari but passes on IE, Edge, and Firefox. Our [`getClientRects` call inside `.offset`](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/73bf35ecf31867d7ed4662374121efa310cf9f8d/src/offset.js#L96-101) returns a length of zero on those browsers but `getBoundingClientRect` seems to work fine. 

It's a relatively edgy case and this unit test isn't present in Bootstrap 4, but given the way it fails it isn't something that can be easily worked around via Migrate for example. I'm also worried that other code may be expecting to get offsets on SVG elements, even though we've never officially supported it. Would it work to check whether the current element is SVG perhaps and avoid the check for that case?

title: rfocusMorph fails when jQuery.event.triggered is undefined
Boolean attribute getters throw if the attribute name is not all lowercase
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest (1.x, 2.x, 3.x) versions of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What acually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on https://jsbin.com or https://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->
### Description

In #2916 we removed our logic that lowercased attribute names. This caused one regression: any attribute getter using a name for boolean attributes but not all lowercased is going into an infinite recursion, exceeding the stack call limit.

Amongst others, this is breaking the AngularJS test suite when tested with jQuery 3.0.0-rc1.
### Link to test case

https://jsfiddle.net/shnann6y/2/

Basically, `$('<div>').attr('requiRed')` is enough to trigger the error.

title: .width() totally broken: systematically rounded, inaccurate
body:
http://output.jsbin.com/soteno
1. Look at the console output, which prints ·("#test").width()
2. Compare it with the actual value, as displayed by the browser's dev tools

Expected: the value should be 100% accurate
Observed: the value is systematically rounded to an integer (which is not as documented), and it is not even accurately to the nearest integer, nor systematically floored, nor systematically ceiled. Sometimes it is rounded to N+1 when its value is less than N<0.5, or viceversa.

Anyway, it shouldn't be rounded at all.

This renders .width() totally broken and absolutely useless.

title: JQ3.0 RC1, Deferred.notify / .progress callback getting the wrong params
Selector of input with attribute [value=xxx] doesn't take changes via .val function into account
body:
I think there is a problem in jQuery 1.9.0+ as the selector of value is not taking into account the value set by the val function of jQuery.
I'm not sure that it's by design or not, but it seems like a bug.
If you set a value of a text box via $("input:text").val("newValue") then the selector of jQuery is not taking this change into account.
So the $("input:text[value='newValue']") returns nothing.

You can check the difference in the following links:
jQuery 1.9+:
https://jsfiddle.net/fghamsary/13v7kobL/2/
jQuery 1.8.3-:
https://jsfiddle.net/fghamsary/13v7kobL/3/

Normally I would expect change with .val function to be reflected on the value attribute of the input as well. (Which seems reasonable)

Bug Reports:

  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What acually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on http://jsbin.com or http://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

*\* Description**
Using the latest versions (as of 5/18/16) - 1.12.3 and 2.2.3
and also the latest jQuery validate files.

On a simple form of  9 fields, 5 input and 4 select boxes, with validation around it,
during a jQuery submit, I am noticing a 3.5 - 4.5 second delay in the triggering of the submit.

Doing testing and using FireBug, I was able to locate the line of code that was slowly down the system: $("#myform500002").submit();

The chunk of code in question was:

```
$.validator.setDefaults({
    submitHandler: function() {
        $("#myform500002").submit();            
    }
});
```

This section was causing a delay in processing.

When changing from the above code to the following code:
    $.validator.setDefaults({
        submitHandler: function() {
            var formname = 'myform500002';
            document.formname.submit();  
        }
    });

The form submitted almost immediately (1 second delay).
I would account for the delay for the submission of the code on the server. 

The jQuery submit process is slow, while a javascript submit is much faster.

*\* Link to test case **
I don't have an external link to the code but if you need the source code, I can post that.

Thanks

title: Empty value of cloned input element changed to type 'hidden' is lost
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest (1.x, 2.x, 3.x) versions of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What acually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on http://jsbin.com or http://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

This is a corner case indeed, but it happened to me just now, so ...
## What works

I have a pre filled input field on page load:

```
<input type="text" value="test" id="test">
```

The input field is then changed, e.g.

```
$('#test').val('something')
```

Then I clone the element and change it to hidden type:

```
var $clone = $('#test').clone()
$clone.attr('type', 'hidden')
```

... and I look at the cloned val:

```
$clone.val() // -> 'something'
```

Everything fine. The clone has the same value as the original input.
## What does not work

If I change the value of the original not to `something`, but empty it (by hand or by js) ...

```
$('#test').val('')
```

... and do everything else like before, the val of cloned input field is:

```
$clone.val() // -> 'test'
```

... - it is the value of the original input on page load! It should be empty, of course.

**Fiddle:** https://jsfiddle.net/m7yndayg/1/

If I do not change the cloned type to `hidden`, it works as expected.

So it fails only if these conditions are met:
1. the original input has a non empty value attribute
2. the original input is cleared after page load
3. the type of the clone is changed to hidden

Happens on 2.2.3, 1.12.2 and 3.0.0-alpha1. Tested with Firefox 48.0a2 here.

title: Bug: jQuery.data() read differs from .data() when using kebab-case and object-notation

`$(element).data({ 'in-view': true });`
`$(element).data('in-view', false);`

Now reading `data('in-view')` should return `false`, but in fact returns `true`

Using `jQuery.data($(element), 'in-view')` works fine!

Test case: https://jsfiddle.net/u0ersr5e/1/

title: Shim focusin/focusout in all browsers?
body:
<!--
Feature Requests:
  Please read https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Adding-new-features
  Most features should start as plugins outside of jQuery.

Bug Reports:
  Note that we only can fix bugs in the latest (1.x, 2.x, 3.x) versions of jQuery.
  Briefly describe the issue you've encountered
  *  What do you expect to happen?
  *  What acually happens?
  *  Which browsers are affected?
  Provide a *minimal* test case, see https://webkit.org/test-case-reduction/
  Use the latest shipping version of jQuery in your test case!
  We prefer test cases on http://jsbin.com or http://jsfiddle.net

Frequently Reported Issues:
  * Selectors with '#' break: See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2824
-->

**Description**
If `focusout` & `blur` handlers are attached on one input and `focusin` & `focus` on the second one, the order of events fired by jQuery is:
1. `focusout`
2. `blur`
3. `focusin`
4. `focus`

The order mandated by [the spec](https://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-3-Events/#h-events-focusevent-event-order) and followed by IE 11 is:
1. `focusout`
2. `focusin`
3. `blur`
4. `focus`

EDIT: IE is not following the spec, though, as it fires only `focusout` & `focusin` synchronously and `blur`/`focus` asynchronously. This has been fixed in Edge and now all events are fired synchronously as in other browsers.

(The spec also mandates that focus is lost after `focusout` & before `blur` and gained after `focusin` but before `focus` event fires).

Chrome/Safari do the following:
1. `blur`
2. `focusout`
3. `focus`
4. `focusin`

Edge 13 does the following:
1. `focusout`
2. `blur`
3. `focus`
4. `focusin`

Firefox doesn't support those events yet but there's ongoing work in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=687787.

We're currently polyfilling this event everywhere except in IE. Since IE differs from our implementation and it's an obsolete browser it sounds bad to let it do its own thing different than what we have. Should we just shim everywhere?

**Link to test case**
https://jsfiddle.net/66znLhfw/2/

title: `.position()` and `.offsetParent()` return incorrect value
body:
`.position()` method should return a position of element relative to a closest ancestor element that is positioned.
Therefore, for example, if CSS properties `top/left` of the element that has `position:absolute` are set to that returned position, the element should not move.
But when the ancestor element that is positioned does not exist (i.e. all ancestor elements have `position:static`, this is default), a position relative to `<html>` element incorrectly is returned.
For example:
https://jsfiddle.net/fqbgy5pq/

Result:

```
ClientRect   top: 63   left: 63
CSS props    top: auto left: auto
.position()  top: 59   left: 59
Set return value of `.position()` to `top` and `left`, then the element should not move.
ClientRect   top: 59   left: 59
CSS props    top: 59px left: 59px
.position()  top: 55   left: 55
```

**Note:** `2px` was lost by this issue, and more `2px` was lost by [another issue of `.offset()`](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/3080).
When fixed `.offset()` is used:

Result:

```
ClientRect   top: 63   left: 63
CSS props    top: auto left: auto
.position()  top: 61   left: 61
Set return value of `.position()` to `top` and `left`, then the element should not move.
ClientRect   top: 61   left: 61
CSS props    top: 61px left: 61px
.position()  top: 59   left: 59
```

`.offsetParent()` method that is called by `.position()` method returns `<html>` when ancestor element that is positioned is not found. Then, `.position()` mistakes.
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/305f193aa57014dc7d8fa0739a3fefd47166cd44/src/offset.js#L180
I think that `.offsetParent()` should return `document` or `null` in this case.
`document` means "base of coordinates".
`null` means "ancestor element is not found".

Also, `.position()` method should return coordinates relative to the document in this case.

And also, `.position()` method returns incorrect coordinates when `<html>` has `position:non-static` (i.e. the ancestor element is really `<html>`).
For example:
https://jsfiddle.net/wczL6ae5/

Result:

```
ClientRect   top: 63   left: 63
CSS props    top: auto left: auto
.position()  top: 59   left: 59
Set return value of `.position()` to `top` and `left`, then the element should not move.
ClientRect   top: 62   left: 62
CSS props    top: 59px left: 59px
.position()  top: 58   left: 58
```

**Note:** `1px` was added by this issue, and `2px` was lost by [another issue of `.offset()`](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/3080).
When fixed `.offset()` is used:

Result:

```
ClientRect   top: 63   left: 63
CSS props    top: auto left: auto
.position()  top: 61   left: 61
Set return value of `.position()` to `top` and `left`, then the element should not move.
ClientRect   top: 64   left: 64
CSS props    top: 61px left: 61px
.position()  top: 62   left: 62
```

When `.offsetParent()` method returned `<html>`, `.position()` method ignores its offset.
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/305f193aa57014dc7d8fa0739a3fefd47166cd44/src/offset.js#L144
Therefore, if the `<html>` has offset (i.e. `margin`), returned value is incorrect.
Strange to say, only `border-width` is included in that calculation.
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/305f193aa57014dc7d8fa0739a3fefd47166cd44/src/offset.js#L150

I think that it might affect scripts that exist if the return value of `.offsetParent()` method is changed.
At least, `.position()` should be fixed even if `.offsetParent()` is not fixed. In this case, `.position()` should not use `.offsetParent()`, or it should check whether `position` is `static` when `<html>` was returned.
This issue affects `.offset()` method because setter of `.offset()` uses `.position()`.

title: Ensure we support the common touch and pointer event properies
body:
The two plugins I found that mess with event properties and might be popular are these:

https://github.com/aarongloege/jquery.touchHooks  
https://github.com/timmywil/jquery.event.pointertouch  

Rather than waiting for people to report a problem, let's be sure we added the relevant properties here. In particular, `changedTouches` and `touches`. By the time we remove pageX/Y we will still be way ahead on size.

title: Remove jQuery.event.fix performance bottleneck
body:
Every native event has to go through `jQuery.event.fix()` to copy and normalize properties that go into the `jQuery.Event` object passed to handlers. There is a tension between minimizing the number of items copied for performance reasons versus making more of them available directly so that users won't be forced to get them via `event.originalEvent`. 

See further discussion in gh-2860 and gh-1746.

title: Adding an element with name 'nodeType' using append() prevents subsequent elements being added to the parent
body:
If I append an input element to a form using the append method, where the name of that new child element is "nodeType" (i.e. the same as the HTML element property indicating type), then no elements can be subsequently added to that parent. Subsequent append methods don't raise an error, it just never gets added to the DOM.

I have created a simple JsFiddle that demonstrates the issue: https://jsfiddle.net/vj952g91/3/

I have also created a version of the test case where the same elements are created, but using native JS methods rather than jQuery: https://jsfiddle.net/8yzq4zom/1/; the issue does not occur when using native code.

I have tried this using jQuery 1.12.2, 2.2.3 and 3.0.0 alpha.

I have reproduced this issue in Chrome (my version is 49.0.2623.112) and Firefox (41.0.1). The issue does _not_ occur in IE 11.

title: Ajax- status 200, without data, in response is NOT considered as request success
body:

In case of an Ajax request, if the server responds with status code 200 and do not send any data in response, it is considered as an ERROR.

**Expectation**
It should be considered as SUCCESS and trigger `done` handler of the ajax object.

title: MouseEvent.pageX/pageY fill isn't needed in jQuery 3.0
body:
Related to: https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/3080
Original comment: https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/3080#issuecomment-215337185

> `MouseEvent.pageX/pageY` also might be influenced.
> https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/9f268caaf43629addb9a1a2001ab341839300b14/src/event.js#L435
> If native `event` don't have `pageX/Y`, these are calculated using `clientLeft/clientTop`.
> 
> If `html` element has `border-width:10px` like the example above, in a browser that doesn't support `event.pageX/Y` and correct `clientTop/clientLeft`, jQuery returns `10,10` as `pageX/Y`, when mouse is positioned at left-top-corner of `body`. In a browser that returns correct `clientTop/clientLeft`, jQuery returns `0,0` as `pageX/Y`.
> 
> I feel that `10,10` is correct result.
> 
> But I don't know recent browser that doesn't support `event.pageX/Y`.

Since Firefox returns `0` as `clientTop/clientLeft` of `html` element always, `MouseEvent.pageX/pageY` might be incorrect.
When native `event` object doesn't have `pageX/Y`, `jQuery.event.mouseHooks.filter` calculates these using `document.documentElement.clientLeft/clientTop` (i.e. `border-width` of `html` element).
(But I don't know recent browser that doesn't support `event.pageX/Y`.)

Represent:
https://jsfiddle.net/rent9q5g/
This simulates a browser that doesn't support `event.pageX/Y`.

Chrome:
![m-ch](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4763469/14910319/2a930df4-0e27-11e6-8f38-6ac58f389365.png)

IE:
![m-ie](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4763469/14910321/33f3deb4-0e27-11e6-9c9a-2c4bf728a408.png)

Firefox:
![m-ff](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4763469/14910328/3d939658-0e27-11e6-8e4a-8878a5864a9a.png)

incorrect result in Firefox by its bug, but I think `pageX: 10 pageY: 10` is correct result. That is, `jQuery.event.mouseHooks.filter` should not subtract `clientTop/clientLeft`.

title: Selecting anchor links using `href^=#` is broken as of jQuery 2.2
body:
**Description**

In trying to select anchor links on a page using an attribute starts with selector to target any links that have an href that begin with an octothorp, specifically:

```
$('a[href^=#]')
```

The selector is parsed as invalid in jQuery as of version 2.2 and an error is thrown. This is consistent in the latest versions of Safari, Chrome, Firefox and Opera.

Also, it seems that this issue is only problem when using `#` as the attribute value in the selector. Selecting something like `$('a[href^=foo]')` works as expected.

Here are the test cases I set up. The test code is the same in both. Only the version of jQuery differs:
- https://jsfiddle.net/vh9m4h5r/2/ - Uses jQuery 2.1.4 (test passes)
- https://jsfiddle.net/139916L6/1/ - Uses jQuery 2.2.3 (test fails)

title: issues using the map function with autocomplete
Deferred tests fail in Android 4.0
body:
Commit 76084372c29a59b3fa790ea4d2687f0767514999 introduced a regression in Deferred tests for Android 4.0. If I read that right, its strict mode is a little buggy, causing test failures: http://swarm.jquery.org/result/1233856.

We need to decide what to do about it. Considering low usage of this browser (2.2% of all Android usage as of April 4, 2016 according to [Google Play stats](https://developer.android.com/about/dashboards/index.html)) maybe we should skip those few tests in Android 4.0.

title: `offset` method returns incorrect value in Firefox

**Description**

JavaScript crashes when running jQuery using a selector like `jQuery("a[href*=#]:not([href=#])")`.

It works when enquoting the attribute-value like `jQuery('a[href*="#"]:not([href="#"])')` or when switching back to an older minor release.

**Affected versions**

The example failed in 1.12.x and 2.2.x but works on 1.11.x or 2.1.x

Tried in Firefox 45.0.2 and Google Chrome 50.0.2661.86 (64-bit) but also other users on IRC confirmed it.

- Passing test: https://jsfiddle.net/n3a4dyrb/ (quoted attribute-value)
- Passing test: https://jsfiddle.net/uuf8ppob/ (jQuery 2.1.x)

title: Get rid of excessive "use strict" pragmas in the built file
body: Since our AMD modules are now strict and we're not stripping the `"use strict";` pragmas when building, we have a lot of (harmless) excessive `"use strict";` statements in the built file. They all get stripped when minified so it's not a big deal, just slightly confusing to casual readers of the built file contents.

title: Check minified code for syntax errors (e.g. by trying to construct an AST)
body:
*\* Description**

Enabling strict mode uncovered an UglifyJS issue (https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/issues/1052) where it was creating code with SyntaxErrors. Perhaps we should try to generate the AST of the generated minified code to check if it doesn't contain syntax errors.

title: Update all src modules to strict mode
body: As suggested by @mgol: https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/3061#issuecomment-213641281

title: Class-related methods fail to meet w3c standard for whitespace handling
Event handlers with invalid selectors should be caught at attach time
body:
Otherwise, they become very difficult to debug.

See [this jsfiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/v4emgtLs/1/) for an example. Attaching an event handler with an invalid selector `div:not` causes an exception to be raised at event time. This makes it very difficult to debug, as the trace of the error will usually only include jquery code.

I suggest jQuery should throw an exception at attach time instead, which makes it fairly easy to detect the faulty code.

title: src/core/support.js triggers a Content-Security-Policy error in Firefox if base-uri directive is declared
:input[type!='hidden'] not working
body:
The query

```
$("#mydiv :input[type!='hidden']")
```

returns input elements with type `hidden`, whereas

```
$("#mydiv :input").not("[type='hidden']")
```

does not.

The documentation states these two queries should return same results, which they don't.

title: .then improperly propagates progress from locked-in Deferred
body:
When `.then` locks in a Deferred by rebinding to a thenable resolved by its base, progress context is inappropriately propagated as progress _data_, and progress data is in appropriately wrapped in an array. It's probably easier to explain in code than in natural language: https://jsfiddle.net/zwavzvpx/ .

This happens because `.notify` is used where `.notifyWith` belongs, at [deferred.js#L131](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/055cb7534e2dcf7ee8ad145be83cb2d74b5331c7/src/deferred.js#L131).

title: Remove default Deferred callback context
body:
I ran into an interesting obstacle when working on #3029: our longstanding behavior of using a default context for jQuery.Deferred callbacks (specifically, [the deferred's base promise](http://jsbin.com/tugocasose/edit?js,console)). It's not _necessarily_ a blocker, but it does make `$.when( $.Deferred().resolve() ).done( whatsMyContext )` very counterintuitive (in that I'm not even sure what to code for #3029). For sanity in that case—and for increased similarity with native Promises—I'd like to remove the default, making `*With` methods _required_ to provide a meaningful context. In other words, the preceding code would have either `undefined` or global object context, depending on whether or not it was executed in strict mode.

Any objections?

title: [req] modify $.fn.eq() to also accept an array?
Add `traditional` param to `.serialize()`
body:
As a result of gh-3030 we'll soon be properly ignoring `jQuery.ajaxSettings.traditional` in `jQuery.param()` as we said we did back in 1.8. The intent is to make `serialize.js` independent of ajax settings, which is good, but now there is no way for `.serialize()` to specify the `traditional` flag at all. Since it accepts no args at the moment, we could add `traditional` as an arg and pass it down to `jQuery.param()` that way. 

Ref https://github.com/jquery/jquery-migrate/issues/173

(Edited, `.serializeArray()` doesn't need changing)

title: Exposing filter pseudo functions for use with elements directly
body:
Very often I am wanting to get access to common pseudo methods such as:
`:focus`, `:selected`, `:checked` or `:empty` etc. for a single target element in an event callback.

For that, I currently have two options:
1. Either write my own code (duplicating jQuery's failsafe methods). Which seems redundant.
2. Wrap the element into jQuery and use the `$.fn.is(:peudo)` selector.

Both are however wasteful of resources. Given that those methods (taking a single element argument), are already in the code base. They have a legit case to be used directly. But they are not exposed...

Could they be exposed to an `$.is` set of functions as well. It would allow simple efficient checks like `$.is.focus(el)` without having to go through creating a new object and runs regex exprs needlessly?

title: Element which is not in page still :visible in IE8
body:
Hi, I'm having an issue with the `:visible`/`:hidden` check giving the wrong result in IE8 when the element under test isn't in the page. A simplified testcase is the following snippet: `$('
Test
').is(':visible')` In all browsers the result of this is `false` (because the element isn't in the page), except in IE8, for which it actually is `true`. From what I've investigated it seems like the issue is the final return of the `filterHidden` function: https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/1.12-stable/src/css/hiddenVisibleSelectors.js#L19 I think this must check if the resulting `node` is a document fragment. If it is a fragment the element can't be visible, and the result must thus be `true`. And there may possibly be different node types which could be the parent while the element isn't actually in the page, for which the test also returns the wrong result.
