title: .contents() returns empty object for inaccessible iframes in Firefox
Over event isn't propagated if nested droppable doesn't accept draggable under a certain scenario
body:
The steps below are applicable to the following jsFiddle, https://jsfiddle.net/deepankarj/60zz9zgb/.

**Steps:**
1. Click on and drag Draggable 1 onto the inner droppable of Droppable 3. Continue to hold Draggable 1, do not release it.
2. Note that when Draggable 1 is on the inner droppable and the pointer is fully over the area of Droppable 3, the outer Droppable 3 is highlighted, which is expected.
3. Move Draggable 1 beyond the bounds of Droppable 3 and release it so that it's resting entirely in whitespace.
4. Click and drag Draggable 2. You only have to drag it to some random whitespace spot, not on a droppable.
5. Release Draggable 2.
6. Grab Draggable 1 again and drag it onto the inner droppable of Draggable 3. Continue to hold Draggable 1, do not release it.
7. When Draggable 1 is on the inner droppable and the pointer is fully over the area of Droppable 3, take a note of the state of the outer Droppable 3 container.

**Expected results:**
- The outer Droppable 3 container is highlighted when Draggable 1 is entirely on the inner droppable and within the bounds of Droppable 3.

**Actual results:**
- The outer Droppable 3 container is not highlighted when Draggable 1 is entirely on the inner droppable and within the bounds of Droppable 3.

**Notes:**
- If you debug the issue, it turns out that simply dragging Draggable 2 results in some state changes in Droppable 3, such that event propagation no longer works as expected when Droppable 1 is on the inner droppable.
- Console logs have been added to this jsFiddle to help highlight this issue.

title: Shape of $.getJSON deferred changes depending on how it's used
body:
Let's say I have a deferred `json = $.getJSON('//someplace')`.

If I call `json.done` or `$.when(json).done`, I get just the data per http://api.jquery.com/jquery.getjson/.

If I call `$.when(json, $.Deferred().resolve()).done`, I get an array, of which the data is the first element per https://api.jquery.com/jquery.when/ (see the last example).

I don't think the shape should change depending on how it's used.  Please see http://jsbin.com/tewusix/1/edit?js,output for a clear example of how the shape changes.

title: $.when( deferred ).done() (serious?) regression
body:
This was [discussed on IRC](http://irc.jquery.org/%23jquery-dev/default_%23jquery-dev_20160328.log.html#t12:06:48) but it doesn't look like a code ticket was created. There is one for the docs at https://github.com/jquery/api.jquery.com/issues/904 because the example in `$.when()` is pretty bad, but the main problem is that `.done()` now gets an array instead of individual args.

Repro here: http://jsbin.com/civaxelixa/edit?html,console

Marking this as a blocker for the moment.

title: Invoke jQuery.ready callbacks without context
body: `jQuery.ready` callbacks are currently invoked with `document` context, but `this` is _soo_ 2014. [Promises/A+](https://promisesaplus.com/#point-35) and [ES2015](http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/6.0/#sec-promisereactionjob) Promises explicitly specify that `then` callbacks should be called without a `this` context. And although `jQuery.Deferred#*With` methods provide context to callbacks, we are moving in the direction of increased standards compliance, and should stop providing it in this case, especially since it will [soon be thenable](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/2891) itself.

title: Deprecate jQuery.fn.ready
body: Although [`jQuery.fn.ready`](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/dabd5ba96c05279b3ffb052db5b8d17f75996694/src/core/ready.js#L10-L16) has the form of a method, it doesn't use context—the following are all equivalent, and specifically equivalent to `jQuery( fn )`: - `jQuery().ready( fn )` - `jQuery( document ).ready( fn )` - `jQuery( "" ).ready( fn )` - `jQuery( document.body.lastChild ).ready( fn )` We should deprecate it in favor of `jQuery( fn )` and/or [`Promise.resolve( jQuery.ready )`/`jQuery.when( jQuery.ready )`/etc.](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/2891), furthering a trajectory that began with gh-2264.

title: Published jQuery versions should have `@VERSION` etc. replaced in `src/` as well
body: If someone uses our AMD modules in a published version, they shouldn't get `$.fn.version === "@VERSION"` but the true version instead. We should do the replacement not only in `dist/jquery.js` but also in `src/` (but only for published versions, not on regular `grunt` runs).

title: Cannot set `val()` for select options containing tabs (`\t`)
body:
I have a select element that contains options whose values contain tab characters. My original use case was a trailing tab (`string\t`), but I've also tested with leading tabs (`\tstring`) and tabs in the middle of non-whitespace (`str\ting`).

I called `.val('value with tab')` on the select element and expected the corresponding option to be selected since the values are identical, but no option is selected.

A few interesting observations:
- I can work around this issue for the leading and trailing cases by removing the leading or trailing tab characters from the string I pass to `.val()`, but this is unexpected since the values don't match exactly.
- Removing a middle tab character and passing that to `.val()` does not select the value, so there is no workaround for strings that have tab characters in the middle.
- The behavior is the same with jquery 2.2.1, 3.0.0-alpha1 and edge.
- With jquery 1.12.1, the leading and trailing tabs have the bug behavior but having a tab in the middle of the word and passing a matching string with a tab in the middle works as expected, so there was a regression at some point in this case.

JSFiddle: https://jsfiddle.net/onnucjx7/2/ You'll see in the console what I expect the behavior to be compared to what the behavior actually is. 

I searched for "tab" and "whitespace" and didn't see anything directly relevant; I did find this issue https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/1902 but it only mentions IE10 and I am seeing the unexpected behavior in Firefox 44 and Chrome 48.

title: Unintended/redundant onload event in 2.2/1.12
body:
I migrated from 2.1.4 to 2.2.1 and found a strange issue. Sorry, I can't provide a simple code to reproduce, but maybe you'll find out what's going on. Steps:
1. Open a jQuery-UI (1.10.4) dialog with a few tabs.
2. In one tab I have an upload form with hidden iframe. In more detail, the iframe is created ad-hoc on "Upload" button click. Something like:

```
$('<iframe>').attr(...).appendTo(document.body).on('load', {some:data}, onload_fn);
$(form).attr({target: frame_name, ...}).submit();
```
1. When I click the "Upload" button the form is submitted and all is fine, but...
2. When I then select any other tab the onload_fn is executed once again. Only once, switching tabs does not execute the onload again... until I create another iframe.

What's more the redundant event is also executed when I just close the dialog, so tabs may be not required to reproduce the issue.

title: Eliminate the intro/outro nuisance tickets
body:
Good news! The development best practice of using JSHint or ESLint to check source files is becoming a lot more common now.

Bad news! People are running JSHint and ESLint on jQuery source files and getting error messages on intro.js and outro.js since they are not actually complete files. Examples are #2747, #2819, #2953, and (I think based on Google Translate) #2971.

We should be able to fix this by changing the extension of those two files from `.js` to `.js_partial` or some such. That way they won't be linted by default and the name should provide a clue that they are not complete files.

title: $.parseHTML() creates anchor elements with empty href property in Chrome
body:
`document.implementation.createHTMLDocument("")`-created documents interpret the `href` property of anchor elements different in different browsers, e.g. in Chrome returning an empty string. This affects our `jQuery.parseHTML`. The `createHTMLDocument` usage has been backed out on `1.12-stable` & `2.2-stable` but we try to may make it work for 3.0.

In https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2941#issuecomment-190305062 @gibson042 suggested to create a `<base>` element, setting it to the base of the current document.

The original issue: 2941

title: e.stopPropagation is not a function in jQuery 2.2.x
body:
Since jQuery 2.2.0 I experience the following problem:

```
Uncaught TypeError: e.stopPropagation is not a function
jQuery.Event.stopPropagation @ jquery-2.2.1-ver-1456907236000.js:5020
jQuery.extend.Event.stop @ wicket-event-jquery-ver-1456907236000.js:193
jQuery.extend.Ajax._handleEventCancelation @ wicket-ajax-jquery-ver-1456907236000.js:1941
(anonymous function) @ wicket-ajax-jquery-ver-1456907236000.js:1995
fire @ jquery-2.2.1-ver-1456907236000.js:3182
....
```

It appears that JQuery.Event's originalEvent is not a native event but jQuery object (i.e. `function(selector, context)`).

I wasn't able to reproduce it in JSFiddle but I've deployed a simple application at http://jquery220-mgrigorov.rhcloud.com.
To reproduce it:
- open DevTools/Firebug, Console tab
- click HERE to open a modal window
- click Close button

If I set a breakpoint at jQuery.js line 5020 it works correctly - the event is MouseEvent.
But if I set a conditional breakpoint (`!e.stopPropagation`) then I see that the event is jQuery object and it throws the exception.

There is no such problem with jQuery 2.1.3 and 1.12.1.

I hope the provided information and demo application are enough to debug it!
Please let me know if I can provide more information!

title: License tags
body:
The jquery javascript files that users run should be tagged as free software so that people who want to run only free software on the web could do so. jQuery is free software might be free software but since it is not tagged as such you have to either allow all proprietary javascript as well or just not run jQuery.

LibreJS is a project by GNU to make it possible for those who want to run only free software on their browsers to only allow files that are free software.

http://www.gnu.org/software/librejs/
http://www.gnu.org/software/librejs/free-your-javascript.html

PS. The license file on jquery.org (and rest of the page for that matter) is completely unaccessible from Tor.

body:
Hi,

after this change https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/5943f1d7ffef41cc1a99bffe189f6d111fbccfd0 webpack builds are broken when loading individual modules:

`ERROR in ./~/jquery/src/selector-sizzle.js
Module not found: Error: Cannot resolve 'file' or 'directory' ../external/sizzle/dist/sizzle in /Users/berto/Temp/webpack-jquery/node_modules/jquery/src
 @ ./~/jquery/src/selector-sizzle.js 1:0-14:3`

I think this is happening because in 2.2.1 'selector-sizzle.js' is trying to load the sizzle dependency as '../external/sizzle/dist/sizzle' a file which does not exist, unlike in 2.2.0 (for instance) which loads 'sizzle'.

I set up a simple example here: https://github.com/bertez/webpack-jquery

```
npm install
npm run build
```

Thank you very much in advance.

title: .ajax() doesn't emit textStatus: 'timeout' error when a 504 Gateway Timeout occurred
body:
When 504 error occurred, callback `error`'s parameter `textStatus` is just an **`'error'`**.
(prototype: `error: function( jqXHR jqXHR, String textStatus, String errorThrown )` )

`textStatus` should be `'timeout'` according to the RFC2616's description for 504 error. Though there's some conflicts when I try to comprehend how jQuery.ajax() should do when there's a gateway timeout in [jQuery API documentation](http://api.jquery.com/jQuery.ajax/):

> #### error
> 
> Type: Function( jqXHR jqXHR, String textStatus, String errorThrown )
> A function to be called if the request fails. The function receives three arguments: The jqXHR (...) object, **a string describing the type of error that occurred** and an optional exception object, if one occurred. Possible values for the second argument (besides `null`) are **`"timeout"`**, `"error"`, `"abort"`, and `"parsererror"`. When an HTTP error occurs, `errorThrown` receives the textual portion of the HTTP status, such as "Not Found" or "Internal Server Error." As of jQuery 1.5, ... . Note: This handler is not called for cross-domain ... .

`504 Gateway Timeout` error usually occurs when it use a long-time-pending request to wait for some events but there's a **proxy / reverse proxy**, especially reverse proxy such as _nginx vhost_. That means: once the proxy configuration of gateway set a smaller timeout limit than the browser or ajax's `timeout`option, never a `timeout` error can get.

Here's part of [RFC2616 Hypertext Transfer Protocol -- HTTP/1.1](https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html#sec10.5.5) for reference.

> ### 10.5.5 504 Gateway Timeout
> 
> The server, while acting as a gateway or proxy, did not receive a timely response from the upstream server specified by the URI (e.g. HTTP, FTP, LDAP) or some other auxiliary server (e.g. DNS) it needed to access in attempting to complete the request.
> 
> ```
>   Note: Note to implementors: some deployed proxies are known to
>   return 400 or 500 when DNS lookups time out.
> ```

title: Tag-like attribute values modified by .html(htmlString)
body: If you use tag-like text in attribute value via `.html(htmlString)`, it gets improperly modified. Example: ``` javascript $element.html(''); ``` you get ``` html a ``` instead of expected ``` html a ``` produced by `.innerHTML`. (According to [HTML5 specification](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/syntax.html#syntax-attribute-value) tag-like values seem to be fine – only ambiguous ampersands have to be escaped.)

title: Removing parent node during event bubbling doesn't have the same result as pure javascript code
body:
In the following code, clicking the button triggers a form submission in Google Chome 48.

``` html
<form>
    <button>ok</button>
</form>
<script>
$(function(){
    $('form').submit(false) ;
    $('button').click(function(){ $('form').remove() }) ;
}) ;
</script>
```

However, the same test case without using jQuery does not trigger a form submission.

``` html
<form onsubmit="return false">  
    <button onclick="form.remove()">ok</button>
</form>
```

**What's the expected behavior?**
Both examples should be functionally equivalent.

**Browsers affected:** Google Chrome 48
**jQuery version tested:** jQuery 2.2

Also tested in Firefox 43, but the problem does not happen there.

title: e.preventDefault() is undefined
The husky lint git hook is vulnerable to PATH changes
body: The linter git hook added in d94c4539796d02dd0f54e9a3417b660195b844b0 has a significant fault; it creates a pre-commit file where PATH is hard-coded to the one at the end of initial `npm install` (subsequent `npm install`s don't update it). This poses a problem for tools like [nvm](https://github.com/creationix/nvm) where after removing an older Node version (e.g. when a new patch release comes out you might want to remove the older one to not keep vulnerable & outdated releases on the disk) the previous PATH stops being valid, the hook stops working and packages need to be re-installed.

title: Don't manually lowercase attribute name passed to `setAttribute`
body: In #2730 we changed the lowercasing logic of the `.attr()` setter to better conform to the spec (we were lowercasing too much) but we had to lowercase at all only because of IE<9. We don't need that logic in `3.0` and removing it may even "accidentally" make this API sort-of work on SVGs (see #2910) so why not.

title: Absolutely positioned inline elements become block-level after using hide() and show()
body:
Test case: [http://codepen.io/anon/pen/rxqzKO](http://codepen.io/anon/pen/rxqzKO)

As the test case shows, even when an inline element has display: inline explicitly stated in the css, after using hide() before show(), jQuery sets it to display: block. This happens only on elements with position:absolute.

I reproduced the bug in the following environments:
Chrome 48.0.2564.97/OS X 10.11.3
Firefox 42/OS X 10.11.3
Firefox 44/OS X 10.11.3
Opera 35/OS X 10.11.3
Firefox 44/Windows 7
Edge 12/Windows 10

The bug did not occur in IE 9/Windows 7, IE 10/Windows 8, or IE 11/Windows 10 (I did not test any other Internet Explorer versions).

The bug also occured using jQuery Core 1.12.0.

If you're debugging a site with 1.9.1 from the CDN, suddenly 1.11.1 is in your debugger... which is wrong.

Here's some context from jquery-dev chatting with @dmethvin:

title: Ignore Sizzle working with AMD modules
.offset() adds scrollTop to the top coordinate (only in IE and jQuery 1.12.0 and 2.2.0)
body:
## Context

I'm a collaborator in the [jQuery UI Month Picker](https://kidsysco.github.io/jquery-ui-month-picker/) project.

Recently we've setup a demo page where we've used the latest compat version of jQuery (1.12.0).

The plugin allows the user to click a button that uses the jQuey UI [.position()](https://jqueryui.com/position/) method to position a menu under an input field.

As [demonstrated in this page](https://benjamin-albert.github.io/jquery-ui-month-picker/jquery-bug.html), everything worked fine except for **Internet Explorer** which seems to positions the menu as far below the input as you scrolled.

**IMPORTANT**: This only happens the **first time** after you position an element, but you can reproduce the issue by refreshing the page.
## What have I tried

At first I thought this had something to do with the jQuery UI version (1.11.4) we were using, but switching to several different versions of jQuery UI didn't solve the issue.

Then I tried to use jQuery version 1.11.3 and everything is working fine even in IE.

I than tried version 1.9.1 (which we run [our tests](https://github.com/KidSysco/jquery-ui-month-picker#month-picker-development-kit) against) and once again everything worked find.

I also tried a different version 1.9.2 of jQuery UI with jQuery 1.9.1 and everything worked fine.

Then I tried to use jQuery version 2.2.0 and one again everyting was working fine except for IE.
## What's going on in the code

When the user clicks the button the [Open() method](https://github.com/KidSysco/jquery-ui-month-picker/blob/c4ce4d6ae9cf2d7a079e809e627c1bf9af40d1bc/MonthPicker.js#L567) in our code is called.

The open method calls the [.fadeToggle()](http://api.jquery.com/fadetoggle/#fadeToggle-options) method using the `start` callback option.

The start callback is called right after the `dispaly:none` is removed and right before the animation begins (which as mentioned in the [jQuery ui .position() docs](http://api.jqueryui.com/position/) is **required** for it to work).

[Our start callback](https://github.com/KidSysco/jquery-ui-month-picker/blob/c4ce4d6ae9cf2d7a079e809e627c1bf9af40d1bc/MonthPicker.js#L775) calls jQuery UI's .position() method, which [eventually will call elem.offset({...})](https://github.com/jquery/jquery-ui/blob/cb69f0025f257c28ac3be39c4269373a9fa74002/ui/position.js#L336).

Eventually the [jQuery.offset.setOffset()](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/29370190605ed5ddf5d0371c6ad886a4a4b5e0f9/src/offset.js#L35) method calls `elem.offset()` to get the elements offset.

Eventually the `elem.offset()` method calls [rect = elem.getBoundingClientRect();](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/29370190605ed5ddf5d0371c6ad886a4a4b5e0f9/src/offset.js#L101) which seems to add `scrollTop` to the top property return by `.getBoundingClientRect();`.
## TLDR

I'm not sure if the problem is a result of us doing something wrong which just happens to work in every different configuration we've tested, or is this an issue with jQuery that needs to be resolved.

title: Consider emitting named event when DOM manipulations occur.
body: My apologies if this is not the proper forum to submit a potential feature request.  Older browsers do not support some/all of the mutation events.  It would be helpful if jQuery core emitted an event when the DOM has been manipulated.  That way we can subscribe to that event and react to dom structures being added/removed.  This might be similar to the functionality of `$.fn.live` which was deprecated.  So I also understand if there are performance concerns related to this. Thoughts?

body:
Not sure if this is a bug per se, as I think it's technically a syntax error, but on the release notes for jQuery 2.2.0 it say it is not expected to have any breaking changes so I thought I would report this in case.

So, I have this line:

```
var a = $("a[href*=#]:not([href=#])");
```

This line works fine on 2.1.4, but throws this error on 2.2.0:

```
Syntax error, unrecognized expression: a[href*=#]:not([href=#])
```

Quoting the values in the attribute selectors fixes this (i.e. `[href*='#']`). But as I said, I'm not sure if this is an intended fix or a regression.

title: New feature .reattach()
body:
Hi :)

Why not creating a `.reattach` methode?
So this: `jqElement.detach().reattach()` will change nothing.

It's will more easier to cancel a `.detach()` operation (eg. drag and drop).
And it can be use everytime like this:

``` javascript
jqCollection
    .detach()
    .css( { prop:values, ... } )
    .toggleClass( "a b c" )
    ...
    .reattach()
;
```

to accelerate the traitement, faster than `.css( "display", "none|block" )`.

To avoid any bug we can save the next sibling (to use the native `insertBefore`) **and** the parent in case if there was no next element or if it's deleted, to allow some usecase like:

``` javascript
jqCollection
    .detach()
    .parent()
        .empty()
        .end()
    .reattach()
;
```

title: JSDOM $.event.trigger does not trigger keyboard events
Consider adding support for passive event listeners
body:
Blink has [shipped](https://www.chromestatus.com/features/5718574840676352) support for [EventListenerOptions](https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#dictdef-eventlisteneroptions) and we expect to soon [ship](https://www.chromestatus.com/features/5745543795965952) support for the [passive option](https://github.com/RByers/EventListenerOptions/blob/gh-pages/explainer.md).

Ideally jquery users would be able to mark event listeners as passive, so they can get the same performance benefits.  Also @scottgonzalez mentions it would be good for jquery to polyfill the capturing API as well.

Thoughts?  Feel free to file any issues / questions with the spec [here](https://github.com/RByers/EventListenerOptions/issues).

title: Document that $('.foo').append(document.createTextNode('bar')) is a supported use case
body:
The documentation says append() accepts:
- string
- Element
- jQuery collection

The problem is there's no official way to append a text _node_ in jQuery. Using append() with a text node works just fine, but Text is not an instance of Element, it's an instance of its parent prototype, Node.

This echoes in other tools and definitions like Definitely Typed's jQuery TypeScript .d.ts definition, where the TypeScript compiler throws an error when I'm appending a text node.

Please fix this in the documentation so it can trickle downstream into our tooling. Thanks :-)

title: Commit to how disconnected elements toggle
body:
Ref https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2404#issuecomment-172993424 `.toggle()` uses the newly-renamed `isHiddenWithinTree` to determine whether a `.show()` or `.hide()` is called for, and effects methods use it to determine if they should invoke a preliminary `.show()`. But since `isHiddenWithinTree` does not yet perform exactly as advertised, _all_ disconnected elements are treated as hidden. In code, `jQuery( "
" ).find( "*" ).addBack().toggle()` locks in inline `defaultDisplay` values for both elements, as does `$visible.detach().toggle().appendTo( inPageParent )`. This is counterintuitive to me, _especially_ when it comes to element descendants like the above ``. I'd propose updating `isHiddenWithinTree` to use only inline display values when evaluating disconnected elements. Other possibilities include a) treating elements differently by parent (document or element vs. document fragment or null)—please no, and b) keeping everything as-is. But no matter what, we should either add unit tests asserting the consensus decision, or document that disconnected elements are invalid context for the methods.

title: Remove right-hand side specificity recommendation
body:
In http://learn.jquery.com/performance/optimize-selectors/ you say:

"Be specific on the right-hand side of your selector, and less specific on the left."

I've opened a thread on SO: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34923710/selectors-be-specific-on-right-hand-side

and done some benchmarks. Basically, in modern browsers supporting queryselectorall, as far as I'm aware, the Sizzle engine is not used for processing the selector. And the way modern browsers, unlike Sizzle, evaluate selectors is left-to-right. Thus being specific on the right-hand side can hurt rather than help performance. The right-hand side should be treated with the same rules as the left-hand side, having less specificity.

Correct me if I'm wrong.

title: Drop support for jsdom on Node<4 completely
body:
We currently have a [wonky logic](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/fe05cf37ffd4795988f9b2343df2182e108728ca/Gruntfile.js#L18-L28) for installing a new jsdom and only testing on version 3 manually, if installed, on older Node.js (0.10 & 0.12). The problem is, jsdom has now bug that makes our whole DOM manipulation basically completely broken (see https://github.com/tmpvar/jsdom/issues/717) so it doesn't make much sense to test on it, even manually (especially that it's so easy to miss it before a release).

IMO we should drop support for old jsdom versions in 3.0.0.

title: $(elem).css("property", "value !important") fails, without any feedback
body:
This bug was previously reported as [11173](https://bugs.jquery.com/ticket/11173) which was closed as wontfix, however as [this Stack Overflow question and comment demonstrates](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2655925/how-to-apply-important-using-css/11723492#comment27272643_2655925), the recommended "workaround" in the bug ticket doesn't actually work because the test case used is incorrect. Furthermore, as per [comment 3](https://bugs.jquery.com/ticket/11173#comment:3) on the bug, the documentation is incorrect.

The Stack Overflow question has numerous answers that allow `!important` to be used in this context, but they are either very verbose or very hacky. `!important` is a very, well, important feature that should be natively supported by jQuery's `.css()` function.

title: Firefox: don't set e.relatedTarget to null on focusout
body:
On `focusout` event object, the `relatedTarget` property tells which element is obtaining the focus.
In Chrome, `relatedTarget === null` only when no other element obtains the focus (a click on the page background).

Firefox doesn't have a focusout event, so it is faked by jQuery. But the `relatedTarget` is not well set by jQuery: it is always set to `null`.

A better solution would be to set `relatedTarget` to:
- `null` only when we know that no other element obtains the focus
- `undefined` when we can't know if or which element obtains the focus

This way, when `relatedTarget === undefined`, we are either in an old browser that has not a complete implementation of the `focusout` event (like Safari 5.1), or we are in a faked event that cannot tell which element obtains the focus.
And when `relatedTarget === null`, we can be certain that a `focusout` event has happened but no other element is obtaining the focus.

JSFiddle where you can test the values of `e.relatedTarget`: [jQuery bug: focusout relatedTargetset to null](https://jsfiddle.net/jlgrall/eoa2bwcd/)

title: jQuery 2.2.0 has error from jQuery UI 1.11.4
Don't use detached tags & don't add built files to those tags
body:
We now use the [jquery-dist](https://github.com/jquery/jquery-dist) repo to publish jQueries with proper build artifacts. We should update the release script to:
1. No longer include those artifacts in the tag in the main repo.
2. To tag a commit on the main branch, not create a detached one.

The first point will be more important in the future when, as @dmethvin pointed, we'll have more build artifacts (e.g. when transpiling from ES6 modules). The second one is just confusing for users as you don't fetch detached tags by default so they're not visible in that case. Because of that, ESLint changed their release script to avoid detached tags. They were only used here to add build artifacts but since that's no longer needed the tag doesn't have to be detached as well.

title: Chaining .on() broken for null handlers in jQuery 2.2.0 (inconsistency with 1.12.0)
body:
It looks like a bug was introduced in jquery 2.2.0 with the 'on' function.

If you have code that registers a bunch of handlers in a chain and one of the callbacks is null, the on function will return the window object when the callback is null which causes the chaining to fail.  This works with jquery 2.1.4.  After a little investigation, it looks like the 'on' method was refactored to be global within jquery's scope and returns this (which used to be the jquery object but now is window).

//example from jquery impromptu plugin
$('.selector').on("keydown",keyDownEventHandler)
                        .on('impromptu:loaded', opts.loaded)
                        .on('impromptu:close', opts.close)
                        .on('impromptu:statechanging', opts.statechanging)
                        .on('impromptu:statechanged', opts.statechanged);

title: unquoted attr selector throws error
body:
This line is throwing an error after updating from 2.1.4 to 2.2.0.

`$('a[href*=#]:not([href=#])');`

This is due to the attribute selector not being encased in quotes. i.e this fixes the error:

`$('a[href*="#"]:not([href="#"])');`

Not sure if this is expected but this is supposed to be a non-breaking release.

I do realize that the first example (which throws the error) is not correct syntax, based on [the jQuery docs](https://api.jquery.com/category/selectors/attribute-selectors/), but not sure if this is supposed to throw an error. I'm assuming a graceful degradation is preferred over an error which ultimately stops further Javascript execution.

title: Tripple negation and text nodes
body:
A while back, A.Wolff found an inconsistency in jQuery and posted it on StackOverflow.
I thought A.Wolff would submit this issue, but I can't find he did, so here it is:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34593399/triple-negation-needed-to-retrieve-text-node/34598245

In short; non-element (e.g. text) nodes in recursive `:not(*)` (and probably other) pseudo-selectors are treated differently for `.filter()` and `.not()`.

I dug into the issue and found the cause. I'm not sure whether to consider this a bug or not, but there is an easy fix (in the answer) to make it atleast consistent. The cost of the fix is quite low.

title: $(window).scroll(function () { ... }) vs $(window).on('scroll', function () { ... }) are not equivalent
body:
Contrary to what the [jQuery `.scroll()` documentation states](https://api.jquery.com/scroll/):

> This method is a shortcut for `.on( "scroll", handler )` in the first and second variations...

`$(window).scroll(function () { ... })` is not directly equivalent to `$(window).on('scroll', function () { ... }` as can be [seen in this jsfiddle](http://jsfiddle.net/ba58kL9j/6/).

The documentation should be updated with info on this edge case.

title: Deprecate jQuery.parseJSON
body: `jQuery.parseJSON` was needed for IE<8 & Android 2.3, apart from that it was kept on both branches mostly so that we're API-compatible between them. Those reasons are no longer valid on `master` so IMO we should deprecate this method and switch all internal uses to `JSON.parse`. We could then remove it in 4.0.

title: MutationObserver fiering twice when using .html()
body:
I found the html method firing two MutationObserver Events. I think "cleanData" and/or "empty" are causing the first event on removal, and, the second event occures due to "append" and/or "innerHTML" beeing called!?

**I think this is undermining the MutationObserver's basic idea to have only ONE event when a bunch of DOM-changes take place, right!?**

Is is technically possible to do these actions in one go?

Architectural considerations: Well, I am inbetween two chairs. Personally, I need to hook into both, the add- and removal- event of a certain container, currently replaced by the html method. I was expection only one MutationObserver Event. I think technically it would be nice to distigusih between these actions. So, what's the current way to do so!? That is reliable? Are there any plans to make jquery distingush DOM add- and removal- events based on MutationObservers? As far as I can see, there are no MutationObservers used in jquery at all!?

Regards.
O.B.

title: closest: remove exception for pos selectors
body:
Further discussion here:  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34580013/jquery-closest-default-context

The documentation for closest states: 

>  If no context is passed in then the context of the jQuery set will be used instead.

However, it seems that this is often not the case.  You can see this illustrated here:

https://jsfiddle.net/pjbg4398/

When the context is passed explicitly, closest works as expected and only finds an element if it is within the context element.  However, if the jquery set has a context and closest is called without explicitly passing a context, no context is used (contradicting the documentation).  However, if the selector passed to closest contains non-css selectors (gt, eq, etc.), then the set's context **is** used.

I believe the fix should be to change the loop condition as follows:

>  for (cur = this[i]; cur && **cur !== context**; cur = cur.parentNode) {

should become:

>  for (cur = this[i]; cur && **cur !== (context || this.context)**; cur = cur.parentNode) {

which would be in line with the non-css code which does a similar thing with context:

>  pos = rneedsContext.test(selectors) || typeof selectors !== "string" ? jQuery(selectors, **context || this.context**) : 0;

title: Stop appending `px` to everything except a blacklist?
body:
We're currently appending `px` when using the `.css()` setter if the value given is numeric and the CSS property is not on the [`jQuery.cssNumber` blacklist](http://api.jquery.com/jQuery.cssNumber/).

From https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/2793#issuecomment-167990441:

>  This is a mess, we're adding more & more stuff to this array and it'll always be a problem as CSS is expanding. I'd like to get rid of this `px`-appending but it might be too big a breaking change.
> 
> This is probably too late for 3.0 but how about switching the blacklist to a whitelist? If jQuery doesn't append `px` for you it's easier to fix by yourself than if it does append erroneously. My guess would be 99% of the uses are common properties like `(min-|max-|)(height|width)` or `top`, `left` etc. We could identify those most popular ones and append `px` only to them. Migrate could restore the previous behavior but warn if someone passes a numeric value to properties that are not on the current blacklist.

title: css('animation-iteration-count', 5) doesn't apply style to element
body:
When I use `css('animation-iteration-count', 5)` I expect element has `style="-webkit-animation-iteration-count: 5;"` (this vendor prefix is just a example), but it doesn't.

So I debug jQuery.js, I found when I use `css('animation-iteration-count', 5)` actually become `style[ 'WebkitAnimationIterationCount' ] = 5 + 'px'`.
Browser consider it a illegal value, because `animation-iteration-count` only accept `infinite | <number>`, so this style don't have effect.

This is a [reproduceBug demo](http://output.jsbin.com/gupugawibe)

So that `cssNumber` shoud add `animationIterationCount` property to prevent automatically add "px" to the value.

title: undefine jquery in AMD environment when noConflict is called
body:
Hi

**Scenario:**

An app is using requireJS for dependency management. Also its using a nonAMD jquery plugin that needs `jQuery` on window to work which it specifies as dependency in the requireJS config. The app has a tracking script (say crazyegg) installed too that loads its own jquery, but in noconflict mode.

**Issue:**

Reduced testcase demo: http://plnkr.co/edit/6nxWaGnRHo6xRTiGQQBq?p=preview
- The tracking script loads and executes. It registers "jquery" with requireJS but no `jQuery` or `$` on window is put as its in noconflict mode. All good.
- requireJS loads our jquery plugin. But since it has a dependency on _jquery_, it tries to load _jquery_ first.
- But requireJS already has a _jquery_ registered with it (which tracking script did) and so it does nothing. No additional jquery is loaded (which should have).
- Now the plugin is loaded and since it expected `jQuery` on window and its not there, it breaks.

**Solutions:**
- `noConflict` method should also unregister _jquery_ in the AMD environment. Makes sense because noconflict is meant to remove any traces that the jquery library leaves on the website environment its loaded on.

OR
- Give another method for AMD noConflict which users can call separately.

If the jquery team agrees on either approach, I can take this issue up.

`$audio.trigger('play')` invokes `playCallback` twice
body:
Reposted from [My stackoverflow post](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/33670514/why-audio-triggerplay-fires-playhandler-twice-while-audio0-play). There is no satisfactory answer and **I DO THINK THIS MAKES CODE BUG-PRONE** so I repost it here.

I used to think `trigger(play)` just fires the native `play` function of audio, but today I just noticed that there is a slight difference between these two methods. If you register a callback for `play`, e.g. `$('audio').on('play', function() { console.log('playing'); })`, the callback will be invoked twice if you use `trigger(play)` but only once when using `play()`.
- How come this discrepancy?
- Is this as expected? I expect `trigger('play')` to behave exactly the same as `play`.
- Is it possible to make `trigger(play)` only fires the `play callback` once, so as to keep potential bugs away?

[[demo]](https://jsfiddle.net/Richard_Liu/gttde0p0/)

---

In the demo, I call `trigger('play')` and `trigger('pause')` and then `play()` and `pause()`. The result is 

```
// the following four lines are generated by trigger calls
play 
play
pause
pause
// the following two lines are generated by native calls
play
pause
```

This demo could illustrate what I'm talking about.

This problem could be reproduced on:
- Chrome version 46.0.2490.86 m
- IE 11.0.9600.18053
- FireFox 42.0

---

One example problem is:
I want to `addClass` on a button in the `playCallback` and `removeClass` in the `playingCallback`. When the audio is already playing,
- If `audio.play()` is called, neither `playCallback` nor `playingCallback` will be invoked.
- If `$audio.trigger('play')` is called, the `playCallback` will be invoked ONCE and the `playingCallback` is not invoked. This is an unexpected behavior.

title: 7 Traversing Unit Tests, suddenly failing in Microsoft Edge.
body:
It appears something has changed in the master branch of JQuery, that is causing the following unit tests to fail when run in Microsoft Edge

_"traversing: find(String)"_
_"traversing: find(String) under non-elements"_
_"traversing: find(leading combinator)"_
_"traversing: find(node|jQuery object)"_
_"traversing: is(String|undefined)"_
_"traversing: is(jQuery)"_
_"traversing: is() with :has() selectors"_

All of the failures give the following message: `Died on test #1    at Global code (/jquery/test/unit/traversing.js:234:1): Permission denied`

When running tests for  **all modules** from the master branch in the last week of November, all of the above tests pass.

However, when running tests for **all modules** from the master branch on December 4th all of the above tests fail.

Both times I used the same build of Windows 10 and with the Same Build of Microsoft Edge, so the change appears to be coming from JQuery

**Note** that these tests do not fail when run in isolation, or when just running the "traversal" module. Instead it appears they are dependent on the failure of test:
_"selector: Iframe dispatch should not affect jQuery"_ 

This test was failing previously in Microsoft Edge as well, however now when it fails, the traversing tests that follow it also fail as well.

title: myForm.trigger('submit') when form contains an element named "submit"
body:
If you try to do something like: `<input type="submit" name="submit">`
(I see coders doing this all the time, they're unoriginal and can't think of a better name for a submit button than "submit" so bare with me, I think it would be good to address such users)

Then when calling `myForm.trigger('submit')` for the form which contains this element, it will fail to submit in the same way which `myForm.submit()` fails since it will reference the element rather than the submit function of the form. I believe jQuery should add a check when dealing with "submit" to verify it's indeed a function before calling it. If not, you can still submit the form by grabbing a copy of the function by creating a new form dynamically, grabbing its submit method, then sending the form we want to submit through this function:
`document.createElement('form').submit.call(myForm)`
We could also try to do something like `myForm.constructor.prototype.submit`... but then they might have an element named "constructor" in their form resulting in the same sort of issue. So I believe creating an element for it would be a good solution to grab the submit method and apply it to the function we wish to submit.

title: jQuery 1.* IE6 XHR custom fields
.trigger( "multiple events triggering" )
body:
Hi :)

We can do this :

``` javascript
$( "body" ).on( "mousedown touchstart", function() { /* ... */ } );
```

But not this :

``` javascript
$( "body" ).trigger( "mousedown touchstart" );
```

We have to call `.trigger` **N** times.

``` javascript
$( "body" )
    .trigger( "mousedown" )
    .trigger( "touchstart" )
;
```

Why not calling `.match( rnotwhite )` on the event string?

title: outerWidth() documentation possibly incorrect
body:
According to [outerWidth docs](http://api.jquery.com/outerwidth/#outerWidth-includeMargin):

"The value reported by .outerWidth() is not guaranteed to be accurate when the element or its parent is hidden. To get an accurate value, ensure the element is visible before using .outerWidth(). **jQuery will attempt to temporarily show and then re-hide an element in order to measure its dimensions, but this is unreliable and (even when accurate) can significantly impact page performance. This show-and-rehide measurement feature may be removed in a future version of jQuery.**"

Looking at the jQuery 1.11.3 source, I see no specific show/hide behaviour for `outerWidth()`. Is that functionality still there, or has it been removed? My own tests suggest that this is not happening, but I wanted to check to make sure.

title: Issue with node-strophe module
Map method is flattening arrays
.html doesn't return dynamically created markup as expected
body:
This seems like unexpected behaviour to me, but let me know if I'm mistaken:

http://jsfiddle.net/0986gj4h/

I traced it to a couple different things: The dynamically created markup ends up being an array of elements, then in .html `this[0]` is referenced, which only refers to the first element in the array, hence the inner html for only the first element is returned.

Seems like there are a few ways to fix this: check if this.length > 0 and then either return the outer html for each element in the array (not very nice), or create a fake element (div for example) append `this` to the element and return that inner html (nicer, but still not that great), or possibly something else I'm not thinking of? I'm not too familiar with all the code around this, so I'm sure I'm missing some edge case scenario.

I'm able to workaround this issue through other means, just thought it seemed odd.

title: Nodes created by src/css/support.js can break the DOM in some PhantomJS environments.
body:
jQuery inserts a [`div`](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/487d5ca913c237aafe9efa1179749b46382fddbf/src/css/support.js#L10) into the DOM on page load which is appended to `html`. This element is subsequently removed but the DOM is in an invalid state in the interim since `div` tags are not valid outside of the `body`. This is an issue for web crawlers using PhantomJS as the results of the html may be recorded before the element has been removed, resulting in broken html.

We are experiencing this issue with our single page app at https://househappy.org. When a crawler visits the site, PhantomJS loads the requested page and served the generated html to the crawler. To reproduce, spoof your user agent string to `Googlebot/2.1 (+http://www.googlebot.com/bot.html)` and visit the site. Using your browser's developer tools to inspect the DOM, you can see that all of the tags (`meta` et. al) that belong in the `head` are nested within the `body`. Looking at the source, we can see the culprit is a rogue `div` inserted after `html`. Using `MutationObserver` and `debugger`, I have pinpointed it to the `div` appended by jQuery.

Appending it to the `body` will not maintain compatibility with all environments (in my tests, `body` doesn't always exist when this element is appended). Most crawlers allow you to blacklist elements by selector but I have not had luck in this case (`html > div` should work, but doesn't?). My suggestion is to add a discrete selector to this element to allow it to be easily blacklisted. I am thinking of submitting a PR to address this issue, using a data attribute as a selector (supported by PhantomJS as well as IE7+, avoids collisions with IDs / classes that may be in the wild).

Let me know if you have any thoughts (or if this issue is even worth addressing).

title: Add unhandled exception notices for Deferred
body:
Right now, if there is an exception in a `.then()` it is silently swallowed.  I don't think we should ship 3.0.0 with that behavior.

http://jsbin.com/bodevaqive/edit?js,console

Maybe a `console.warn` message? We may end up yelling about rejections that might have been dealt with by a handler attached later in time. 

One possible tradeoff would be to only generate the console warnings for errors that seem to be programming mistakes such as `TypeError` or `ReferenceError`. That prevents the really bad mistakes such as the example above with a typo in a function name.

For more complex cases we could recommend that people use native Promise if it's consistently available across their supported platforms, since it will be easier to debug.

title: Package Distribution Ignores Build Dependencies (.npmignore)
body:
This may be an edge case issue, or a even non-issue, but I'd love to hear your thoughts!

Required build dependencies are being ignored based on the `.npmignore` file. The following commits contribute to this change: 35f8e15fd73256ec02397d7bf93893e38afc9bc9 and b04b3861802606a114c936e753c0f20da6e8b236.

Currently, I'm relying on the `npm` published package for a module. As it stands right now, the distributed package cannot be re-built (module exclusion) as the various required files are being ignored – I'm looking to make `grunt custom:-deprecated,-effects,...` a `postinstall` hook. 

It seems the current solution would be to include `jquery` as a `git submodule` and building, which _works_, it just feels a little dirty (...blame the package managers for this one. :wink:)

It's also worth pointing out that I'm bundling for the browser – so the exclusion of modules/file size has some effect.

Thanks!

title: 2.2 Release progress
body:
Instead of porting bug fixes to `2.2-stable` branch i decided to go with opposite way - reverting back-incompat commits.

I tried more conventional approach at first (and another three too), but it proved (to me) to be ineffective. Since there was a lot more conflicts then with chosen approach which were prompted by the use of the new QUnit API and style fixes.

Below, you find three lists, one of the reverted commits and one of the questionable commits that are in `2.2-stable` and are back-compat, but might be inappropriate for this release. And also list of reverted commits which requires special attention.

I would expect from reviewers to check those lists and current state of the branch, verifying that API doesn't include new features, don't break back-compat and done overall correctly.

Processed commits started from Oct 30, 2014.
### Questionable commits

Drop support for Opera 12.x, Firefox<29, Safari<6.0 and old Blackberry
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/740e190223d19a114d5373758127285d14d6b71e

Callbacks module change, considered as a bug
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/89ce0af2cf7f001647e74fc1de92ce94a51fd5c2

Hides `jQuery.swap`
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/bb4d888f4f7886371347b59eae5d4e6135acb7ed

Adds `jQuery.htmlPrefilter` - allowed by the semver for the minor version,
but might be inappropriate for this release, also not documented.
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/225bde37c997f5ddd9fe00fdfb8e9a43545cfbbc

Changes signature of the `jQuery#init`, needed for the Migrate (/cc @dmethvin)
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/7a6931de689865f559bed26e797e8cbb5674bbce

Adds `jQuery.uniqueSort`, deprecates `jQuery.unique` - allowed by the semver for the minor version, but might be not contracdict 2.2 release, also not documented.
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/e1090c3d2b2a988a5b41f1f1ed9f8d6dcae02200

Hides `jQuery.domManip`
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/62d5579578109f1468a37e44f76af06f283a46ab

Hides `jQuery.buildFragment`
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/a74320fca8bb0a2190f6e1fdb71a73733b6986e4

Changes signature (remove additional param) of `jQuery.event.simulate` couldn't find docs for it, if documented is not acceptable change for the minor
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/3655c4e1908cc3ee49487e7e26e8cfca9fe8146d

Hides `jQuery.acceptData`
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/224271982eb9cd351d7db1b38c740b4e927e6f97

Hides `jQuery.dir` and `jQuery.sibling`
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/f9ef427d355a8a2b531aed5d112dfa4f9692105c

Even though subject of the commit reads "Adding unit tests for jQuery.Animation"
There was changes in logic and interface of the `effects` module (/cc @gnarf)
https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commit/b3b2d6c3dd51fbdc69e1942e9af75cc99a1834c2
### Reverted commits

title: selected option changes in IE after forward/back button
body:
In IE (confirmed in 9+), after detaching a non-selected option from a select dropdown and navigating to another page and back (e.g. click forward then back buttons), the selected option changes.

In the test case below, "3 selected" should be selected.  However, in IE9+, navigate away from the page and back, then 1 will be selected instead of 3.  FF and Chrome do not have this problem.

Test case:

``` html
<!DOCTYPE html><html lang="en">
<head><meta charset="UTF-8">
    <title>select-option-detach IE/jquery bug</title>
</head>
<body>
<script src="//code.jquery.com/jquery-1.11.3.min.js"></script>
<select>
    <option value="1">1 not selected</option>
    <option value="2">2 not selected</option>
    <option value="3" selected>3 selected</option>
</select>
<script type="text/javascript">
    $(function(){
        $('option').eq(1).detach();
    })
</script>
</body></html>
```

title: Android 2.3 basic tests time out
body:
Android 2.3 basic tests on master time out: http://swarm.jquery.org/job/1684. OTH, the jQuery 1.12/2.2 tests are mostly working: http://swarm.jquery.org/job/1685. This is even though we now no longer load other test files than `basic.js` when testing the `basic` module. Perhaps there's a problem with source.

When I joined the swarm with a local emulator running on x86 instead of the ARM emulator, it passed: http://swarm.jquery.org/job/1654. But that doesn't help maintaining it.

There are lots of problems with Android 2.3 testing and apparently even just running basic tests is problematic. Restarting those jobs doesn't help, they just don't work with the BrowserStack Android 2.3 version. I'd prefer to just drop Android 2.3 completely in jQuery 3.0.0 but since no one else except @markelog thinks the same (well, except Mobile folks that are dropping it completely; am I right, @arschmitz?), how about we remove it from the periodic run and just add a note to the release process at https://github.com/jquery/jquery/wiki/Release-process that before a release one has to fire up a local Android 2.3 emulator & run basic tests? The TestSwarm job is useless anyway as it stands.

Not sure if it is open yet, but could you please do not dumb overwrite $.fn ?
It is very bad if the jQuery object gets overwritten and all registered plugins are gone.

Some CMS plugins using jQuery and they do not use $.noConflict() and maybe overwriting each other. For example they include code from a CDN and all registered plugins before are gone forever.

title: JQuery 2.4.1 async problem
body:
This is apparently an old issue, but there's a new wrinkle. Like others have reported on various sites (e.g. StackOverflow), they will occasionally get this JQuery error message:

`Synchronous XMLHttpRequest on the main thread is deprecated because of its detrimental effects to the end user's experience. For more help, check http://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/`

In my case, the offending code was in the JQuery 2.1.4 file:

`xhr.open( options.type, options.url, options.async; options.username, options.password );`

The relevant information at http://xhr.spec.whatwg.org/ states:

`Developers must not pass false for the async argument when the JavaScript global environment is a document environment.`

I could not find use of xhr.open in any of my own JQuery, so I looked in the JQuery source file itself. And there I found the source of the problem:

`jQuery._evalUrl = function( url ) {
    return jQuery.ajax({
        url: url,
        type: "GET",
        dataType: "script",
        async: false,
        global: false,
        "throws": true
    });
};`

Having `async` set to `false` triggers the console log error on my browsers. By changing it to `true`, the problem (i.e. the console error) disappears. Is there a reason why this is set to false when the specs say that doing so is now bad practice as the feature is being deprecated?

title: Types does not explain how named functions can be passed
body:
According to http://api.jquery.com/Types/ "this page documents virtual types like Selectors, enhanced pseudo-types like Events and all and everything you wanted to know about Functions. "

http://api.jquery.com/Types/#Function mentions that "A function in JavaScript can be either named or anonymous." and provides examples of declarations:
`function named() {}`
`var handler = function() {}`

There is however not a word or example about passing named functions, which is supported by numerous jQuery functions such as .change(). The following discussion explains:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/7963609/how-can-i-name-and-call-a-jquery-function

Note that there is no explanation there of how to read the description of functions which take Function arguments. For example, https://api.jquery.com/change/ says:
handler
Type: Function( Event eventObject )

What "Function( foo bar )" means should be specified somewhere.

title: $.map vs javascript .map
CommonJS: avoid a global with a custom window passed to the factory
body:
In a CommonJS scenario [these lines](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/769446c69775f6c44e35cee1bcdeccafba51be7b/src/intro.js#L26-L32) may result in one of 2 things:
1. `window` & `window.document` exists => the exported thing is a jQuery using `window`, the global is not set.
2. otherwise, when a custom implementation is passed to the factory: `require( "jquery" )( window )` the `noGlobal` flag is not passed => global is created.

I thought for a moment we might want to pass along the second parameter but IMO we should just set it to true in such a case without asking for anything. After all, if someone invokes:

``` js
var $ = require( "jquery" )( window );
```

then it's trivial to attach it to the `window` by ourselves if needed. The fact that we behave differently in CommonJS based on the initial setup worries me.

title: Any way for jquery to work with script tags in electron?

The electron guy suggest using require, but this is a bit of a problem for us because of the way components are shared across our web and desktop versions.

I'd like to understand why it's not possible for jquery to be available via window.jQuery or window.$ when it's included in a script tag in electron.  I'd also like to know if there might possibly be some way to get it to work?

Thanks for your help

title: JQuery 1.11.3 Memory Leak on IE8
body:
Hi Guys,

We're developing a website using asp.net and JQuery v.1.11.3. It has frameset and frames (althought it is unsupported in HTML5). Our target clients use IE8 on Windows XP.

We encountered memory leak in IE8 everytime a page is being rendered by the frame element. I have also read several articles which states that there are memory leaks when using frames in IE8.

So how do I confirm it as a bug? Well first I tried our website on other browsers such as Chrome and Firefox and it seems that memory leak doesn't exists. And then I get back to IE8 and downgrading the JQuery version step by step, I started at 1.11.3, 1.11.2, 1.11.1 and then I stopped at 1.11.0, this is the most current version that the memory leak DOESNT exists.

I haven't bump yet into any articles that has the same problem that I encountered, hope you can shed a light regarding this.

Thank you and more power to the JQuery team!

title: [New Feature] Attributes: provide a list of classes when given a selector
body:
This is my first attempt at contributing to jQuery, apologies if I've missed a step. I've read over the contribution guidelines and I'd like to open a discussion on adding a jQuery.classList() function in the attributes module.

I assumed jQuery had a function to list all classes when given a selector until I needed the functionality this morning and stumbled upon this stackoverflow post:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1227286/get-class-list-for-element-with-jquery

This functionality would be easy to build in, and I believe it would add value to the users who for whatever reason need to loop through classes held by an object. I have some questions about what would be the most appropriate output.

Given a selector the function should return an array of classes for the attribute(s). 
1. Should the output array have duplicates removed?
   
   My feeling is that this would be more valuable than having duplicates. If a user wants to know what classes fall under a selector I doubt they would be using it for duplicate entries.
   
   Alternatively, they could use $.unique() to remove duplicate entries.
2. Should the output be sorted in any way?

Does this functionality seem valuable?

title: :target doesn't match elements on initial page load in Chrome and Firefox
Accept 202 HTTP Header
body:
Currently jQuery.ajax only supports HTTP status 204 or 304 to not contain response contend but there are few more HTTP codes which might or might not contain response body such as 202 Accept status. When no body is found for any other responses codes than 204 or 304 jQuery.ajax expects content body and throws an exception `SyntaxError: Unexpected end of input at Object.parse (native) at jQuery.parseJSON` while trying to parse undefined content data. 

I think additional HTTP status codes should be included as optionally having no response body or it should depend on `Content-Length` header and not try to parse data when header is set to `Content-Length: 0`.

title: Data: Feature detect and use `Symbol` if present
body:
JSPerf: http://jsperf.com/defineproperty-vs-symbol-for-privacy

I've noticed that in much of my code, `Data.key` is often near the top of CPU time for initialization when hundreds or thousands of elements have their data initialized (as is sometimes the case using `ngAnimate` in Angular).

By feature detecting the presence of `Symbol` and using it rather than a non-enumerable property, this function went from like 70-100ms CPU time to 0.3 since not only does it not have the overhead of define property, but we can avoid the try/catch in that codepath as well.

title: Iframes that refuse to display still get load event.
body:
In latest Chrome or Firefox, and jQuery 1.11, you will see the iframe loaded here even though it was blocked:

`jQuery('<iframe src="http://www.google.com">').load(function() {console.log(this); console.log('load!');}).appendTo('body')`

I see "Refused to display 'https://www.google.com/?gws_rd=ssl' in a frame because it set 'X-Frame-Options' to 'SAMEORIGIN'.", yet just below it I see the iframe element, and "load!"

Is there a way we can get a notification or error message when iframe isn't actually loading, so the web-app may intelligently fallback to opening in a new window or setting the toplevel window url?

title: jQuery HTML parser corrupts script content that looks like HTML tags (including strings)
body: With functions like .append(html), .repaceWith(html) or even just $(html), if html contains javascript and some content of that script looks like an HTML tag, it will be modified undesirably. E.g. <script type='text/javascript'> alert('<What?/>'); </script> when used as argument for .append() or suchlike produces "<What?></What>" in the alert when it should produce "<What?/>" Example at http://jsfiddle.net/fwaoj0eh/2/ (where you can also see benign [in this case] replacement of <p/> with <p></p>), with workaround (and possible route to fix?). Bug present in jQuery 1.11.3 on all Windows browsers tested (IE7-12, FF, Chrome, Safari, Opera).

title: Make jQuery.isNumeric consistent
body: Some people understand `isNumeric` as, "can I do math on this thing?" Others are asking, "Is this actually a number?" Now that we have no internal usage of `jQuery.isNumeric`, I think we can choose one or the other and update the documentation. Right now, it is inconsistent and a confusing confluence of the two.

title: Only change `%20` to `+` for application/x-www-form-urlencoded
body: This resurrects [trac-3400](http://bugs.jquery.com/ticket/3400) which has the argument for the change. Currently we _always_ change encoded spaces (`%20`) to the plus sign (`+`) in `jQuery.param()`. That is only correct behavior for posted form data, but not other cases. The conversion should be moved to `jQuery.ajax()` and only be done when the method is POST.

title: $.each don't work for array stored in object property
$().prop("tabIndex") returns wrong value (JSBin example included)
body: Hello, $(...).prop("tabIndex") behaves differently in JQuery 1.11.3 and 2.1.4 when Internet Explorer 11 is used. This is true at least for images (dom nodes of type ) that doesn't have an attribute "tabindex" explicitly given. Please see also the playground example here: http://jsbin.com/herehipoke/1/edit?html,output When changing the URL of the loaded jQuery version, you can see that the tabIndex is different ("0" vs. "-1"). This is because of changes in attributes/porp.js file... The propHook for tabIndex is different: The current code line (master and 2.1 stable) show the code of propHooks - tabIndex as follows: ``` javascript get: function( elem ) { return elem.hasAttribute( "tabindex" ) || rfocusable.test( elem.nodeName ) || elem.href ? elem.tabIndex : -1; } ``` 1.11.1 looks like that: ``` javascript get: function( elem ) { var tabindex = jQuery.find.attr( elem, "tabindex" ); return tabindex ? parseInt( tabindex, 10 ) : rfocusable.test( elem.nodeName ) || rclickable.test( elem.nodeName ) && elem.href ? 0 : -1; } ``` I've seen that jQuery Compat 3.0 Alpha uses the 1.11 logic again. Maybe it would make sense to move that kind of logic also into jQuery 2/3 as Internet Explorers are still supprted (at least the newer ones starting from 9 upwards). Best regards, Alexander

title: About the return value of `eq` method
body:
- run `eq` with argument `undefined` return empty array
- run `eq` with argument `null` return the first element

This problem caused by `+undefined` and `+null` have different behavior in javascript, and in `eq` function this happen:

``` js
j = +i + ( i < 0 ? len : 0 ); // i is the argument
```

I don't know whether it's what you want, but maybe it's confused for users.

If this is not an issue, sry for bother, just ignore me.

body:
Using jQuery 1.11.3 in Chrome, I'm not sure if this is a bug or a "nice to have feature", but if you try to do a `$.param()` on something `undefined` it throws the error:

```
Cannot read property 'jquery' of undefined
```

This mainly happens when let's say your passing parameters into a function and sometimes you don't want/need to pass any:

```
function Example (parametersToPass) {
    $.param( parametersToPass );
}


Example(); // <-- will error out.
```

The easiest fix is to simply:

```
$.param( parametersToPass || '' );
```

title: Guard jQuery.extend against non-object arguments (especially strings)
body:
Hi,

When calling the extend method and passing a string as argument, the string is split and character positions are added as property keys with the corresponding characters as values.

![2015-10-04 12 56 10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4307137/10267535/9af4829a-6a98-11e5-9718-949556da0368.png)

Since the docs http://api.jquery.com/jQuery.extend present the function as a way to mix objects, I would never expect this kind of behaviour. When passing a non-object argument (which can always happen when not having added some sort of check before calling extend), I would expect it to be ignored/skipped; e.g. adding an integer is not reflected in the result of an extend operation:

![2015-10-04 13 05 02](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4307137/10267532/98e01a78-6a98-11e5-91ad-249631d8b570.png)

Of course you can sell this as a feature, but I'd rather say this can cause hard to spot bugs…

-Felix

title: jQuery.param() semantically incorrectly handles boolean properties
body:
Boolean values can't be passed to query string explicitly. Because of it `jQuery.param()` turns boolean properties of input object to strings: `true` is turned to `'true'` and `false` is turned to `'false'`. For example: `jQuery.param({ foo: true, bar: false })` returns `'foo=true&bar=false'` (http://codepen.io/anon/pen/BoQXVg).

In most cases server side scripts don't have ability to check whether query variable was originally boolean or string and auto conversion to boolean turns both `'true'` and `'false'` to `true`. It would be great if `jQuery.param()` handles boolean properties like HTML checkbox element does: returns `on` or `1` if the state is `true` and `''` (empty string) if the state is `false`. For example: `jQuery.param({ foo: true, bar: false })` would return `'foo=1&bar='`.

title: minified jquery-1.11.3.min.js has syntax error causing hangs in the isArraylike function
body:

        type = jQuery.type( obj );`
The minification reduces it to:
`function r(a){var b="length"in a&&a.length,c=m.type(a);`
The Firefox Javascript interpreter is misreading this and throwing the following:

`TypeError: invalid 'in' operand a

...]"]=b.toLowerCase()});function r(a){var b="length"in a&&a.length,c=m.type(a);ret...`

Can someone put a space in there between "length" and `in`.

Thanks :)

body:
Some element, lets call it EL1, may have real width as floating point number, for example if the element's width is set by CSS as 25% of parent element which is 345px - our EL1 will have 86.25px width.

When I want to set another element, lets call it EL2, to be the same width as EL1, I can use $(el2).width(el1.width());

However, jquery's width() function returns integer instead of floating point number. Jquery rounds the width. In most cases this is not any problem, but I noticed that sometimes, when the EL1 width is some particular fraction, jquery returns a number which results in EL2 rendeded one pixel off compared to  EL1.

Can be jquery made that it returns floating point widths, as like the browser internally uses, in order to get consistent results all the time? Because if browser accepts floating point widths, but jquery rounds it, it sometimes leads to wrong behavior.

title: How work $.extend method?
html() uses a regular expression that performs badly in IE > 9
body:
rnoInnerhtml = /<(?:script|style|link)/i

The above causes significant performance issues in IE 10 IE 11 and EDGE when inserting large amounts of HTML using the html function.

It can be re-written as the following:
 rnoInnerhtml = /<script|<style|<link/i,

The above performs at the same level in other browsers and exponentially faster in IE .
My tests show for two columns for 4096 rows the difference is 18 seconds versus 5 milliseconds (IE 11). 

http://jsfiddle.net/Lwa0t5rp/3/

Note when testing you the first test will always be slower than the second in chrome / firefox

Ticket logged at Microsoft however i think jQuery should be fixed anyways.
https://connect.microsoft.com/IE/feedback/details/1736512/regular-expressions-are-slower-in-edge-than-in-ie8

title: Select multiple will return null when no values returned
body:
I've just been looking into an issue whereby if you have a `select` element with the `multiple` option set and no options selected `$().val()` will return `null` rather than an empty array. If one more more items are selected, then it returns an array. I would have expected that an empty array would have been returned in this case.

[This fiddle shows the issue](http://jsfiddle.net/jzyyhosx/). IT appears all the way back to jQuery 1.2 where multiple value support was added.

The reason an empty array is not returned is the check for `elem.selectedIndex` being < 0 [here](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/src/attributes/val.js#L87). While I understand that for a single select, I don't while get why that would be done for a multi-select.

Removing `|| index < 0` would allow the empty array to be returned.

Having said that, I'm not really expecting this change to be made as I guess a number of sites will depend upon this behaviour. I'm more wondering if someone might be willing to say why it is done this way? I've searched this issue tracker and the bugs.jquery.com site, but couldn't find any mention of it.

title: .css() for 'animation-delay' attribute cannot be set with variable
body:
I cannot use a variable to change the 'animation-delay' css property.

Note: This will work for something like background color or other animation attributes. The animation-delay will also work with a string '10s' but not a variable--even when the variable is explicitly set to a string.

```
var animationDelayTime = '10s'  
$('.my-animation-class').css({  
  'animation-delay' : animationDelayTime  
})
```

The this other method also does not work:

```
$('.my-animation-class').css(  
  'animation-delay', animationDelayTime  
)
```

This currently works:

```
$('.my-animation-class').css({  
  'animation-delay' : '10s'  
})
```

title: Query.param adds incremented keys to arrays of objects
body:
```
decodeURIComponent(jQuery.param( {a:[{a:1},{a:1},1]} ) )
//=> "a[0][a]=1&a[1][a]=1&a[]=1"
```

So the outer `a` gets incremented keys (`0` and `1` in this case) if the value is an object while it doesn't get a key (just an empty `[]`) when the value is a number (or string).
I would have expected

```
//=> "a[][a]=1&a[][a]=1&a[]=1"
```

I tried this with jQuery version 3.0.0-alpha, 2.1.3, 2.1.0, 2.0.2, 1.11.0 and 1.10.1.

http://jsfiddle.net/7nrwL7pg/

title: ParseHTML removes content in Windows Store App

However, this ruins functionality that is dependent on, for example, comments to work, like the virtual element template binding in Knockout.js.

This could be fixed by changing innerHTML with WinJS.Utilities.setInnerHTMLUnsafe when used in a Windows Store App.

title: Scripts in inner html are not exectuted sequentially in order
body:
When inner HTML contains scripts, one external and other inline, are not executed sequentially in order.

Here is a sample demonstrating the issue: http://jsfiddle.net/8cqa7byq/2/

Above sample uses this as inner HTML: https://gist.githubusercontent.com/junaidpv/8027996b52d8446a7054/raw/e48d8abbea9808549960a84e747e7a58686d0b2a/html-with-script.html
Which contains an external script (twitter widget) and following inline script uses `TWTR` object from previous external script. In my project for @wickwood the inline script is generated dynamically, so I cannot put it on a separate file now.

If you run above fiddle you will get `ReferenceError: TWTR is not defined` on console.

While debugging, I see script tags are processed at https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/1.7.2/jquery.js#L6068
The scripts are considered in correct order, but for unknown reason external script is not get loaded till inline script is executed.

I did search to find if it is already reported and did not find it. Will it have a workaround?

Thanks

body: Not sure if this has to do with more than just this case but it's illustrated here http://jsfiddle.net/69h99rec/ . In other browsers this would log the transition. In edge its just an empty string.

title: jQuery Truck Factor
body:
As part of my PhD research on code authorship, we calculated the Truck Factor (TF) of some popular GitHub repositories.

As you probably know, the [Truck (or Bus) Factor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bus_factor) designates the minimal number of developers that have to be hit by a truck (or quit) before a project is incapacitated. In our work, we consider that a system is in trouble if more than 50% of its files become orphan (i.e., without a main author).

More details on our work in this preprint: https://peerj.com/preprints/1233

We calculated the TF for **jQuery** and obtained a value of **4**.

The developers responsible for this TF are:

Timmy Willison - author of 34% of the files
jaubourg - author of 25% of the files
John Resig - author of 21% of the files
Michał Gołębiowski - author of 17% of the files

To validate our results, we would like to ask **jQuery** developers the following three brief questions:

(a) Do you agree that the listed developers are the main developers of **jQuery**?

(b) Do you agree that **jQuery** will be in trouble if the listed developers leave the project (e.g., if they win in the lottery, to be less morbid)?

(c) Does **jQuery** have some characteristics that would attenuate the loss of the listed developers (e.g., detailed documentation)?

Thanks in advance for your collaboration,

Guilherme Avelino
PhD Student
Applied Software Engineering Group (ASERG)
UFMG, Brazil
http://aserg.labsoft.dcc.ufmg.br/

title: Modify ajaxConvert to return a promise/thenable.
body:
The internal `ajaxConvert` function always returns synchronously. This makes it impossible to support new techniques such as [async `JSON.parse`](http://azimi.me/2015/07/30/non-blocking-async-json-parse.html) by defining custom converters.

Considering:
- Ajax is already asynchronous.
- `ajaxConvert` is in an unreachable private scope.

I propose that we modify `ajaxConvert` to return a promise/thenable. If this is considered beneficial, I'll have a patch up with tests this week.

title: npm shim module for jQuery 1.x compatibility build
body:
Hi there! Any chance to get the npm package for [jquery-compat](https://www.npmjs.com/package/jquery-compat) to have multiple releases tracking the non-beta 1.x versions?

Based on looking at [this thread](https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/5499), shim modules seem like the easiest way to get what I want for now. I'm using npm and browserify to bundle stuff and have reasons to use 2.x in certain bundles and 1.x in others. Basically something like the way I can have both [lodash](https://www.npmjs.com/package/lodash) and [lodash-compat](https://www.npmjs.com/package/lodash-compat) in the same package and require them as needed.

title: Data: new data-as-expando implementation uses delete on DOM nodes
body:
The jQuery3 data changes started doing `delete elem[ expando ]` similar to what jQuery1 originally did (see #1664). jQuery2 previously left the data property on the nodes and never deleted it so this wasn't an issue.
#1664 has the originally jQuery1 discussion. The jsperf mentioned there (http://jsperf.com/cleandata/4) still shows improvements using assign instead of delete with the latest Chrome.

title: `getAttribute` call on `document-fragment`
body:
**Hello jquery community,**

**First of all:**
Here's the [demo](http://pkaske.github.io/polymer-problems/jquery-event-delegation/index.html)

All relevant output show's up in the browser's console.
Here's a screenshot that shows the line in jQuery where the problem happens.
(You can see that `elem` is a `document-fragment`)
![selection_008](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11567985/9084426/e9871192-3b73-11e5-8e19-7cd9f1b75dde.png)

**Source of the demo**
Can be found [here](https://github.com/pkaske/polymer-problems/tree/master/jquery-event-delegation)

**Situation**
You have a delegate click event handler that targets elements by a specific attribute
`$(document).on('click', '[some-attribute]', function() {...});`

You have a custom element that uses html5 templates to create a simple list of items.
Each item has a button to remove the parent item itself from the list.

**What happens**
The click on a items button removes the element before the event reaches the jQuery event handler. At the time the event arrives, the item has been removed and placed in a document fragment. Now jQuery tests the event selector on the document fragment and that fails of course.

I guess the fix would simply be to check if the element tested on the selector actually has a attribute api?

title: ajax response cannot been parsed correctly in iOS chrome browser
body:
I am developing a web application which use ajax request to retrieve data from server side application. The function working fine in all desktop browsers and most mobile browser except iPhone chrome.

The ajax request was sent correctly but the data returned from server was empty in ajax success callback function.

title: jquery munges wheel event
body:
`WheelEvent` has two properties `deltaX` and `deltaY` (see [mdn](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WheelEvent)). Both of these properties are absent on event that jQuery provides for `wheel` event.

``` js
$("#element").on('wheel', function(e) { console.log(e.deltaX); });
```

outputs `undefined`
